finding: The SNP rs993137 exhibited a significant association with 378 traits, primarily focusing on risky behaviors like adventurousness and alcohol consumption. This indicated its crucial role in impulsivity across various cohorts.
title: CADM2 is implicated in impulsive personality and numerous other traits by genome- and phenome-wide association studies in humans and mice

finding: An association was confirmed for rs11288859 near CADM2, contributing to the literature on impulsivity and associated traits.
title: CADM2 is implicated in impulsive personality and numerous other traits by genome- and phenome-wide association studies in humans and mice

finding: Significant association was found for rs35614735 near CADM2, reinforcing earlier findings on its impact on motor impulsivity.
title: CADM2 is implicated in impulsive personality and numerous other traits by genome- and phenome-wide association studies in humans and mice

finding: Associated with CRF-vo2max, this SNP was significant in male samples and showed strong linkage with rs6801957, supporting its relevance to cardiorespiratory fitness.
title: The genetic case for cardiorespiratory fitness as a clinical vital sign and the routine prescription of physical activity in healthcare

finding: The rs7652296 variant within 3p11.1 associated with intelligence and showed significant impacts on network connectivity among temporal and parietal areas, reflecting the genetic underpinnings of cognitive functions.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: The rs2279829 variant in the 3q24 region was linked to risk-taking behaviors and demonstrated strong associations with the interactions among the frontoparietal, cingulo-opercular, and default mode networks, enhancing its relevance in behavioral genetics.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: The rs6762267 variant in 3p12.1 revealed genetic influences in risk-taking traits and was significantly associated with several brain networks like the frontoparietal, suggesting its role in behavioral and neuropsychiatric outcomes.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: The SNP rs6764623 was noted as a causal SNP with an effect size of 0.01 during the GWAS analysis of simulated data.
title: A High-resolution Haplotype-resolved Reference Panel Constructed from the China Kadoorie Biobank Study

finding: The SNP rs2293607 in the 3q26.2 region was associated with an increased risk of multiple cancers (OR=1.11, P=5.8×10^-10), showing consistent results for invasive tumors (OR=1.10, P=1.5×10^-7). This association indicated its role in cancer risk through associations with telomere maintenance.
title: Unraveling the genetic landscape of susceptibility to multiple primary cancers

finding: The SNP rs28654158, located in the ADCY5 locus, had both maternal and fetal effects on gestational duration, suggesting that this SNP influenced the duration of pregnancy positively. This finding was significant due to its dual effect, which was consistent for both maternal and fetal alleles.
title: Genetic effects on the timing of parturition and links to fetal birth weight

finding: The SNP rs11708067, also near the ADCY5 locus, was implicated in birth weight, showing effects that were opposite to those observed for gestational duration. This SNP affected birth weight and was linked to traits relating to glucose metabolism, further highlighting the antagonistic effects between maternal gestational duration alleles and fetal birth weight outcomes.
title: Genetic effects on the timing of parturition and links to fetal birth weight

finding: Also a sentinel variant for short-term effectiveness, rs4686373 showcased genetic connections to varenicline treatment outcomes in smoking cessation.
title: Genome-wide association study of varenicline-aided smoking cessation

finding: Associated with MECOM, this SNP showed significant age-dependent effects in lung function assessments.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide association study improves resolution of genes, pathways and pleiotropy for lung function and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

finding: Associated with cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation and flutter, as well as with waist hip ratio, standing height, and basal metabolic rate.
title: Using human genetics to understand the causes and consequences of circulating cardiac troponin I in the general population

finding: The SNP rs1799988 was associated with increased CCR2 expression (p = 8.2e-5), decreased CCL-2 serum levels (p = 2.41e-9), and increased risk of developing type 1 diabetes (T1D) (p = 7.9e-5). This finding linked rs1799988 to the regulatory mechanisms of the CCR2/CCL2 immune pathway in the context of T1D.
title: The 3p21.31 genetic locus promotes progression to type 1 diabetes through the CCR2/CCL2 pathway

finding: The SNP rs746492 showed significant association with increased CCR2 expression (p = 5.2e-5), decreased CCL-2 serum levels (p = 6.21e-9), and elevated risk of T1D (p = 7.9e-5). The findings indicated that rs746492 contributes to the regulatory role of the CCR2/CCL2 pathway in T1D pathogenesis.
title: The 3p21.31 genetic locus promotes progression to type 1 diabetes through the CCR2/CCL2 pathway

finding: For the SNP rs9290877 in the LPP gene, significant associations were noted in the liability GWAS for asthma but were absent in the binary method. This was consistent with existing literature on the genetic landscape of asthma.
title: Genetic association studies using disease liabilities from deep neural networks

finding: Within the TRANK1 region, the rs6789885 SNP was identified as having a significant association with KLS, displaying the highest odds ratio of 1.53 based on the study findings with a p-value of 8.9×10^-8.
title: Kleine Levin syndrome is associated with birth difficulties and genetic variants in the TRANK1 gene loci

finding: SNP rs11129735 was indicated to show a significant association with KLS, with an associated p-value of 9.9×10^-6. This SNP was also presented with linkage disequilibrium effects that corresponded to other proximal variants.
title: Kleine Levin syndrome is associated with birth difficulties and genetic variants in the TRANK1 gene loci

finding: The SNP rs1516725, located in the DGKG region, was associated with obesity and linked to the mean volume of the hippocampus in ENIGMA2 summary statistics (p < 9 × 10^-4). It was also correlated with the volume of grey matter in the right ventral striatum (p < 10^-26), areas of the brain associated with reward processing and contextual memories, respectively.
title: A Multimodal Foundation Model for Discovering Genetic Associations with Brain Imaging Phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs993137 demonstrated a strong association with ADHD and was paired with the volume of grey matter in the left amygdala (p < 3 × 10^-11) within the COMICAL framework. It was also connected to the mean volume of the inferior temporal cortex in ENIGMA2, a region linked to behavioral inhibition, which is relevant for ADHD.
title: A Multimodal Foundation Model for Discovering Genetic Associations with Brain Imaging Phenotypes

finding: The study found a significant association between the rs17753641 SNP and IL-12p70 levels, with donors having the homozygous major allele exhibiting a higher proportion of IL-12p70 low responders. This finding was part of a larger analysis of five SNPs all located near the IL12A gene relevant for IL-12p70 production in healthy individuals after LPS stimulation.
title: Early IFNβ secretion determines variable downstream IL-12p70 responses upon TLR4 activation in health and disease

finding: This SNP was shown to significantly associate with IL-12p70 production in the context of the five SNPs near the IL12A gene. Similar to rs17753641, individuals homozygous for the major allele were more likely to be classified as IL-12p70 low responders.
title: Early IFNβ secretion determines variable downstream IL-12p70 responses upon TLR4 activation in health and disease

finding: Like the previous SNPs, rs17810546 demonstrated a significant connection to IL-12p70 levels and was part of the panel of SNPs linked to variable responses to LPS in the study, identifying it as a critical genetic variant influencing immune response.
title: Early IFNβ secretion determines variable downstream IL-12p70 responses upon TLR4 activation in health and disease

finding: The rs76830965 SNP was identified as one of the significant genetic variants associated with IL-12p70 secretion. Analysis indicated that homozygous major allele carriers had a higher prevalence of being IL-12p70 low responders compared to heterozygous individuals.
title: Early IFNβ secretion determines variable downstream IL-12p70 responses upon TLR4 activation in health and disease

finding: The SNP rs143060887 was found to significantly correlate with IL-12p70 levels. It was one of five SNPs identified in linkage disequilibrium near the IL12A gene that influenced responses to LPS stimulation, highlighting its role in IL-12p70 production variability.
title: Early IFNβ secretion determines variable downstream IL-12p70 responses upon TLR4 activation in health and disease

finding: Identified in the MOBP gene, this novel variant was associated with diastolic blood pressure (DBP) in a large meta-analysis of individuals of African ancestry, emphasizing the distinct genetic landscape contributing to blood pressure traits in these populations, particularly where variants differ from those seen in European populations.
title: Genomic Exploration of Essential Hypertension in African-Brazilian Quilombo Populations: A Comprehensive Approach with Pedigree Analysis and Family-Based Association Studies

finding: The SNP rs9834970 located on chromosome 3q12.1 was previously associated with lithium response and identified as a significant locus in relation to mania in bipolar disorder, contributing to the understanding of its genetic architecture.
title: Isolating the genetic component of mania in bipolar disorder

finding: Finding indicated that rs13059102 has a notable association with obesity due to its proximity to BCHE, an enzyme involved in the ghrelin pathway.
title: The genetic architecture of changes in adiposity during adulthood

finding: The rs35055419 variant was noted to have a significant association with both p-tau and t-tau levels, contributing to the understanding of genetic influences on Alzheimer's disease biomarkers.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of CSF biomarkers in Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease cohorts

finding: The rs9877502 locus within the 3q28 region was previously shown to be associated with higher CSF tau levels, reinforcing its significance in Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of CSF biomarkers in Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease cohorts

finding: MultiSuSiE fine-mapped the rs4894803 variant at the FNDC3B locus associated with resting heart rate. The variant was not fine-mapped in the Afr47k, Eur47k, or Eur94k datasets due to various reasons including lower minor allele frequency (MAF) in Afr47k and high levels of linked disequilibrium in European cohorts. It was previously implicated in GWAS studies related to resting heart rate.
title: MultiSuSiE improves multi-ancestry fine-mapping in All of Us whole-genome sequencing data

finding: rs9876658 was implicated in the regulation of AMOTL2 expression specifically in SMCs. Extensive analyses, including CRISPR interference validations, demonstrated that this variant, which lies within a functional enhancer, significantly affects AMOTL2 expression, marking it as a novel candidate relevant to atherosclerosis.
title: Single cell variant to enhancer to gene map for coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs1376606, located in an intergenic region near the OSBPL10 gene on chromosome 3p23, was associated with reduced P2Y12 reaction units (PRU) values. It exhibited a significant relationship with PRU (β: -31.38, 95% CI: -43.66 to -19.09, p=7.75·10^-7) and was recognized as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for OSBPL10 in multiple GTEx tissues.
title: Discovery of Ancestry-specific Variants Associated with Clopidogrel Response among Caribbean Hispanics

finding: The SNP rs12495172, located in intron 12-13 of the ERC2 gene, was positively associated with aneuploidy rates in IVF embryos. The study reported a positive beta value of 0.079, indicating that the alternative allele of this SNP correlated with increased aneuploidy risk. Furthermore, eQTL analysis using GTEx project data demonstrated that the alternative allele of rs12495172 was linked to reduced expression of the nearby gene CCDC66, suggesting a potential mechanism whereby decreased CCDC66 expression might contribute to higher levels of aneuploidy.
title: Identifying risk genes for embryo aneuploidy using ultra-low coverage whole-genome sequencing

finding: The rs12629450 found in ST6GAL1 was among the identified variants which contributed notably to the understanding of genetic influences on PSA levels.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The findings indicated that genotype-dependent effects of oxytocin treatment were observed with greater improvements in SRS-2 scores and changes in oxytocin concentrations seen in CC relative to T+ carriers of rs2268491. This SNP was noted to have some preliminary evidence linking it to autism, contributing to variation in response to oxytocin treatment.
title: Infrequent intranasal oxytocin followed by positive social interaction improves symptoms in autistic children: a randomized clinical trial

finding: The rs1491985 SNP was identified as a significant locus associated with chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain (CWP), residing within the RNF123 gene. It was replicated with a meta-analysis p-value of 0.0002, indicating a robust association with CWP.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies RNF123 locus as associated with chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain

finding: The rs10490825 SNP showed suggestive association with CWP, with a p-value of 0.0227 in replication analysis, indicating a consistent direction of effect in five out of six independent replication samples. This SNP is located in the ATP2C1 gene.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies RNF123 locus as associated with chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain

finding: The SNP rs17806888, mapped to the SUCLG2 gene, was identified as part of an epistatic interaction with rs924135 that explained approximately 32% of the variance in clustering participants into bioenergetically distinct groups. This interaction notably influenced the rate of cognitive decline, indicating that specific genotypes could determine how quickly cognitive impairment progresses, especially in the context of Alzheimer's disease.
title: Individual bioenergetic capacity as a potential source of resilience to Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The BP allele of rs843355 showed decreased expression of PSMD2 in various immune cells, including Blood-Neutrophils CD16+ (P = 1.38×10−6) and Blood-Monocytes (P = 1.79×10−6).
title: Pathway-based polygenic score analysis identifies the NRF2-KEAP1 and mRNA splicing - minor pathways as enriched in shared genetic variation between chronotype and bipolar disorder

finding: For rs62287507, the BP allele was linked to increased expression of POLR2H in blood (P = 2.33×10−6), suggesting its role in transcriptional regulation.
title: Pathway-based polygenic score analysis identifies the NRF2-KEAP1 and mRNA splicing - minor pathways as enriched in shared genetic variation between chronotype and bipolar disorder

finding: The risk allele associated with rs6441930 in locus 3p21.31 was linked to reduced IL-6 production in PBMCs stimulated with influenza, further supporting the hypothesis that COVID-19 risk alleles could hinder proper immune response during initial viral infections.
title: A functional genomics approach to understand host genetic regulation of COVID-19 severity

finding: This SNP was associated with the TCTA gene and was significant in the context of genetic contributions to addiction risk.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association meta-analysis of over 1 million subjects identifies loci underlying multiple substance use disorders

finding: Noted for its significance in cannabis use disorder phenotypes, this SNP contributes to understanding substance-related genetic risks.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association meta-analysis of over 1 million subjects identifies loci underlying multiple substance use disorders

finding: This SNP affiliated with CADM2 was highlighted in addiction risk studies, indicating its relevance in the genetic architecture.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association meta-analysis of over 1 million subjects identifies loci underlying multiple substance use disorders

finding: The analysis highlighted rs17011282 within ZNF385D, which revealed a significant interaction with STST for PP in Hispanic populations, achieving a P-value of 5.9×10^-7, marking it significant for hypertension research.
title: A Large-Scale Genome-Wide Study of Gene-Sleep Duration Interactions for Blood Pressure in 811,405 Individuals from Diverse Populations

finding: rs138288695, linked to CRBN, showed interaction with LTST for DBP in Hispanic populations, with P-value of 3.5×10^-7, underlining its potential significance in hypertension.
title: A Large-Scale Genome-Wide Study of Gene-Sleep Duration Interactions for Blood Pressure in 811,405 Individuals from Diverse Populations

finding: rs142966182, linked to ALCAM, was found to interact with LTST for DBP in European populations, achieving a P-value of 1.0×10^-7, showing its importance in blood pressure traits.
title: A Large-Scale Genome-Wide Study of Gene-Sleep Duration Interactions for Blood Pressure in 811,405 Individuals from Diverse Populations

finding: The SNP rs2120789, located in the KALRN gene, showed an ASD-SV found in nearly one-fifth of ASD individuals. Disruption in KALRN was linked to dendritic density alterations in models, enhancing its implication in ASD.
title: Structural Variants Are a Major Component of the Missing Heritability of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs4856257 was connected with ASD through observed SVs in the ROBO1 gene, showing how disruption could correlate with symptoms, as expression was downregulated in ASD individuals.
title: Structural Variants Are a Major Component of the Missing Heritability of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs687813 was flagged as having significant ASD-SVs in ROBO2, reinforcing its association due to prior reports connecting variability in this gene with ASD.
title: Structural Variants Are a Major Component of the Missing Heritability of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs16827974 was identified as a significant finding in the meta-analytic GWAS for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) PA-FGRS, with a beta coefficient of 0.014 and a p-value of 2.9 × 10−8. This finding indicated a consistent sign with an independent MDD GWAS by Howard et al.
title: PA-FGRS is a novel estimator of pedigree-based genetic liability that complements genotype-based inferences into the genetic architecture of major depressive disorder

finding: The SNP rs6780942 was found significant in the MDD case-control GWAS, reporting a beta of 0.085 with a p-value of 7.1 × 10−9. It shared a consistent sign in the independent study by Howard et al.
title: PA-FGRS is a novel estimator of pedigree-based genetic liability that complements genotype-based inferences into the genetic architecture of major depressive disorder

finding: The SNP rs10490770, located on chromosome 3, was identified as a significant genetic risk factor for COVID-19 severity. Carriers of the risk allele exhibited a 40% increased risk of all-cause mortality (HR 1.4) and a 50% increased risk of COVID-19-related mortality (HR 1.5). Additionally, they were associated with increased odds of severe respiratory failure (OR 2.0), venous thromboembolism (OR 1.7), and hepatic injury (OR 1.6). The findings indicated that individuals aged 60 years or younger carrying this allele had even higher odds of death or severe respiratory failure (OR 2.6), compared to those over 60 years (OR 1.5), suggesting a pronounced age-dependent effect. Notably, among those aged 60 or less who died or experienced severe outcomes, 31.8% were carriers of the risk variant. The study emphasized that the predictive ability of the rs10490770 risk allele on severe COVID-19 outcomes was comparable to or superior to most established clinical risk factors.
title: Age-dependent impact of the major common genetic risk factor for COVID-19 on severity and mortality

finding: The SNP rs6783485, associated with the gene LOC105377110, was identified among the top 20 variables significantly correlated with 'fast' PD progression. The presence of the non-reference allele increased the risk for faster progression in patients.
title: Artificial Intelligence-Based Clustering and Characterization of Parkinson’s Disease Trajectories

finding: rs11711441, on chromosome 3 at 183103487, appeared among the top SNPs associated with faster PD progression, where the non-reference allele was linked to a greater risk of accelerated disease.
title: Artificial Intelligence-Based Clustering and Characterization of Parkinson’s Disease Trajectories

finding: This SNP, known as rs7617877 and linked to LINC00693, raised the probability of categorizing patients within the 'moderate' subtype of PD progression.
title: Artificial Intelligence-Based Clustering and Characterization of Parkinson’s Disease Trajectories

finding: Like rs11675342, this SNP was among the seven shared between the hypothyroidism and TSH levels, showcasing its importance in thyroid trait correlations.
title: Uncovering the Shared Genetic Components of Thyroid Disorders and Reproductive Health

finding: This SNP represented a private mutation c.547G>A in the RBSN gene, resulting in a glycine to arginine substitution at position 183 in the FYVE domain of the RBSN protein. It was confirmed to completely segregate with the disease characterized by progressive muscle weakness, facial dysmorphisms, ophthalmoplegia, and intellectual disability in a family of consanguineous Red parents. The mutation was predicted to be deleterious, indicating a likely critical role of this residue in RBSN function.
title: RABENOSYN separation-of-function mutations uncouple endosomal recycling from lysosomal degradation

finding: This SNP caused a homozygous variant c.538C>G leading to a p.Arg180Gly substitution within the PI3P-binding domain of RBSN. It was observed in an unrelated family with overlapping symptoms, including developmental delay, intellectual disability, distal motor axonal neuropathy, and facial dysmorphism, and segregated recessively with disease in affected individuals. Its low frequency (frequency < 1e-5) in GnomAD and lack of homozygous occurrence in large cohorts supported its significance as a pathogenic factor.
title: RABENOSYN separation-of-function mutations uncouple endosomal recycling from lysosomal degradation

finding: The SNP rs6774202 at the BSN/3p21.31 locus was identified as associated with endometriosis and was an original finding. It functioned as an eQTL for various overlapping genes involved in pathways enriched across endometriosis and other immune conditions, particularly associated with leukocyte trans-endothelial migration.
title: The Association between Endometriosis and Immunological diseases

finding: The SNP rs6809879, also at the BSN/3p21.31 locus, was associated with osteoarthritis. This SNP was an original finding and was shown to be an eQTL for overlapping genes involved in immune pathways, further supporting shared genetic factors with endometriosis.
title: The Association between Endometriosis and Immunological diseases

finding: The variant rs2071041 in the ITIH4 gene showed a positive finding in both African and European ancestry cohorts with a beta of 0.0237 (p=4.9e-8) for African ancestry and 0.0180 (p=2.6e-10) for European ancestry, indicating its significance in influencing prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels.
title: Genome-wide association study of prostate-specific antigen levels in 392,522 men identifies new loci and improves cross-ancestry prediction

finding: The SNP in IGF2BP2 (rs4402960) was associated with T2D in males but not in females, showing a significant differential effect based on sex.
title: Sex-specific genetic loci linked to early and late onset type 2 diabetes

finding: For the SNP rs341988, it was reported as insignificant for type 1 diabetes in GWAS with a beta of -0.0009 and a p-value of 0.17. However, in the WGWAS, it was found to be genomewide significant with a beta of -0.004 and a p-value of 1.26 · 10^-8. This finding highlighted the attenuation bias present in the standard GWAS, which had led to missing this genomewide significant locus for type 1 diabetes. This SNP was identified as part of three independent loci that were novel findings in WGWAS.
title: Correcting for volunteer bias in GWAS uncovers novel genetic variants and increases heritability estimates

finding: This SNP was associated with anxiety disorders and had significant overlap with cardiometabolic and hematological traits.
title: Genome-wide association study of major anxiety disorders in 122,341 European-ancestry cases identifies 58 loci and highlights GABAergic signaling

finding: The SNP rs2304725, a synonymous variant in the SLC6A11 gene, was replicated in both the Pain Questionnaire cohort and the Verbal Interview cohort, indicating a strong association with ME/CFS. This SNP was also found in Community 15, which is enriched for GABA synthesis and release and is connected to CNS-related pathways.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for ME/CFS Identified using Combinatorial Analysis

finding: This SNP within LSAMP was replicated across GRaD and ALSPAC analyses, showing potential involvement in reading ability, although the exact manner of influence was unclear.
title: Genetic and Demographic Predictors of Latent Reading Ability in Two Cohorts

finding: The SNP rs1768208 was confirmed as a PSP susceptibility locus with an odds ratio of 0.76 (95%CI=0.64–0.89; p=2.49·10^-04), consistent with earlier findings.
title: A Novel Susceptibility Locus in NFASC Highlights Oligodendrocytes and Myelination in Progressive Supranuclear Palsy Pathology

finding: The SNP rs9836522 was associated with sensitivity to particulate matter (PM2.5), with an odds ratio of 0.75. This suggests a protective effect against asthma exacerbations related to PM2.5 exposure. The gene linked to this variant was PFN2, known for its negative correlation with asthma incidence.
title: GWAS reveals Genetic Susceptibility to Air Pollution-Related Asthma Exacerbations in Children of African Ancestry

finding: This SNP (CACNA2D2) was previously linked to coffee consumption by CCGC, supporting its role in the genetics of habitual coffee drinkers.
title: Habitual Coffee Consumption Increases Risks for Metabolic Diseases: Genome-wide Association Studies and a Phenotype-wide Two Sample Mendelian Randomization Analysis

finding: The minor C-allele of SNP rs9838739 was associated with increased risk for SS as it decreased DNA methylation levels at the intergenic region within the CCR cluster on chromosome 3 (cg03879629). This result highlighted the potential mechanism through which this variant could elevate the susceptibility to SS.
title: An integrative multi-omics approach in Sjögren’s Syndrome identifies novel genetic drivers with regulatory function and disease-specificity

finding: In SS patients, the minor A-allele of SNP rs56077428 was related to increased PLSCR1 expression. This association illustrated a potential role of PLSCR1 in the pathogenesis of SS.
title: An integrative multi-omics approach in Sjögren’s Syndrome identifies novel genetic drivers with regulatory function and disease-specificity

finding: SNP rs9873183 was identified in conjunction with RNF123 expression in the context of endometriosis and IBS. Its linkage disequilibrium with significant SNPs underscores its potential influence in the genetic architecture connecting these conditions.
title: Evidence of shared genetic factors in the aetiology of gastrointestinal disorders and endometriosis and clinical implications for disease management

finding: The SNP rs13092179 was associated with the use of Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering (SERS) spectroscopy in cancer diagnosis, particularly for sensing and characterizing exosomes. This finding contributed to advancements in the diagnostic capabilities of Raman spectroscopy for cancer, indicating a potential genetic influence on the efficacy of these techniques in clinical applications.
title: Applications of Data Characteristic AI-assisted Raman Spectroscopy in Pathological Classification

finding: The association of rs1818163 within the HTR1F locus was significant for sleep apnea in non-obese individuals with a beta of 0.059 and P-value less than 1.58e-8 in the FinnGen study. This finding replicated in the Estonian Biobank with a beta of 0.042 and P-value of 0.046, suggesting a strong link between this SNP and the phenotype of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The signaling co-localized with HTR1F expression across multiple tissues, particularly in neurons, indicating a potential functional role in regulating HTR1F expression relevant to sleep apnea.
title: Regulatory variation at serotonin receptor 1F (HTR1F) modulates arousals and risk for sleep apnea

finding: The SNP rs150312701 represented a germline heterozygous stop-gain mutation p.Arg1953X in the POLQ gene, which co-segregated with disease status in hereditary colorectal cancer (CRC) pedigrees. This mutation was shown to cause a premature termination codon, which resulted in hyperactivation of the error-prone TMEJ DNA repair pathway. Tumor tissues from carriers exhibited microsatellite instability, hypermutation, and resistance to radiotherapy. Furthermore, this mutation had previously been reported as a heterozygous somatic mutation in studies relating to CRC organoid cultures.
title: A germline heterozygous POLQ nonsense mutation causes hereditary colorectal cancer

finding: SNP rs116643249 recorded a p-value of 5.93×10−6. The details of allele frequencies remained undisclosed. It was associated with the CCDC54 gene, crucial for protein interactions.
title: Genomic predictors of response to antidepressants in Major depressive disorder (MDD): A GWAS-Based Study on Indian cohort

finding: The rs6795524 variant was located in the PROS1 locus and revealed additional independent signals while being categorized within previously recognized loci associated with VTE.
title: Cross-Ancestry Investigation of Venous Thromboembolism Genomic Predictors

finding: The rs28479320 variant, identified in the ARL13B locus, displayed significant association signals and was related to VTE risk in prior studies.
title: Cross-Ancestry Investigation of Venous Thromboembolism Genomic Predictors

finding: Variant rs165177, linked to mitral valve prolapse, was predicted to create an SP-like motif instance and regulate LMCD1, highlighting its relevance in valve development.
title: Molecular convergence of risk variants for congenital heart defects leveraging a regulatory map of the human fetal heart

finding: The rs9875219 variant was significantly associated with recurrent miscarriage (P=2.6e-08) and had previously been identified in a GWAS focusing on bone development.
title: Trans-ancestral Genome Wide Association Study of Sporadic and Recurrent Miscarriage

finding: The lead variant rs1991431 in <italic>ZBTB38</italic> exhibited a replicable association with hyperplasia of prostate (BHP) in the FinnGen data. Additionally, associated variants in this locus were linked to various complex traits, including cell counts of lymphocytes and monocytes, as well as <italic>ZBTB38</italic> mRNA expression based on data from the IEU openGWAS project.
title: Meta-analysis of gestational duration and spontaneous preterm birth identifies new maternal risk loci

finding: The T allele of variant rs9846396 was associated with longer gestational duration, with a <italic>Z</italic>-score of 6.36 and a <italic>p</italic> value of 2.04e−10. This variant's alleles were also associated with taller height, higher body mass measures, and an increased risk of prostate cancer. Furthermore, colocalization analysis indicated that variants associated with gestational duration influenced <italic>ZBTB38</italic> expression in monocytes, T cells, and B cells.
title: Meta-analysis of gestational duration and spontaneous preterm birth identifies new maternal risk loci

finding: This variant was shown to increase mutation counts specifically in females within the SMC4 locus, highlighting a sex-specific aspect of clonal hematopoiesis.
title: The Genetic Determinants and Genomic Consequences of Non-Leukemogenic Somatic Point Mutations

finding: Identified in the SMC4 locus fine-mapping, rs1451760 was associated with mutation burden modification, showcasing its relevance in hematopoietic pathway studies.
title: The Genetic Determinants and Genomic Consequences of Non-Leukemogenic Somatic Point Mutations

finding: Found within the SMC4 locus, rs6790951 was one of the variants linked to increased mutation counts, further implicating SMC4 in the genetic basis of clonal phenomena.
title: The Genetic Determinants and Genomic Consequences of Non-Leukemogenic Somatic Point Mutations

finding: The variant rs445676 in the TLR9 gene exhibited the highest positive effect on predicting plasma levels of the TIMP2 protein. This association was connected to cognitive performance, specifically in global cognition and memory, suggesting that TLR9 may play an essential role in regulating TIMP2 levels that influence brain health.
title: Polygenic proxies of age-related plasma protein levels reveal TIMP2 role in cognitive performance

finding: The variant rs76685449 in the SMIM4 gene, located near the TLR9 gene, was identified as the most statistically significant variant but had the highest negative effect on TIMP2 protein levels. This finding indicated a potentially adverse regulatory role by SMIM4 on TIMP2 expression.
title: Polygenic proxies of age-related plasma protein levels reveal TIMP2 role in cognitive performance

finding: The prostate cancer lead SNP rs4857906 was found in the eRNA region of the GATA2 gene, exhibiting the highest posterior probability of being a causal SNP for prostate cancer.
title: Enhancer RNA transcriptome-wide association study reveals an atlas of pan-cancer susceptibility eRNAs

finding: The SNP rs13059657 was part of a narrowed linkage region identified in the study, which was defined by phased haplotypes in affected family members. It contributed to linkage analysis showing that individuals with a Type 1 EKG pattern or positive procainamide test formed a significant association, leading to a LOD score of 2.02, and 3.18 when including individuals with Type II EKG patterns.
title: Additional Evidence Implicating GPD1L in the Pathogenesis of Brugada Syndrome in A Large Multi-generational Family

finding: Similar to rs13059657, the SNP rs7651953 defined the 3' breakpoint of a narrowed linkage region in this investigation. The study indicated that individuals carrying this SNP in combination with others showed significant associations with Brugada Syndrome, reinforcing its relevance in the genetic underpinnings of the disease.
title: Additional Evidence Implicating GPD1L in the Pathogenesis of Brugada Syndrome in A Large Multi-generational Family

finding: The rs10428132 SNP, associated with the SCN10A gene, was found to be homozygous in 8 out of 15 affected individuals, indicating strong genetic predisposition within the family for Brugada Syndrome, particularly characterised by Type I, II, or III EKG patterns.
title: Additional Evidence Implicating GPD1L in the Pathogenesis of Brugada Syndrome in A Large Multi-generational Family

finding: The SNP rs11708996 related to the SCN5A gene was identified as heterozygous in 12 of the 15 affected subjects. This finding underscored the role of SCN5A risk alleles in co-segregation with the GPD1L-A280V mutation and contributed to the overall genetic risk profile for affected members of the family.
title: Additional Evidence Implicating GPD1L in the Pathogenesis of Brugada Syndrome in A Large Multi-generational Family

finding: The variant rs832190 was identified as a candidate causal variant affecting schizophrenia (SZ), bipolar disorder (BD), and sitting height linked to the gene THOC7. It was determined through the integration of GWAS and eQTL results, yielding colocalization posterior probabilities (CLPP) greater than 0.05.
title: Trans-ethnic eQTL meta-analysis of human brain reveals regulatory architecture and candidate causal variants for brain-related traits

finding: The variant rs73064425 was linked to severe COVID-19 susceptibility through several studies, confirming it as one of the strongest severity loci. The original findings indicated an odds ratio (OR) of 2.14, with a very low discovery p-value of 4.77 × 10^-30. In the context of the ODYSSEY trial cohort of hospitalized patients, this association was further replicated with an OR of 3.2 and a p-value less than 0.0001. This genetic variant was situated within the 3p21.31 locus, in high linkage disequilibrium with other variants, and its higher minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.19 was observed in this cohort compared to global populations.
title: Role of FYVE and Coiled-Coil Domain Autophagy Adaptor 1 in severity of COVID-19 infection

finding: The variant rs33910087 was identified as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for CXCR6, and demonstrated a highly significant association with monocyte percentage (p=3.8479e-46) in the analysis of the Odyssey data. This variant was also associated with three coding mutations within the FYCO1 gene, resulting in two amino acid substitutions. The strong linkage disequilibrium (LD) with the top SNPs in the region highlighted its critical role in severe COVID-19 susceptibility.
title: Role of FYVE and Coiled-Coil Domain Autophagy Adaptor 1 in severity of COVID-19 infection

finding: Variant rs1561072 was associated with any TP53 mutation and TP53 gain of function mutations, with significant P values <1.0×10^-6 across multiple analyses.
title: Association of ESR1 germline variants with TP53 somatic variants in breast tumors in a genome-wide study

finding: The variant rs3020779, an eQTL for RNF123, was associated with multiple cancers in the prostate cancer-specific analysis, suggesting a role in tumor suppression mechanisms.
title: Assessment of Genetic Susceptibility to Multiple Primary Cancers through Whole-Exome Sequencing in Two Large Multi-Ancestry Studies

finding: The novel variant rs35593046, located within the CACNA1D gene, had a protective role against high blood pressure and was observed more frequently in East Asians (53.8%) than in Europeans (26.8%). This SNP was identified in the all-cause HF and non-ischemic HF studies with effect sizes of -0.0630 and -0.0767, respectively.
title: Genome-wide analysis of heart failure yields insights into disease heterogeneity and enables prognostic prediction in the Japanese population

finding: The SNP rs73062389 located at the SLC6A20 locus on chromosome 3 was discovered to be significantly associated with SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility in a genome-wide association study conducted on a European population, with a P-value of 2.315 × 10^-12. This finding indicated that variants at this locus may play a crucial role in modulating susceptibility to the infection.
title: Genetic risk factors associated with SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility in multiethnic populations

finding: The SNP rs73062394 located at the LZTFL1 locus was significantly associated with SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility in the European cohort, yielding a P-value of 4.401 × 10^-11. This finding suggested that the LZTFL1 gene might be critically involved in the biological pathways influencing susceptibility to the virus.
title: Genetic risk factors associated with SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility in multiethnic populations

finding: The SNP rs6762208 in the SENP2 gene was shown to correlate with an increased risk of insulin resistance (IR). Individuals possessing the A/C-C/C genotypes had an odds ratio of 3.11, with a confidence interval of 1.55-6.24 (p < 0.0013), supporting the association under a dominant inheritance model.
title: Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Insulin Resistance Risk in Normal BMI Indians

finding: This SNP was identified as a trans-pQTL for VEGF-R3, where the C allele was linked to decreased plasma levels, validating previous studies that reported similar associations.
title: Common variation in a long non-coding RNA gene modulates variation of circulating TGF-β2 levels in metastatic colorectal cancer patients (Alliance)

finding: The SNP rs73062389 was included in the 95% credible set of GWAS signals and was previously reported in the context of earlier variants of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Central role of glycosylation processes in human genetic susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infections with Omicron variants

finding: The SNP rs13100262 (located in the RPL24 gene) had been previously reported associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection related to earlier variants, showing an odds ratio indicating it was a risk factor.
title: Central role of glycosylation processes in human genetic susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infections with Omicron variants

finding: The SNP rs13322149 was the strongest associated signal (OR 0.857) in the study, located within ST6GAL1, affecting immune development and linked to susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Central role of glycosylation processes in human genetic susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infections with Omicron variants

finding: The rs116421102 SNP in CHL1 showed an association with a p-value of 2.5 × 10^-5, suggesting its impact on longevity.
title: Genetic associations with human longevity are enriched for oncogenic genes

finding: The SNP rs121912698 served as a top pQTL site identified in a previous study that linked aminoacylase 1 levels to the plasma levels of N-acyl-alpha amino acids, specifically N-acetylvaline, N-acetylglutamate, and N-acetylmethionine. This analysis was conducted to evaluate its causal effects on the risk of type 2 diabetes through the relationship with aminoacylase 1, as demonstrated using two-sample Mendelian randomization. This finding highlighted the potential role of plasma metabolites in influencing type 2 diabetes risk.
title: Metabolome-wide Mendelian randomization characterizes heterogeneous and shared causal effects of metabolites on human health

finding: The SNP rs9851257 exhibited variation in effect allele frequency (EAF) within the GIFTS cohort. This finding underscored the SNP's role in the analysis of genetic factors related to birth weight in South Asians, complementing the overall investigation into genetic mechanisms influencing fetal growth in different populations.
title: Associations of genetic scores for birth weight with newborn size and later Anthropometric traits and cardiometabolic risk markers in South Asians

finding: The finding for rs1046956, a coding variant in the gene SEMA3F, indicated that increased expression of this gene was linked to higher chronic pain risk. This suggestion was supported by eQTL colocalization evidence, and the study highlighted SEMA3F's role in axon guidance and pathfinding of sensory neurons, which are crucial in chronic pain mechanisms.
title: GWAS of Extended Prescription Analgesic Use Identifies Novel Genetic Loci in Chronic Pain

finding: The rs13874 variant associated with SLC25A26 was positively linked to 2,3-dihydroxy-5-methylthio-4-pentenoate (DMTPA), highlighting its significance in mitochondrial SAM transport.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: rs7617877 was identified as a significant contributor to Parkinson's disease (PD) risk, specifically associated with eQTL effects for the gene EAF1-AS1 in the heart atrial appendage. It accounted for approximately 3% of the total model weight in analyses.
title: Machine learning identifies six genetic variants and alterations in the Heart Atrial Appendage as key contributors to PD risk predictivity

finding: Similar to rs7617877, rs6808178 also significantly contributed to PD risk and was linked to eQTL effects for the gene EAF1-AS1 in the heart atrial appendage, representing approximately 3% of the model weight.
title: Machine learning identifies six genetic variants and alterations in the Heart Atrial Appendage as key contributors to PD risk predictivity

finding: The SNP rs2777888 was associated with the expression of the gene NAA80 in the anterior cingulate cortex of the brain. This association was highlighted in a meta-analysis of a PTSD GWAS, indicating a significant genetic relationship with PTSD. The finding underscores the relevance of NAA80 in neuropsychiatric conditions and contributes to the understanding of the genetic architecture underlying post-traumatic stress disorder.
title: Identifying potential risk genes and pathways for neuropsychiatric and substance use disorders using intermediate molecular mediator information

finding: The study indicated that the haplotype associated with the lead SNP rs73064425 on chromosome 3 was correlated with a doubling of the occurrence of severe respiratory disease in COVID-19 patients, as supported by previous genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This haplotype was linked to genes important in the immune response, including cytokine receptors involved in the cytokine storm.
title: Potential associations of selected polymorphic genetic variants with COVID-19 disease susceptibility and severity

finding: The rs6772228 SNP, related to the PXK gene, was associated with total cholesterol levels, which is an important factor in cardiovascular health. This connection highlighted the broader implications of shorter TL on cardiac imaging results in the study's framework.
title: Leukocyte Telomere Length and Cardiac Structure and Function: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The SNP rs73842644 was significantly associated with gestational length, showing a beta value of -0.667 and a P-value of 4.9×10^-8. This association suggested a reduction in gestational length, implicating a genetic risk factor for preterm birth.
title: Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Adverse Pregnancy Outcomes in Nulliparas

finding: The SNP rs72956265 was one of three loci significantly associated with gestational diabetes, with an odds ratio (OR) of 3.09 and a P-value of 2.98×10^-8. This variant is an intronic SNP located in the ZBTB20 gene, which regulates beta cell function and glucose homeostasis.
title: Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Adverse Pregnancy Outcomes in Nulliparas

finding: The SNP rs61167087, in conjunction with rs72956265, showed significant association with gestational diabetes and is an intronic variant in the ZBTB20 gene, which is implicated in the regulation of insulin secretion.
title: Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Adverse Pregnancy Outcomes in Nulliparas

finding: The rs4058156 SNP, located in the RUVBL1 gene, was associated with endometriosis, having a significant p-value of 3.51E-10. This locus was among the seven previously unreported loci identified in the study, indicating its novel contribution to the understanding of endometriosis.
title: Expanding the genetic landscape of endometriosis: Integrative -omics analyses uncover key pathways from a multi-ancestry study of over 900,000 women

finding: The rs9870207 SNP at 3q28 locus showed a significant association with endometriosis, with a p-value of 4.17E-09. This locus was also newly reported in this GWAS, highlighting its relevance to the disease.
title: Expanding the genetic landscape of endometriosis: Integrative -omics analyses uncover key pathways from a multi-ancestry study of over 900,000 women

finding: Identified in connection with cancer-related traits, rs73187787 presents further insights into genetic factors influencing cancer.
title: Genome-wide association studies in a large Korean cohort identify novel quantitative trait loci for 36 traits and illuminates their genetic architectures

finding: The SNP rs2019689 located near the MBNL1 gene on chromosome 3 exhibited a significant association with knee pain in males, with a p value of 6.51 × 10^-9. This association implies a potential role in post-transcriptional regulation related to knee pain.
title: A Genome-wide Association Study Identifies Novel Genetic Variants Associated with Knee Pain in the UK Biobank (N = 441,757)

finding: Located in an intronic region of STAG1, this SNP was identified as an EUR-specific signal associated with RA.
title: Trans-ancestry genome-wide association study identifies novel genetic mechanisms in rheumatoid arthritis

finding: The SNP rs1354034 was associated with elevated levels of YBX2. This SNP was also investigated for its relationship with the ARHGEF3 locus, which influences platelet counts. Additionally, the variant linked to over 1,000 SOMAmers in a recent pQTL study.
title: Genome and epigenome wide studies of plasma protein biomarkers for Alzheimer’s disease implicate TBCA and TREM2 in disease risk

finding: The SNP rs80064213 was associated with the oxo-MiNP_oh-MiNP ratio near the FECHP1 gene, showing a positive original finding with an effect size of 0.331 and a p-value of 4.15E-08.
title: Common genetic variants associated with urinary phthalate levels in children: a genome-wide study

finding: The rs750567016 variant in the ST6GAL1 gene was identified to affect IgG glycosylation and was more than 300 times more common in ORCADES compared to the UK Biobank or gnomAD.
title: Exome sequencing reveals aggregates of rare variants in glycosyltransferase and other genes influencing immunoglobulin G and transferrin glycosylation

finding: The SNP rs35092096 was found to have a significant association with the proportion of CCR6+CCR7-CCR5+ regulatory T cells in patients with type 1 diabetes (T1D). Specifically, the presence of the minor allele T in this SNP correlated with an increased ratio of these T regulatory cells, suggesting its role in T1D pathogenesis.
title: Genetic and environmental effects on the immune phenotypes in type 1 diabetes

finding: The T1D risk allele rs11574435-T was located in strong linkage disequilibrium with rs113010081 and was associated with increased percentages of CCR5+ CD4+ T cells and decreased percentages of CCR5-CD4+ T cells, highlighting its impact on T cell composition in T1D.
title: Genetic and environmental effects on the immune phenotypes in type 1 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs113010081 was shown to be in strong linkage disequilibrium with rs11574435, impacting T cell composition in patients with T1D by affecting the proportion of CCR5+ CD4+ T cells.
title: Genetic and environmental effects on the immune phenotypes in type 1 diabetes

finding: This SNP was identified as significant in QTL mapping and associated with T cell subpopulations specifically expressing chemokine receptors, indicating a role in mediating immune responses among T1D patients.
title: Genetic and environmental effects on the immune phenotypes in type 1 diabetes

finding: The variant rs6795209 was located in the <italic>HTR1F</italic> gene which encodes serotonin 5-HT<sub>1F</sub> receptor, showing robust evidence of association with migraine with a <italic>P</italic> value of 1.23 × 10<sup>− 8</sup>.
title: Genome-wide analysis of 102,084 migraine cases identifies 123 risk loci and subtype-specific risk alleles

finding: For rs61069053, located in an intergenic region between CRYGS and DGKG, significant interaction with vitamin use was documented (p<sub>GE</sub>=1.05×10<sup>−5</sup>). The minor allele (G) led to higher estimated odds of NSCL/P in individuals without vitamin use, but lower odds in those who utilized vitamins.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: This intronic variant in ARHGEF3 was uniquely associated with females and had a P-value of 1.8 x 10^-8, adding to evidence of sex-specific genetic influences on fat distribution.
title: Inherited basis of visceral, abdominal subcutaneous and gluteofemoral fat depots

finding: The Val15Phe (rs9290264) SNP in the SI gene was also classified as a hypomorphic variant, detected in 113 patients. This variant was associated with a greater likelihood of responding to the low FODMAP diet, further supporting the influence of hCAZyme genetic variations on dietary response in IBS patients.
title: Functional variation in human Carbohydrate-Active enZYmes (hCAZymes) in relation to the efficacy of a FODMAP-reducing diet in IBS patients

finding: The SNP rs2581789 was previously identified as a genome-wide significant locus for OCD. In this analysis, it was refined to rs2564930, which became the lead SNP, indicating its importance in OCD.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies new loci associated with OCD

finding: The SNP rs2564930 emerged as the lead SNP at the previously identified locus rs2581789, which had associations with various psychiatric disorders, affirming its significance in OCD.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies new loci associated with OCD

finding: Identified in the 3p12.3 region, the SNP rs7429614 was linked to the mode of anisotropy (MO) of the corticospinal tract, showing significant associations with sleep conditions.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The 3p21.31 variant rs10865954 showed association with fractional anisotropy (FA) of the fornix-stria terminalis in connection with insomnia.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The rs145367119 SNP located in 3p11.1 was linked to resting fMRI phenotypes related to sleep.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: Identified in the 3q13.11 region, rs34967119 was associated with the right cuneus' effects on sleep.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs13082684 was reported as significant in the GenLang consortium study concerning reading and spelling abilities, validating its association with dyslexia.
title: Discovery of 42 Genome-Wide Significant Loci Associated with Dyslexia

finding: The coding variant rs138043992 in KIF15 detected in fine-mapping suggested a potential deleterious impact with an odds ratio of 1.71, particularly enriched in the Finnish population.
title: Leveraging global multi-ancestry meta-analysis in the study of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis genetics

finding: The variant rs13059238, located in the FYCO1 gene, was associated with severe COVID-19 and hospitalisation phenotypes in the analysis, supporting its role as a genetic determinant of disease severity.
title: Exome-wide association study to identify rare variants influencing COVID-19 outcomes: Results from the Host Genetics Initiative

finding: The SNP rs41289622, also found in the FYCO1 gene, was identified to be associated with the hospitalisation phenotype, reinforcing FYCO1's significance in COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Exome-wide association study to identify rare variants influencing COVID-19 outcomes: Results from the Host Genetics Initiative

finding: The variant rs141045534, located in the LIMD1 gene, was found to be associated with the susceptibility phenotype, marking it as an important locus in understanding COVID-19 susceptibility.
title: Exome-wide association study to identify rare variants influencing COVID-19 outcomes: Results from the Host Genetics Initiative

finding: Identified in the OUD-MTAG analysis, this SNP was linked with the NICN1 gene and showed significant association with OUD, contributing to the understanding of genetic influences on opioid use disorder.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: This SNP linked to the PLCL2 gene was found to be GWS in the OUD-MTAG study, offering insights into the genetic architecture of opioid use disorder.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: The variant rs2241766 (+45T>G) was associated with metabolic syndrome (MetS) in North Indian women. Specifically, the frequency of the combined mutant genotype (TG+GG) was significantly lower (p=0.017) in MetS women, and the mutant G allele was found at a higher frequency (p=0.008) compared to the wild type. The mutant genotype GG was significantly linked to lower adiponectin levels, higher leptin levels, and increased HOMA-IR (all p<0.001) in MetS women.
title: Linking Adiponectin Gene Variants (+45T>G and +276G>T) to Adipokine Levels and Metabolic Syndrome in a North Indian Adult Women

finding: The variant rs1501299 (+276G>T) showed significant findings in the context of metabolic syndrome. The frequency of the mutant T allele was significantly lower (p=0.027) in MetS women compared to those without MetS. Additionally, the mutant genotypes TT were significantly associated with lower adiponectin levels, higher leptin levels, and increased HOMA-IR (all p<0.001) in MetS women.
title: Linking Adiponectin Gene Variants (+45T>G and +276G>T) to Adipokine Levels and Metabolic Syndrome in a North Indian Adult Women

finding: The lead variant rs3887925 was unique within the 99% credible set for the gene RPL39L. This SNP was associated with increased RPL39L expression and linked to type 2 diabetes, showing expression changes that were consistent with its effects in human islet studies.
title: Identification of novel type 1 and type 2 diabetes genes by co-localization of human islet eQTL and GWAS variants with colocRedRibbon

finding: The SNP rs11708067 influenced ADCY5 expression, decreasing it and increasing type 2 diabetes risk. Its effects were evident in multiple metabolic traits, emphasizing its critical role in glucose homeostasis.
title: Identification of novel type 1 and type 2 diabetes genes by co-localization of human islet eQTL and GWAS variants with colocRedRibbon

finding: Through trans-ancestry colocalization, the SNP chr3:50297330:A:G was discovered as a significant finding associated with the gene RHOA and linked to schizophrenia.
title: Brain eQTLs of European, African American, and Asian ancestry improve interpretation of schizophrenia GWAS

finding: The SNP rs1991545 was specifically associated with focal epilepsy (FE) and was located in the SLC33A1 gene. This finding contributed to the understanding of transporter-associated genes in epilepsy development.
title: Systematic review of genome wide association studies (GWAS) of epilepsy identifies common risk variants and associated genes

finding: The c.316G>A (p.Asp106Asn) variant in the QARS1 gene was similarly identified in 3% of patients. This variant, which replaces aspartic acid with asparagine, was noted to be associated with a syndrome related to microcephaly and seizures. The consistency of these findings across multiple unrelated patients led to the consideration of these variants as potentially pathogenic and possibly causative in the development of epilepsy.
title: Previously defined variants of uncertain significance may play an important role in epilepsy and interactions between certain variants may become pathogenic

finding: Linked to astrocyte gene DGKG, this SNP showed significant colocalization with POAG GWAS signals, indicating that alterations in DGKG expression in astrocytes could drive the risk associated with POAG.
title: Integrating genetic regulation and single-cell expression with GWAS prioritizes causal genes and cell types for glaucoma

finding: The SNP rs17763742, located near the LZTFL1 gene, was previously known and showed a significant association with COVID-19 hospitalization, critical illness, and infection risk specifically among males, highlighting a sex-differential impact.
title: A genome-wide association study of COVID-19 related hospitalization in Spain reveals genetic disparities among sexes

finding: The SNP rs35731912 was previously associated with COVID-19 severity in European populations and was mapped to the LZTFL1 gene, thus confirming its relevance in the context of COVID-19 hospitalization.
title: Novel risk loci for COVID-19 hospitalization among admixed American populations

finding: The SNP rs6794370 was identified as being highly associated with the polygenic architecture of the 'Hemochromatosis Brain' phenotype, showing a significant association with a p-value of 2.43×10^-81. It is located near the transferrin gene (TF), which is important for iron transport in the blood.
title: Polygenic architecture of a novel MRI endophenotype: the “hemochromatosis brain”

finding: The SNP rs6768326 on chromosome 3 was associated with a beta of 1.52 and a p-value of 9.26×10^-8, indicating a significant correlation to the phenotype in the analyzed cohort. This association was observed near the gene RAP2B but was not reproducible due to different genotyping platforms.
title: Phenotypic and genetic factors are associated with absence of cardiomyopathy symptoms in PLN c.40_42delAGA carriers

finding: The rs2276868 SNP located in the promoter region of RPL14 exhibited significant associations with nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) susceptibility in both familial (FHNPC) and all cases (ALLNPC) study groups, with odds ratios indicating a robust genetic predisposition (OR_FHNPC = 1.575; OR_ALLNPC = 1.242). Further analyses demonstrated that this SNP regulated RPL14 expression, influencing the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) life cycle and NPC pathogenesis.
title: Whole-Exome Sequencing Association Study Implicates Genetic Effects on Viral Oncogenesis and Tumor Microenvironment in Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

finding: The rs7618658 locus, a common polymorphism in <italic>SNX4</italic>, was identified as a protective factor for HAPC in both Tibetan and Han populations (P < 5e-8). It showed significant correlations with multiple blood phenotypes, including hemoglobin levels.
title: Differences in pathogenetic mechanism between Tibetan and Han high-altitude polycythemia based on a whole genome-wide association study

finding: The study found that homozygous individuals with the AADAC rs1803155 G>A substitution had a 17.3% lower clearance of rifampicin compared to heterozygous and wild type alleles (p=0.0015). This highlighted the significance of AADAC in rifampicin deacetylation.
title: A Nanopore sequencing-based pharmacogenomic panel to personalize tuberculosis drug dosing

finding: The variant rs2069123, located intronically within the CADM2 gene, was identified as the top association in the sensation seeking GWAS, with a highly significant p-value of 8.85×10^-98. This variant was previously linked to sensation seeking and related traits, emphasizing its role in the genetic architecture underlying sensation seeking behavior.
title: Neurogenetic and multi-omic sources of overlap among sensation seeking, alcohol consumption, and alcohol use disorder

finding: The variant rs187941554 was associated with a substantially raised risk of incident ischemic stroke, with a hazard ratio of 5.44 (95% CI 1.33 to 22.30, p=0.019), although it was not significantly associated with MIs (HR 1.20; 95% CI 0.62 to 2.32, p=0.58). This association was based on a small number of heterozygotes (n=32) and only two incident strokes.
title: Genetic variation in activating clopidogrel: longer-term outcomes in a large community cohort

finding: The variant was identified in a novel locus between the RBMS3 and TGFBR2 genes & significantly associated with sTREM2 levels (P=3.86×10^-9). Functional studies indicated that modulation of TGFBR2 could affect sTREM2 levels, supporting the hypothesis that it is a regulator in this pathway.
title: Proteo-genomics of soluble TREM2 in cerebrospinal fluid provides novel insights and identifies novel modulators for Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The rs35081325 SNP at the LZTFL1 locus was replicated as a strong risk variant for severe COVID-19 in Japanese individuals, particularly in younger cases, with an odds ratio of 11.8 (95% CI = 1.64-85.5, p = 0.014), despite its rare frequency among the population.
title: Japan COVID-19 Task Force: a nation-wide consortium to elucidate host genetics of COVID-19 pandemic in Japan

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with the linear coefficient of cervical change and is located near the IL12A gene, which is involved in immune responses and inflammation. Its association suggests a role in maternal-fetal immune tolerance during pregnancy.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Cervical Length is Shared with Spontaneous Preterm Birth Risk

finding: The SNP rs6777173, which is located 12 kb upstream of KLF15, was identified as an interacting SNP with implications for the disease definition regarding severe long COVID.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Severe and Fatigue Dominant Long COVID and Commonalities with ME/CFS Identified by Combinatorial Analysis

finding: The SNP rs1015164, correlating with CCR1 expression levels, showed a higher frequency in the Indian population, suggesting possible implications for COVID-19 risk.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: As a variant affecting AHSG levels, rs2248690 showed the least frequency in the Indian population, thus possibly increasing the risk of COVID-19 severity.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: SNP BHLHE40 rs4496464 was associated with increased BHLHE40 expression in monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs) and with increased IL-10 production from peripheral blood dendritic cells and MDMs following LPS and TB whole cell lysate (TBWCL) stimulation.
title: CNBP, REL, and BHLHE40 variants are associated with IL-12 and IL-10 responses and tuberculosis risk

finding: SNP BHLHE40 rs11130215 was associated with increased BCG-specific IL2+CD4+ T cell responses and was linked to a decreased risk for pediatric TB in South Africa.
title: CNBP, REL, and BHLHE40 variants are associated with IL-12 and IL-10 responses and tuberculosis risk

finding: SNP CNBP rs11709852 was associated with increased IL-12 production from dendritic cells following TBWCL stimulation, suggesting its influence in immune response.
title: CNBP, REL, and BHLHE40 variants are associated with IL-12 and IL-10 responses and tuberculosis risk

finding: The variant rs6762719 impacted levels of the transferrin protein LTF, indicating it played a role in regulating iron binding capacity relevant to its physiological functions.
title: Plasma Proteome Variation and its Genetic Determinants in Children and Adolescents

finding: The inframe deletion in CACNAD10, identified as rs72556363, was associated with a modest increase in hypertension. This finding was significant in the context of aldosterone-producing adenomas and primary aldosteronism, linking the variant to hypertension risk.
title: Analysis of 200,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subjects implicates genes involved in increased and decreased risk of hypertension

finding: A potentially novel association was found in the 3p22.1 region at rs72419458 near the POMGNT2 gene (p=2.4e-8, MAF=0.072, OR=0.621) suggesting it may be associated with cleft lip.
title: Large-scale trans-ethnic replication and discovery of genetic associations for rare diseases with self-reported medical data

finding: For spontaneous pneumothorax, a significant association was found at rs4437193 in the KY gene (p=3.7e-10, MAF=0.38699, OR=0.7535), with unclear causal mechanisms due to linkage with splice variants.
title: Large-scale trans-ethnic replication and discovery of genetic associations for rare diseases with self-reported medical data

finding: Relying on linkage disequilibrium, rs35934324 was associated with rs4437193 in the KY gene region, contributing to the findings in spontaneous pneumothorax.
title: Large-scale trans-ethnic replication and discovery of genetic associations for rare diseases with self-reported medical data

finding: Similar to rs35934324, this SNP is linked with rs4437193 in the KY gene, reaffirming the association in the context of spontaneous pneumothorax.
title: Large-scale trans-ethnic replication and discovery of genetic associations for rare diseases with self-reported medical data

finding: The rs2260685:T>C variant, an intronic variant in MUC4, was found to increase the risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection with an OR of 1.03 (P = 4.1 × 10^-8).
title: A second update on mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19

finding: The missense variant rs2259292:C>T in MUC4 was in linkage with rs2260685, contributing to the increase in risk for SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: A second update on mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19

finding: The rs10511087 SNP, found within the CADM2 gene, was associated positively with both AUD and BMI, exhibiting concordant effect directions. This SNP was linked to cognitive traits and metabolic phenotypes, asserting its role in both obesity and alcohol consumption behaviors.
title: Alcohol use disorder and body mass index show genetic pleiotropy and shared neural associations

finding: The SNP rs13071605 was identified in a study examining the relationship between genotype and phenotype in heritable retinoblastoma. The context of this finding was significant as it contributed to understanding the genetic basis of this condition, impacting diagnostic and treatment approaches.
title: Evaluating whole genome sequencing for rare diseases in newborn screening: evidence synthesis from a series of systematic reviews

finding: The SNP rs114108468 was identified at the 3q28 locus as having a significant association with the change in triglyceride/high density lipoprotein cholesterol ratio (ΔTHR). It was linked to a higher ΔTHR with a beta value of 1.965 (p = 5.68e-6), and was noted to have a positive impact on the expression of the genes EIF4A2 and ADIPOQ.
title: Novel Loci (EIF4A2, ADIPOQ, TPRG1) for Triglyceride / High-density Lipoprotein Cholesterol Ratio Longitudinal Change (ΔTHR) among Subjects without Type 2 Diabetes: Evidence from the Long Life Family Study (LLFS) and the Framingham Heart Study (FHS) Offspring Cohort (OS)

finding: The SNP rs16864075, also located at the 3q28 locus, was found to increase ΔTHR with a beta value of 0.85 (p = 1.10e-6). However, it was not associated with the TPRG1 gene's transcript levels.
title: Novel Loci (EIF4A2, ADIPOQ, TPRG1) for Triglyceride / High-density Lipoprotein Cholesterol Ratio Longitudinal Change (ΔTHR) among Subjects without Type 2 Diabetes: Evidence from the Long Life Family Study (LLFS) and the Framingham Heart Study (FHS) Offspring Cohort (OS)

finding: The SNP rs2279829 was associated with specific shape features of the brain, particularly in ventricular and subcortical structures. It was noted as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for the gene ZIC4 in human brain tissues.
title: Genetic influences on the shape of brain ventricular and subcortical structures

finding: The intronic variant rs8192675 in the SLC2A2 gene, previously known as GLUT2, was associated with the glycaemic response to metformin. This association indicated the variant's role in glucose metabolism and its relevance to T2D treatment outcomes.
title: Weighted burden analysis in 200,000 exome-sequenced subjects characterises rare variant effects on risk of type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs2102158 at chromosome 3q24 showed a genome-wide significant association with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) (p=2.74×10−8). The analysis suggested that the relative risk of DCM from each alternate allele of rs2102158 was greater among patients with antecedent flu-like illness, indicating a potential modification effect.
title: Antecedent flu-like illness and onset of idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy: The DCM Precision Medicine Study

finding: The SNP rs13061423 was found to influence the immune microenvironment in AML cases. Variants in this locus were linked to significant changes in patient prognosis, where alterations could potentially redirect therapeutic strategies aimed at modulating the immune response against leukemia.
title: Lower RNA expression of ALDH1A1 distinguishes the favorable risk group in acute myeloid leukemia

finding: The variant rs35081325 was identified as a sentinel variant for severe illness and hospitalization related to COVID-19. It was found to overlap a locus associated with eosinophil percentage but did not coincide with monocyte count associations, hinting at potential mediatory roles of eosinophils in COVID-19 severity.
title: Genetic Examination of Hematological Parameters in SARS-CoV-2 Infection and COVID-19

finding: The rs9843653 SNP was associated with a beta effect of -0.13 kg/m² and a p-value of 9.5×10^-46 in the context of adult BMI. Additionally, this common variant showed associations with blood expression levels of the BSN gene and the associations were replicated in independent GWAS data from the GIANT consortium.
title: Protein-truncating variants in BSN are associated with severe adult-onset obesity, type 2 diabetes and fatty liver disease

finding: This SNP was associated with susceptibility to Covid-19. It showed a significant odds ratio (OR=1.21, P=4.26×10^-15) in the chr3p21.31 locus, indicating that the variant may increase the risk of infection.
title: A year of Covid-19 GWAS results from the GRASP portal reveals potential SARS-CoV-2 modifiers

finding: This SNP was linked to the severity of Covid-19 outcomes with an odds ratio of OR=1.62 (P=2.25×10^-9), suggesting its role in modulating the severity of the disease.
title: A year of Covid-19 GWAS results from the GRASP portal reveals potential SARS-CoV-2 modifiers

finding: The variant allele rs34336178-T associated with the Tanner 3 to 4 transition in boys peaked around the genes LARS2 and LIMD1 on chromosome 3. This variant was found to be a splicing and expression Quantitative Trait Locus (sQTL and eQTL), demonstrating its regulatory role in gene expression relevant to pubertal development.
title: Joint models reveal genetic architecture of transitions between pubertal stages and their association with BMI in a Latino population

finding: The variant rs13075111-G was found in the Tanner 3 to 4 transition in boys, located near LARS2 and LIMD1. This variant served as both an eQTL and sQTL for these genes across multiple tissues, indicating its involvement in pubertal processes.
title: Joint models reveal genetic architecture of transitions between pubertal stages and their association with BMI in a Latino population

finding: The rs114974272-G variant was detected in boys during the Tanner 2 to 3 transition. It has been associated with various male phenotypes relating to pubertal onset, supporting its role in the timing of male puberty.
title: Joint models reveal genetic architecture of transitions between pubertal stages and their association with BMI in a Latino population

finding: This SNP was associated with the rapid symptom progression subtype (Subtype III) of PD.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: The study found that rs71325088 was significantly associated with increased risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection and hospitalization status, reporting a Bonferroni corrected P-value of 0.007 with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.46 [95% CI 1.17-1.81]. This variant was part of the genomic region 3p21.31, believed to be influenced by Neanderthal introgression, and it contributed to the severity of COVID-19.
title: Replication of LZTFL1 gene region as a susceptibility locus for COVID-19 in Latvian population

finding: The SNP rs2191031 exhibited a strong association with SARS-CoV-2 infection, having a P-value of 5e-05 and an OR of 1.40 [95% CI 1.19-1.64]. Located in the LZTFL1 gene, this variant showed a higher prevalence in the population studied and was described as equitably associated with differential expression in various tissues.
title: Replication of LZTFL1 gene region as a susceptibility locus for COVID-19 in Latvian population

finding: The SNP rs73064425 was recognized with a Bonferroni corrected P-value of 0.007 and an OR of 1.45 [1.17-1.80]. Like the other variants, it was implicated in the severity of COVID-19 and was part of the 3p21.31 locus.
title: Replication of LZTFL1 gene region as a susceptibility locus for COVID-19 in Latvian population

finding: The SNP rs35081325 in the 3p21.31 locus exhibited a strong genome-wide significant association with severe COVID-19, with a p-value of 3.32×10⁻⁵⁸. It was identified as one of the two independent genetic association signals in this locus, and CXCR6 was prioritized as a candidate causal gene.
title: Single cell sequencing analysis uncovers genetics-influenced CD16+monocytes and memory CD8+T cells involved in severe COVID-19

finding: Similar to rs35081325, the SNP rs33998492 also demonstrated a significant association with severe COVID-19 in the 3p21.31 region, with a p-value of 3.59×10⁻¹⁴. CCR1 was prioritized as the causal gene for this SNP, highlighting its importance in influencing severe disease susceptibility.
title: Single cell sequencing analysis uncovers genetics-influenced CD16+monocytes and memory CD8+T cells involved in severe COVID-19

finding: This SNP was linked with regulatory effects on both MOBP and RPSA as indicated by SMR analysis contributing to ALS risk.
title: Common and rare variant association analyses in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis identify 15 risk loci with distinct genetic architectures and neuron-specific biology

finding: The SNP rs73062389:G>A at SLC6A20 was significantly associated with susceptibility to COVID-19, with an odds ratio (OR = 1.18; 95% CI = 1.16, 1.20; P = 2.5 × 10^-74). SLC6A20 interacts functionally with ACE2.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19: an update

finding: The SNP rs121908839 (c.955C>T, p.Arg319Cys) was previously known to cause ectrodactyly and affected the same codon as the novel mutation (c.956G>T, p.Arg319Leu) identified in the patient. It provided strong evidence that mutating this codon was deleterious, indicating a significant link between this mutation and the phenotype related to ectrodactyly.
title: A Novel de novo TP63 Mutation in Whole Exome Sequencing of a Syrian Family with Oral Cleft and Ectrodactyly
