finding: The SNP rs4686696, which is intronic to IGF2BP2, was implicated in a positive causal effect on reproductive conditions, contributing to the characteristics of metabolic traits in obesity-related reproductive health.
title: The role of obesity in female reproductive conditions: A Mendelian Randomisation study

finding: The SNP rs73163796 showed a posterior probability of 66% for being a shared SNP influencing both major depressive disorder (MDD) and DNA methylation (DNAm). It colocalised with genetic variation influencing a smoking-associated CpG probe, cg15099418.
title: DNA methylome-wide association study of genetic risk for depression implicates antigen processing and immune responses

finding: The SNP rs73163779 had a posterior probability of 17% for shared genetic factors between MDD and DNAm. This SNP also colocalised with the smoking-associated CpG probe, cg15099418.
title: DNA methylome-wide association study of genetic risk for depression implicates antigen processing and immune responses

finding: The SNP rs11710605 displayed a posterior probability of 11% for being a shared genetic factor influencing MDD and DNAm, and was found to colocalise with the smoking-associated CpG probe, cg15099418.
title: DNA methylome-wide association study of genetic risk for depression implicates antigen processing and immune responses

finding: The SNP rs9810512 featured in the set of SNPs with regulatory potential affecting various gene targets.
title: Unveiling Shared Genetic Links between Blood Cell Traits and Cardiovascular Diseases

finding: The SNP rs12630999 was associated with both 'mental health' and 'metabolic' categories due to its location between the Mendelian disease genes STAG1 and PCCB. This dual assignment reflected the complexity of pathways linked to BMI, indicating that this SNP might have influences in both mental health disorders and metabolic conditions.
title: Distinct pathway-based effects of blood pressure and body mass index on cardiovascular traits: comparison of novel Mendelian Randomization approaches

finding: The SNP rs11707416 was associated with the expression of the microglial gene P2RY12, demonstrating a significant relationship with a p-value of 1.2e-4. This association was highlighted in the Brain xQTLserve browser and corroborated in the BRAINEAC database and PsychENCODE data, indicating its importance in the context of Parkinson's disease (PD) and suggesting that P2RY12 could be a strong functional candidate in PD pathogenesis.
title: Heritability enrichment implicates microglia in Parkinson’s disease pathogenesis

finding: The SNP rs17283010, which was found to be in complete linkage disequilibrium with rs11707416 (r² = 1), showed association with expression levels of P2RY12 at a p-value of 1.5e-5. This finding further supported the role of P2RY12 and illustrated its implications in the study of immune mechanisms involved in Parkinson's disease.
title: Heritability enrichment implicates microglia in Parkinson’s disease pathogenesis

finding: The lead SNP rs9834970 (3:36856030, build GRCh37) achieved genome-wide significance in both female (OR T allele = 0.91, SE = 0.01, P = 5.7×10^-12) and male (OR T allele = 0.90, SE = 0.02, P = 6.6×10^-10) meta-analyses. This SNP was consistently associated with BD in previous studies.
title: Genetic diversity enhances gene discovery for bipolar disorder

finding: The SNP rs13082684, located at chr3q22.2, showed a very strong association with reading ability (P = 1.87×10^{-17}) and was consistent with findings from the original dyslexia GWAS, representing a clear positive original finding.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of quantitative reading skill and dyslexia improves gene discovery

finding: Found to be associated with body mass index and showing positive effects on reading ability, rs1317140 was highlighted for its implications in cognitive traits.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of quantitative reading skill and dyslexia improves gene discovery

finding: The SNP rs17366568, located at the ADIPOQ locus, showed strong association with adiponectin levels, with statistical significance maintained despite high heterogeneity in effect sizes.
title: A multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis, fine-mapping, and gene prioritization approach to characterize the genetic architecture of adiponectin

finding: The SNP rs7617025 was identified in the European-ancestry analysis as a previously unreported locus near LINC01214 associated with adiponectin. This marked it as a novel finding pertinent to the study.
title: A multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis, fine-mapping, and gene prioritization approach to characterize the genetic architecture of adiponectin

finding: The variant rs1108842 was found to be one of the 46 putative causal variants related to adiponectin levels, solidifying its established association in the context of the meta-analysis.
title: A multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis, fine-mapping, and gene prioritization approach to characterize the genetic architecture of adiponectin

finding: The SNP rs16861209 was listed among the putative causal variants for adiponectin, confirmed as a lead variant during the analyses of European ancestry.
title: A multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis, fine-mapping, and gene prioritization approach to characterize the genetic architecture of adiponectin

finding: The SNP rs67959919 was confirmed to be associated with the risk of COVID-19, with the rare T-allele correlating with an increased risk after adjusting for age, sex, and hypertension. The significant p-value of 0.003 and an odds ratio (OR) of 1.86 indicated that this variant contributed positively to the susceptibility of the disease among the studied cohort, although no significant distinction was found between severe and non-severe cases.
title: The CCR5-delta32 variant might explain part of the association between COVID-19 and the chemokine-receptor gene cluster

finding: This SNP near GMNC was associated with CSF proteomics data, particularly impacting tau levels, and indicated overlap in genetic etiology for tau levels and brain ventricular volume.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis for Alzheimer’s disease cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers

finding: The SNP rs1062633 was shown to be effective in measuring allelic imbalance in DNA samples, utilized for both classic and SNP-based approaches in detecting heterogeneous copy number alterations. The analysis indicated that using control samples homozygous for rs1062633 improved the sensitivity and accuracy of the measurements.
title: Allele-specific digital PCR enhances precision and sensitivity in the detection and quantification of copy number alterations in heterogeneous DNA samples: an in silico and in vitro validation study

finding: SNP rs2236947 was relevant in evaluating allelic imbalances in the context of uveal melanoma. This SNP, along with rs1062633, was analyzed using digital PCR to understand its effect on copy number value analyses.
title: Allele-specific digital PCR enhances precision and sensitivity in the detection and quantification of copy number alterations in heterogeneous DNA samples: an in silico and in vitro validation study

finding: The SNP rs7650602 located in the ZBTB38 gene region showed significant regulatory enrichment, with ancestral allele frequency of 42%, pointing to its importance in genetic contributions related to gestational duration and preterm delivery.
title: Genetic effects on the timing of parturition and links to fetal birth weight

finding: The missense variant rs1687225 was linked to brain stem LBS with a p-value of 5.6E-10. It was classified as an independent gene expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for VWA5B2 and had a high CADD score, making it one of the 3% most deleterious SNPs.
title: Beyond Volume: Unraveling the Genetics of Human Brain Geometry

finding: The finding related to the SNP rs13061308 indicated a correlation with the development of immune-related adverse events (irAEs) following treatment with immune checkpoint inhibitors. Specifically, it was associated with a higher neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio, which was suggested as a predictive marker for the onset of irAEs in patients undergoing immune checkpoint blockade therapy. This association was highlighted in the study by Lee et al. in 2021, underscoring its relevance in understanding patient responses to such treatments.
title: Baseline risk factors associated with immune related adverse events and atezolizumab

finding: The SNP rs149403252 exhibited a significant association with lower fasting glucose after metformin treatment in individuals of African ancestry (p=1.9×10−9), indicating enhanced metformin response, with heterozygous individuals showing a decrease of 1.1 mmol/L compared to 0.12 mmol/L in non-carriers.
title: Genome-wide association analysis identifies ancestry-specific genetic variation associated with medication response in the Study to Understand the Genetics of the Acute Response to Metformin and Glipizide in Humans (SUGAR-MGH)

finding: The C allele of rs146209333 in PRICKLE2 conferred a more robust response to glipizide, as evidenced by consistently lower glucose levels during the challenge and a steeper glucose slope (p=3.3×10−8) indicating hypoglycemia risk.
title: Genome-wide association analysis identifies ancestry-specific genetic variation associated with medication response in the Study to Understand the Genetics of the Acute Response to Metformin and Glipizide in Humans (SUGAR-MGH)

finding: The SNP rs113341849 was part of the CCR5delta32 haplotype termed 'Haplotype A', identified in the CEU population. It demonstrated high linkage disequilibrium (r2 = 1) with CCR5delta32 and was significant in understanding the genetic structure and selection of this haplotype.
title: Tracing the evolutionary path of the CCR5delta32 deletion via ancient and modern genomes

finding: Similar to rs113341849, rs113010081 was identified as a key variant within Haplotype A, with an r2 value of 1 in the CEU population. This SNP played a critical role in linking the CCR5delta32 allele with European ancestry and showed potential for genetic imputation related to HIV resistance.
title: Tracing the evolutionary path of the CCR5delta32 deletion via ancient and modern genomes

finding: This SNP was among the top variants with strong linkage (r2 > 0.9) in relation to the CCR5delta32 deletion. Its presence in the haplotype framework of Haplotype A supported the evidence of positive selection acting on this region during specific historical periods.
title: Tracing the evolutionary path of the CCR5delta32 deletion via ancient and modern genomes

finding: Present in the top candidates for linkage to the CCR5delta32 deletion, rs11574435 helped reinforce the haplotype association documented through the CEU population. Its functional significance in relation to HIV resistance was also suggested by its strong LD with the core haplotype.
title: Tracing the evolutionary path of the CCR5delta32 deletion via ancient and modern genomes

finding: The rs34097149 variant at the GPR149/MME locus on 3q25.2 was associated with an increased risk of VT recurrence, demonstrating a hazard ratio (HR) of 1.84 (95% CI: 1.49-2.29, P=2.65x10^-8). This finding underscored the genetic implications of the GPR149 gene which was previously linked to coronary artery disease and hemostatic traits.
title: Genomic Landscape of Thrombosis Recurrence Risk Across Venous Thromboembolism Subtypes

finding: This SNP displayed a trans-eQTL relationship, influencing the expression of 297 genes, particularly related to platelet function regulation, which highlights its extensive role in genetic regulatory networks.
title: Genetic analysis of blood molecular phenotypes reveals regulatory networks affecting complex traits: a DIRECT study

finding: The SNP chr3:142485886:C:T was identified as a lead variant at an intron of ATR, with a significant association to leukocyte telomere length (LTL), suggesting a role in DNA damage response and telomere maintenance.
title: Genomic, phenomic, and geographic associations of leukocyte telomere length in the United States

finding: The SNP chr3:44976290:A:G is part of the EXOSC family involved in telomere RNA processing, marking its relevance to LTL.
title: Genomic, phenomic, and geographic associations of leukocyte telomere length in the United States

finding: At the 3p21.31 locus, rs11917431 was associated with febrile seizures with a combined odds ratio of 1.15 and a P value of 5.63 x 10^-12. This SNP is intronic in the gene BSN, which encodes a protein critical for neurotransmitter release. Many eQTL associations were reported at this locus, indicating a potential influence on cognitive traits and neuronal excitability.
title: Genome-wide association study of febrile seizures identifies seven new loci implicating fever response and neuronal excitability genes

finding: The lead SNP rs4974130 at the 3p14.3 locus had a combined odds ratio of 1.31 (P = 1.52 x 10^-13), and it was intronic in ERC2, which encodes the CAST protein. It was identified as an eQTL for ERC2 in the cerebellum, suggesting that increased expression at this locus may influence febrile seizure risk.
title: Genome-wide association study of febrile seizures identifies seven new loci implicating fever response and neuronal excitability genes

finding: The rs73064425 SNP located at 3p21.31 was identified as the lead variant pointing to the CXCR6 gene, establishing it as the strongest susceptibility risk locus for severe manifestation of COVID-19. This association was supported by a very low P-value of 4.77E-30, indicating a significant correlation with severe disease outcomes.
title: Elevated plasma levels of CXCL16 in severe COVID-19 patients

finding: The SNP rs10490770:T>C was reported as another lead variant associated with severe COVID-19, yielding a P-value of 1.443E-73 for hospitalization and 2.20E-61 for critical illness. Carriers of the risk allele for this variant had an increased risk of COVID-19 related mortality with a hazard ratio of 1.5 (95% CI 1.3-1.8) and increased odds of complications such as severe respiratory failure (OR 2.0) and venous thromboembolism (OR 1.7). Furthermore, replication of the association was confirmed in a cohort of hospitalized patients (OR 1.9, CI 1.2-3.5, P-value <0.002).
title: Elevated plasma levels of CXCL16 in severe COVID-19 patients

finding: The variant rs33910087 within the FYCO1 gene was validated as an eQTL for CXCR6 in lung tissue, linking it to the expression of CXCR6 in AT2, ciliated, and club cells. Its association with severe COVID-19 was further bolstered by significant differential expression noted in lung CD8 T cells infected with the virus.
title: Elevated plasma levels of CXCL16 in severe COVID-19 patients

finding: In the Bangladeshi population, this SNP frequency was significantly associated with critical illness from COVID-19, showing an OR of 2.11, thus representing a notable risk factor for severe manifestations of the disease.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19 by worldwide meta-analysis

finding: This lead variant was similarly related to severe COVID-19 outcomes in the Bangladeshi population cohort, emphasizing the significance of population-specific studies.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19 by worldwide meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs13074711 was reported as a risk variant in previous GWAS studies for breast cancer. In the present study, this SNP was implicated in the regulation of the TNFSF10 gene expression, which was associated with immune defense mechanisms against breast cancer. Evidence indicated that the alteration of rs13074711 expression levels influenced IFN-β-induced apoptosis in experimental settings, supporting the notion that TNFSF10 acts as a potential cancer suppressor linked to the breast cancer risk associated with the 3q26.21 locus.
title: A joint transcriptome-wide association study across multiple tissues identifies new candidate susceptibility genes for breast cancer

finding: The SNP rs13092249 was originally found to be associated with homologous recombination repair deficiency, which has implications for tumor immunogenicity. This relationship indicated that variations at this locus could potentially impact how tumors respond to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs), thereby serving as a predictive biomarker in cancer immunotherapy.
title: Tumor genomic subtypes orthogonal to mutation burden predict the efficacy of immune checkpoint therapy

finding: The intron variant rs6808178 was noted with a p-value of 0.038, indicating its potential significance as a risk-associated variant concerning CSF alpha-synuclein aggregate status in LRRK2-parkinsonism cases. Like the previous variants, it did not withstand correction for multiple testing.
title: LRRK2-Associated Parkinsonism With and Without In Vivo Evidence of Alpha-Synuclein Aggregates

finding: Located in RPN1 and observed in the African ancestry group, this SNP had a reported minor allele frequency of approximately 6% in AFR and showed significant association, marking an important finding for mLOY in that group.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide association meta-analysis of mosaic loss of chromosome Y in the Million Veteran Program identifies 167 novel loci

finding: SNP rs12107945 was noted as a leading SNP in the study regarding skull bone mineral density (SK-BMD). It was directly associated with the genetic determinants that contribute to this trait, correlating with factors such as craniofacial development and abnormal cranial bone growth observed in related experiments.
title: Genome Wide Association Metanalysis Of Skull Bone Mineral Density Identifies Loci Relevant For Osteoporosis And Craniosynostosis

finding: Genome-wide significant association with SNP rs11919682 in the ROBO1 gene was noted, with a p-value of 1.63×10^-8, indicating an association with Alzheimer's disease.
title: African Ancestry GWAS of Dementia in a Large Military Cohort Identifies Significant Risk Loci

finding: The common variant rs6801957, located in the RE1 regulatory element, was associated with Brugada syndrome (BrS) and ECG traits. This variant led to reduced expression of the short transcript of SCN10A, which is controlled by an intronic enhancer-promoter complex, while it had a minimal effect on SCN5A expression. This finding emphasized the relevance of non-coding variants in the genetic aetiology of BrS.
title: A rare non-coding enhancer variant in SCN5A contributes to the high prevalence of Brugada syndrome in Thailand

finding: The heterozygous SNP rs7430407 was utilized to evaluate allelic expression of SCN5A in hiPSC-CMs containing the RE5 variant. The analysis revealed that the presence of the RE5 variant correlated with a 34% reduction in the SCN5A transcript allelic ratio compared to isogenic controls. This indicated that the enhancer variant led to decreased SCN5A expression by disrupting the Mef2 transcription factor binding site, thus demonstrating the regulatory impact of the SNP.
title: A rare non-coding enhancer variant in SCN5A contributes to the high prevalence of Brugada syndrome in Thailand

finding: Associated with increased grade ≥3 adverse events; priorly linked to severity of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.
title: Pharmacogenetics of tuberculosis treatment toxicity and effectiveness in a large Brazilian cohort

finding: Linked to treatment failure/recurrence; previously associated with increases in severity of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.
title: Pharmacogenetics of tuberculosis treatment toxicity and effectiveness in a large Brazilian cohort

finding: The SNP rs13092216 was associated with retinoblastoma, where it contributed to the analysis of the impact of intravenous chemotherapy regimens on globe salvage success rates, as reported in a meta-analysis by Daniels et al. (2021), supporting its relevance in retinoblastoma treatment outcomes.
title: Automatic Retinoblastoma Screening and Surveillance Using Deep Learning

finding: The SNP rs509399 was linked to the gene BCL6 for asthma, with a posterior inclusion probability of 0.96. This finding indicated that BCL6 modulates interleukin 4 response, relevant in asthma pathogenesis.
title: Combining SNP-to-gene linking strategies to pinpoint disease genes and assess disease omnigenicity

finding: The SNP rs121912851, also associated with the TP53 gene, had a detection rate of 0.18% among ESCC patients, indicating its relevance in the context of esophageal cancer genetics.
title: Comprehensive Study of Germline Mutations and Double-Hit Events in Esophageal Squamous Cell Cancer

finding: Variant rs1288694 impacted fasting glucose (FG) by influencing the splicing of the FOXP1 gene, which has a known role in hepatic gluconeogenesis. This variant was commonly found in multiple ancestries and showed significant association in the cohort.
title: Investigating gene-diet interactions impacting the association between macronutrient intake and glycemic traits

finding: The rs1540354-T variant in MLH1 was significantly associated with decreased overall survival among individuals treated with temozolomide. The interaction p-value was 0.0044, with a median survival of 6.3 years for T/T or A/T genotype carriers compared to 13.7 years for A/A genotype carriers.
title: The impact of germline variants in DNA repair pathways on survival and temozolomide toxicity in adults with glioma

finding: Polymorphism rs4647218-G in MLH1 was suggestively associated with survival outcomes (p<0.005) among IDH mutant gliomas. Carriers of two copies of the G allele had a median survival time of 14.3 years compared to shorter survival times for those with one or no G alleles.
title: The impact of germline variants in DNA repair pathways on survival and temozolomide toxicity in adults with glioma

finding: The SNP rs16859966 was identified on chromosome 3 as strongly associated with Multiple System Atrophy (MSA), with a P-value of 8.6 x 10-7 and an odds ratio of 1.58 (95% CI = 1.32-1.89). This variant was located upstream of the genes ZIC1 and ZIC4, which encode transcription factors crucial for CNS development, particularly in the cerebellum.
title: Genome-wide association study of autopsy-confirmed Multiple System Atrophy identifies common variants near ZIC1 and ZIC4

finding: The novel rs4955351 SNP in the GADL1 locus, which was newly associated with AD, showed suggestive evidence in the PAD CSF-PET meta-analysis (P=3.19e-08), suggesting potential involvement in AD pathology.
title: Connecting genomic and proteomic signatures of amyloid burden in the brain

finding: The lead SNP rs10706986 was significantly associated with the A1 dimension of autism spectrum disorder (ASD), which was characterized by globally reduced brain volume, cognitive dysfunction, and aging-related genetic variants.
title: Three Imaging Endophenotypes Characterize Neuroanatomical Heterogeneity of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs724016 in ZBTB38 was linked to FVC with a significant P-value of 1.35x10^-10 and beta of -0.0178. This SNP had also been reported in association with Crohn’s disease.
title: Multi-trait and multi-ancestry genetic analysis of comorbid lung diseases and traits improves genetic discovery and polygenic risk prediction

finding: rs1381763 was found as a novel SNP in the context of internalizing psychopathology, notably associated with neuroticism and depression.
title: A Multivariate Genome-Wide Association Study Reveals Neural Correlates and Common Biological Mechanisms of Psychopathology Spectra

finding: The study identified the SNP rs334558, located in the GSK3B gene, as positively associated with bipolar disorder (BD). This finding differed from previously published data, which were inconclusive regarding this association. The positive results present in this analysis were attributed to a larger sample size and a multi-SNP approach, which provided a more objective evaluation. The implication of GSK3B extends beyond BD, as it is also involved in the pathophysiology of other serious conditions including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, schizophrenia, and depressive disorders.
title: Druggable causal genes of bipolar disorder identified through Mendelian Randomization analysis offer a route to intervention in integrated stress response

finding: Located in the 3' UTR of BHLHE40, the lead SNP rs11130215 was noted for its role in binding multiple transcription factors, including those previously associated with AD, highlighting its regulatory importance.
title: Meta-analysis of atopic dermatitis in 1,094,060 individuals identifies new risk loci, and sub-analysis characterizes the loci with disease severity and onset

finding: The SNP rs2710339 was found within the gene body of SFMBT1. It was associated with SCZ risk through imputed adult brain expression of isoform ENST00000492146 (P = 6.9 × 10^-12), corroborating GWAS data that linked decreased expression of SFMBT1 with increased risk of both SCZ and bipolar disorder.
title: Isoform-level transcriptome-wide association uncovers extensive novel genetic risk mechanisms for neuropsychiatric disorders in the human brain

finding: The rs6439513 SNP was noted as the lead SNP in the 3q22.2 region related to type 2 diabetes (T2D), with a P-value of 0.03 and an odds ratio of 1.07, confirmed in a validation study involving 197,272 European individuals.
title: Admixture mapping screening of CKD traits and risk factors in U.S. Hispanic/Latino individuals from Central America country-of-origin

finding: This known association at the CP locus confirmed its role in copper level regulation.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The SNP rs35081325 was strongly associated with infection severity outcomes, consistently linking to the severity cluster of COVID-19 phenotypes based on findings from the main HGI severity study. This association indicated an increased risk of severe cases.
title: Novel COVID-19 phenotype definitions reveal phenotypically distinct patterns of genetic association and protective effects

finding: The SNP rs73062389 showed a strong association with the susceptibility cluster of phenotypes and was identified in the main HGI susceptibility study. This SNP did not correlate with severity phenotypes, indicating that it specifically conferred increased susceptibility risk to COVID-19.
title: Novel COVID-19 phenotype definitions reveal phenotypically distinct patterns of genetic association and protective effects

finding: The novel signal rs2531743 associated with two specific phenotypes: Symptomatic/Paucisymptomatic and Exposed_Positive/Exposed_Negative. Unlike the other signals in the chr3 region, the minor allele of this SNP exhibited a protective direction of effect.
title: Novel COVID-19 phenotype definitions reveal phenotypically distinct patterns of genetic association and protective effects

finding: The SNP rs11922956, located upstream of the CADM2 gene on chromosome 3, was identified as significantly associated with lifetime cannabis use with a p-value of 2.40E-11. This finding replicated previous associations from GWASs related to both lifetime use and cannabis use disorder (CUD). CADM2 was noted to encode a glycoprotein essential for various brain functions including cell-cell adhesion and excitatory neurotransmission.
title: Genome-wide association studies of lifetime and frequency cannabis use in 131,895 individuals

finding: The SNP rs4856591, located near CADM2 on chromosome 3, was found to have a significant association with the frequency of cannabis use, with a p-value of 8.10E-09. It was also noted to be in linkage disequilibrium with rs11922956, suggesting a close genetic relationship in the context of cannabis use traits.
title: Genome-wide association studies of lifetime and frequency cannabis use in 131,895 individuals

finding: The novel SNP rs3836464 was linked to active-to-sedentary transition probability (ASTP), providing a new insight into how genetic variation could influence lifestyle changes related to physical activity.
title: Genome-wide association studies of 27 accelerometry-derived physical activity measurements identifies novel loci and genetic mechanisms

finding: SNP rs9818758 was associated with relative amplitude, a proxy for sleep behavior and circadian rhythm, revealing its potential impact on daily activity patterns and sleep-wake cycles.
title: Genome-wide association studies of 27 accelerometry-derived physical activity measurements identifies novel loci and genetic mechanisms

finding: The rs150385013 variant was discovered to be European-specific for primary open-angle glaucoma, enhancing the repertoire of known variants implicated in glaucoma across different ancestries.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs58812088 variant was found to be in high linkage disequilibrium with PACG lead variants. Its association further deepens the understanding of genetic susceptibility across different glaucoma subtypes.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs16856870 variant has shown association with PACG traits in the East Asian ancestry context, underscoring the focus on ethnicity-specific genetic risk factors in the development of primary open-angle glaucoma.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: A common SNP in the promoter flanking region of RAB7A was found to be genome-wide significant in a recent large GWAS study on smoking. This indicates a strong association of this locus with smoking behaviors and potential implications for respiratory health.
title: Powerful gene-based testing by integrating long-range chromatin interactions and knockoff genotypes

finding: A nearby SNP in the same promoter flanking region of RAB7A was found to be genome-wide significant with eosinophil counts in the UK Biobank. High eosinophil counts have been previously linked to decline in FEV1, suggesting that this SNP may also have relevance to lung function in the context of respiratory health.
title: Powerful gene-based testing by integrating long-range chromatin interactions and knockoff genotypes

finding: The SNP rs2280575 was identified as a lead SNP associated with the gene LRIG1 in the context of Alzheimer’s disease. It showed a negative odds ratio of 0.539, indicating a potential protective effect against the disease in the analyzed population. The SNP's influence on LRIG1 expression was validated through eQTL analysis, showing significant effects in the hypothalamus. The expression levels of LRIG1 were notably high in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus according to various datasets.
title: APOE-stratified genome-wide association study suggests potential novel genes for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease in East-Asian descent

finding: The rs112097551 variant was associated with higher mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) and mean corpuscular volume (MCV) in the Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) study. This variant was found to act through a cis-regulatory element controlling the expression of RUVBL1, a gene essential for hematopoiesis.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: The rs2977562 SNP was associated with mean corpuscular hemoglobin and red cell distribution width, being confirmed in both TOPMed and previously published studies.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: Identified in association with RBC traits in independent samples, the rs147412900 variant showed significant replication of its association results.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: The lead variant at the PROS1 locus (rs121918472) was a missense variant that demonstrated significant association with PS levels, indicating its role in protein S free levels.
title: Antithrombin, protein C and protein S: Genome and transcriptome wide association studies identify 7 novel loci regulating plasma levels

finding: The SNP rs34801745 was linked to body mass index (BMI) and located within 500kb of the TNK2 gene, with a beta effect size of 0.013 and a significance of P = 7 × 10^-11.
title: Population scale whole genome sequencing provides novel insights into cardiometabolic health

finding: The SNP rs6800500 was connected to T2D within 500kb of the TNK2 gene, exhibiting a beta of 0.03 with significance P = 2.4 × 10^-21.
title: Population scale whole genome sequencing provides novel insights into cardiometabolic health

finding: The SNP rs11713193 was linked to BMI and located within 500kb of the IP6K1 gene, with a beta value of 0.025 and a significance level of P = 3 × 10^-48.
title: Population scale whole genome sequencing provides novel insights into cardiometabolic health

finding: Associations for the SNP rs7613875 were observed for T2D, located within 500kb from the IP6K1 gene, presenting a beta of 0.025 and P = 4.8 × 10^-16.
title: Population scale whole genome sequencing provides novel insights into cardiometabolic health

finding: This SNP was identified in a genome-wide analysis for bilateral clefts (BCL), achieving genome-wide significance with a p-value of 3.69×10⁻⁸, indicating a strong association with this subtype of orofacial clefts.
title: The PAX1 locus at 20p11 is a modifier for bilateral cleft lip only

finding: This novel SNP near the ADAMTS9 gene was significant for ascending aortic distensibility and was a noted eQTL for this gene.
title: GENOME-WIDE ASSOCIATIONS OF AORTIC DISTENSIBILITY SUGGEST CAUSAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH AORTIC ANEURYSMS AND BRAIN WHITE MATTER HYPERINTENSITIES

finding: The SNP rs66513933 was associated with S1 subtype of preclinical-T2DM. It was located in the intron of IGF2BP2, a gene strongly linked to low type 2 diabetes risk. This finding highlighted a beneficial genetic factor contributing to T2DM risk in this subtype.
title: Identification of distinct trajectories in preclinical type 2 diabetes and their associations with outcomes

finding: The SNP rs9834970 showed significant colocalization with bipolar disorder for the S1 subtype of preclinical-T2DM. This finding suggested a shared genetic predisposition between T2DM subtype S1 and bipolar disorder, indicating potential overlaps in their genetic underpinnings.
title: Identification of distinct trajectories in preclinical type 2 diabetes and their associations with outcomes

finding: The SNP rs868933181, associated with the gene VPRBP, exhibited a significant association with early-onset gout, showing a meta-analysis P-value of 6.27 × 10^-9 and an odds ratio of 1.66.
title: Novel genetic loci in adolescent-onset gout derived from whole genome sequencing of a Chinese cohort

finding: The SNP rs2800-G in the SLC9A9 gene was associated with a risk of fatty liver disease, reflected in an odds ratio of 3.1 (2.0-4.5; p=0.028). This genetic variant may impact lipid metabolism in individuals with metabolic syndrome.
title: Severe liver damage, low bone mineral content, and PDXDC1/TTC39B gene variations linked to NAFLD with metabolic syndrome

finding: In the Trøndelag Health Study (HUNT), a rare missense variant rs367731784 was identified, suggesting a role for DNAJC13 in transferrin recycling. This variant was noted to have a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.0009 and presented a moderate effect size, being more prevalent in HUNT than in other non-Finnish European populations.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of iron status biomarkers and the effect of iron on all-cause mortality in HUNT

finding: The SNP rs762560584 was identified as a missense variant found among individuals carrying a deletion. It was noteworthy due to its low allele frequency of less than 1% in the gnomAD database and was classified as non-deleterious based on UNEECON scores, which were under 0.15. This variant was relevant in the context of analyzing genetic influences in individuals with epilepsy, particularly in relation to large microdeletions observed in genetic generalized epilepsies.
title: Assessment of burden and segregation profiles of CNVs in patients with epilepsy

finding: The SNP rs1702136 was noted as the strongest signal in the study, categorized as an intronic variant in the EEFSEC gene. It was significantly associated with FGT polyps, indicating its potential role in the genetic predisposition to this condition.
title: Large-scale genome-wide association study to determine the genetic underpinnings of female genital tract polyps

finding: The SNP rs4857866 showed nominal association with endometrial cancer and was located in an intronic region associated with the EEFSEC gene, relating it to polyp development.
title: Large-scale genome-wide association study to determine the genetic underpinnings of female genital tract polyps

finding: The rs1163930676 variant represented a homozygous nonsense mutation (c.1251 C > A, p.(Tyr417*)) in the DALRD3 gene, leading to a premature stop codon and subsequent loss of DALRD3 protein expression. This finding was observed in two sibling patients with severe developmental and epileptic encephalopathy disorders, thus linking this specific DALRD3 variant to significant clinical symptoms. The patients were from consanguineous parents, who were heterozygous for the variant but did not exhibit any detectable pathologies.
title: Epileptic encephalopathy linked to a DALRD3 missense variant impaired in tRNA modification function

finding: This was established as the top associated variant for 3q25.33-SMC4 with a genome-wide significant P-value of 2.3×10−9, contributing to the understanding of loci involved in CH.
title: Genome-wide analyses of 200,453 individuals yields new insights into the causes and consequences of clonal hematopoiesis

finding: The SNP rs143184903 on chromosome 3 was found to be significantly associated with RPD, achieving a p-value of 8.1e-09 in the primary pure RPD GWAS, highlighting its potential role in this specific condition.
title: Genetic Distinctions Between Reticular Pseudodrusen and Drusen: Insights from a Genome-Wide Association Study

finding: The exonic SNP rs141178913 in IL17RC on 3p25.3 was found associated with SCC risk and is involved in inflammatory pathways.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The intergenic variant rs188990825 on 3q13.33, near COX17-POPDC2, showed associations with SCC risk, with COX17 being a previously linked gene to lung function.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: This SNP, located in the intergenic region of LZTFL1 and CCR9, was associated with autoimmune conditions such as Hashimoto's disease and celiac disease. Additionally, it was significantly linked to COVID-19 susceptibility measures, indicating a role in acute COVID-19 infection.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of diarrhea during acute SARS-CoV2 infection identifies multiple novel loci and contrasting etiological roles of irritable bowel syndrome subtypes

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with intelligence (P-value < 2.33E-05) and was detailed within the context of various neurocognitive functions.
title: Genetic Variations in Evolutionary Accelerated Regions Disrupt Cognition in Schizophrenia

finding: The SNP rs147525023 was mentioned as a lead SNP associated with ICP at the 14q24.1 locus, indicating its contribution to increased risk in East Asians.
title: Genetic study of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy in 101,023 Chinese women unveils East Asian-specific etiology linked to historic HBV infection

finding: The rs343320 variant at chr3:146517122:G:A was associated with critical COVID-19, predicted to be a missense mutation in the phospholipid scramblase 1 gene (PLSCR1), which plays a role in antiviral signaling.
title: Whole genome sequencing identifies multiple loci for critical illness caused by COVID-19

finding: This intronic variant in IL17RD was previously reported to be associated with lung function and COPD, with an odds ratio of 0.89 and p-value of 7.87×10^-9 in this study. It suggests a role in the pathogenesis of COPD and asthma.
title: Genetic associations and architecture of asthma-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease overlap

finding: This intronic variant in GLB1 was previously identified as associated with asthma. In this analysis, it was linked to ACO with an odds ratio of 1.10 and p-value of 2.44×10^-9, with significant chromatin interactions observed in fetal lung fibroblasts.
title: Genetic associations and architecture of asthma-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease overlap

finding: The splice-site variant rs192044702 in GBE1 was associated with lower white matter hyperintensity (WMH) volume, with a beta of -0.74 and statistical significance at p=9.7E-9, across 17,830 individuals. This finding was considered an original contribution to the understanding of WMH burden as it pointed to the protective role of GBE1 variants, contrasting with previously reported associations of mutations in GBE1 with conditions like adult polyglucosan body disease (APBD) that typically demonstrate WMH.
title: Whole-exome sequencing in 16,511 individuals reveals a role of the HTRA1 protease and its substrate EGFL8 in brain white matter hyperintensities

finding: The rs2535629 SNP exhibited a G to A substitution, which was confirmed to increase binding affinity for transcription factor CTCF, thus diminishing its suppressive impact. This SNP was directly linked to schizophrenia, showing significant delta repression scores in CNS biosamples.
title: The contribution of silencer variants to human diseases

finding: The SNP rs13061325 was originally identified in a study that highlighted its potential role in the detection of lymphovascular invasion in testicular cancer, specifically in the context of seminoma subtypes. This finding contributed to the understanding of genetic factors influencing the pathology of testicular germ cell tumors.
title: Deep learning for subtypes identification of pure seminoma of the testis

finding: The SNP rs53576 was associated with alcohol abuse in a longitudinal population representative study, suggesting that variation in the oxytocin receptor gene could influence susceptibility to alcohol use disorder (AUD). This finding related to the broader context of the role of oxytocin in addiction and stress pathways, as explored in the study.
title: Altered association of plasmatic oxytocin with affective stress response in alcohol use disorder

finding: The finding examined the rs53576 SNP related to the oxytocin receptor gene, which was shown to modulate oxytocin-dopamine interaction and influence neuroticism traits, as reported by Chang et al. (2014). This SNP became relevant in understanding the individual differences in response to oxytocin treatment and its neurophysiological impacts, particularly in populations at clinical high risk for psychosis.
title: Connectome dysfunction in patients at clinical high risk for psychosis and modulation by oxytocin

finding: Polymorphism rs3814055 in the PXR gene was observed in the study population. It was suggested that this variant could be associated with an increased risk of AT-DILI, as lesser frequencies of the homozygous TT genotype were noted, indicating its role in hepatic drug clearance.
title: Polymorphism of NAT2, PXR, ABCB1, and GSTT1 genes among tuberculosis patients of North Eastern States of India

finding: In the EUR population, rs9823832 was the most strongly associated variant with a p-value of 9.06×10−37 at the DHX36 locus, indicating a significant genetic risk factor for epiretinal membrane (ERM). This locus was also implicated in the trans-ancestry meta-analysis.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: In the trans-ancestry meta-analysis, rs28630834 was identified as the most strongly supported variant at the same DHX36 locus, with a p-value of 2.90×10−37, further supporting its association with ERM.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: This SNP was found to alter expression of DHX36 in the macula with a significance of p=6.38×10−13, suggesting its involvement in the biological mechanisms underlying ERM.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: This SNP was associated with the RARB locus with a p-value of 1.13×10−10, indicating a potential role in retinal development through retinoic acid signaling.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: SNP rs6781046 was significantly associated with microbiome composition at age 3 PC2, with a p-value lower than the Bonferroni-corrected significance threshold.
title: Genotype-microbiome-metabolome associations in early childhood, and their link to BMI and childhood obesity

finding: Similar to rs6781046, SNP rs1040338 was significantly associated with microbiome composition at age 3 PC2, with a p-value below the Bonferroni-corrected significance level.
title: Genotype-microbiome-metabolome associations in early childhood, and their link to BMI and childhood obesity

finding: The SNP rs13086424 was significantly associated with microbiome richness at age 0.5, indicated by a p-value below the Bonferroni-corrected significance threshold.
title: Genotype-microbiome-metabolome associations in early childhood, and their link to BMI and childhood obesity

finding: The frequency of the minor allele T in SNP rs17061792 was positively associated with children's BMI percentiles across several ages, indicating a consistent effect.
title: Genotype-microbiome-metabolome associations in early childhood, and their link to BMI and childhood obesity

finding: The frequency of allele TAA in the rs34799084 locus was negatively associated with children's BMI percentiles across multiple time points, suggesting an inverse relationship.
title: Genotype-microbiome-metabolome associations in early childhood, and their link to BMI and childhood obesity

finding: The frequency of allele C in SNP rs6767126 was positively associated with children's BMI categories, indicating consistent positive effects on BMI.
title: Genotype-microbiome-metabolome associations in early childhood, and their link to BMI and childhood obesity

finding: The rs13076508-C SNP, located near PARP3, was associated with significantly improved survival in IDH-mutant glioma cases receiving TMZ, demonstrating a hazard ratio of 0.40 and a median survival increase of approximately 90.7 months (p=0.041). No effect was observed in cases without TMZ treatment.
title: Functional germline variants in DNA damage repair pathways are associated with altered survival in adults with glioma treated with temozolomide

finding: The variant rs199707443 exhibited a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.003% in non-Finnish Europeans according to gnomAD v3.1.1. Despite this low MAF, it displayed a significant association with Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk in the initial analyses and retained genome-wide significance even after adjustments for sequencing center and kit. This highlighted concerns about spurious associations in AD risk studies due to variability in genotype counts across different sequencing centers.
title: A fast and robust strategy to remove variant level artifacts in Alzheimer’s Disease Sequencing Project data

finding: The index SNP rs13082684, which was identified as the most significant dyslexia-disposing variant in the 23andME GWAS, exhibited associations with lower volume in the right posterior insula and Heschl’s gyrus, along with impacts on deep subcortical structures including the internal capsule, anterior thalamus, and anterior thalamic radiations.
title: Distinct impact modes of polygenic disposition to dyslexia in the adult brain

finding: The SEMA3F variant rs2624839 exhibited both negative associations in the superior longitudinal fasiculi and positive associations in the occipital lobes, linking higher apparent fiber density in the forceps major with dyslexia-disposing alleles.
title: Distinct impact modes of polygenic disposition to dyslexia in the adult brain

finding: The SNP rs11130221 was included among those that exhibited shared causal characteristics linking PTSD with other health-related phenotypes.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The SNP rs748832 was recognized in the study as sharing causal traits between PTSD and various cardiovascular diagnoses.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The SNP rs4269101 was included in the findings, indicating its association with PTSD and potential shared risk with cardiovascular phenotypes.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The G allele of rs6801387 in the CLDN16 gene was linked to a significantly higher likelihood of insulin resistance (IR) with an Odds Ratio (OR) of 9.18 and a p-value < 0.001. This finding was based on inheritance models suggesting dominant inheritance, indicating that individuals with the G/A or A/A genotypes had a higher risk compared to those with the G/G genotype.
title: Unveiling Genetic Associations: Investigating CLDN16, GRID2, NRG3, and CACNG4 Gene Polymorphisms with Insulin Resistance Risk Among Normal BMI Individuals in the Indian Population

finding: A significant association between the diagnosis of functional neurological disorders (FND) and the rs53576 variant of the oxytocin receptor (OXTR) gene was reported. It was found that the minor A-allele correlated with decreased right insular volumes in FND patients, indicating a potential genetic vulnerability associated with this condition. Additionally, in female FND patients, carriers of the A-allele exhibited reduced bilateral amygdalar volume, suggesting a sex-specific structural alteration linked to the genetic variant.
title: Increased Prevalence of Oxytocin Receptor Gene Variant in Functional Neurological Disorder: A Preliminary Case-Control Study

finding: The SNP rs67861307 was among the top three promising SNPs associated with anxiety and depression as identified by both mega-analysis and meta-analysis. It was located in the TNIK gene, which is also highly expressed in the brain and is known to play a role in neurite development and is linked to cognitive disability when mutated.
title: Cross-continental environmental and genome-wide association study on children and adolescent anxiety and depression

finding: SNP rs6771812 was identified as one of the top three promising SNPs shared between the mega-analysis and meta-analysis results for anxiety and depression. It was situated in the TNIK gene, which has implications in cognitive function due to its regulatory role in the development of neurons.
title: Cross-continental environmental and genome-wide association study on children and adolescent anxiety and depression

finding: The SNP rs73184427 was associated with a P-value of 7.11×10−6 and an OR of 1.56. The association differed slightly from prior variants reported in de Lange et al., showcasing a different location but similar implications within the context of IBD.
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: The SNP rs56116661 was associated with a P-value of 5.67×10−10 and OR of 1.14 in IBD, linking it to Crohn's disease variants but showing a different association in this study.
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: The SNP rs28867111 was involved in the inflammatory traits of rheumatoid arthritis, associated with the IP6K2 gene. The analysis indicated significant enrichment of cell types related to oral health, reinforcing the connection between RA and periodontal disease.
title: A scalable variational approach to characterize pleiotropic components across thousands of human diseases and complex traits using GWAS summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs1383063 was identified as a strong predictor of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD), particularly in older males, with significant statistical differences noted in survival analysis. It was present in 30% of the UK Biobank population and was associated with the regulation of MAGI-1, a gene important for kidney function. The allele A of rs1383063 correlated with higher risk in CKD progression and showed a notable role in cellular mechanisms linked to kidney health.
title: Multimodal predictions of end stage chronic kidney disease from asymptomatic individuals for discovery of genomic biomarkers

finding: Japanese-enriched missense variant identified as a putative causal variant for height.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: This stop-gained variant located in <italic>PLOD2</italic> was linked to Bruck syndrome 2.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: The SNP rs73082362 was highlighted as having the most significant p-value in relation to anorexia nervosa risk. Its association was established based on the analysis of genetically predicted mRNA expression, which showed a correlation with the disorder. This SNP was part of a broader investigation that identified multiple genes associated with anorexia nervosa and underscored its significance in genetic predisposition.
title: Multiomic prioritisation of risk genes for anorexia nervosa

finding: SNP rs4241542 was associated with proteinuria in offspring, further highlighting its role in clinical manifestations tied to preeclampsia.
title: Clotting factor genes are associated with preeclampsia in high altitude pregnant women in the Peruvian Andes

finding: The locus rs9810253 on chromosome 3 was discovered to be genome-wide significant in the cross-population analysis of long sleep duration, with an odds ratio of 1.11 and a p-value of 1.24×10^-8. This finding was consistent in all primary studies.
title: Genome-wide association study investigating short and long sleep duration: a cross-population meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs9867455 was identified as a novel Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk locus near the TRANK1 gene, with a significant P-value of 3.49E-08 and an effect size (beta) of -0.0424. The locus was established using a random effects model and was determined to be outside of the maximal linkage disequilibrium boundary for any known AD risk loci.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis and fine-mapping in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs9837978 was identified as another novel AD risk locus near the VWA5B2 gene, with a significant P-value of 3.75E-08 and an effect size (beta) of -0.0526. This finding also emerged from the random effects model and was supported by evidence of significant eQTL associations.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis and fine-mapping in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs6809769 served as a proxy for rs6797002 in the genetic risk score (GRS) calculations. It contributed to the GRS used in the analysis of white matter hyperintensity (WMH) volume, although specific associations with WMH spatial components were not detailed in the findings.
title: White matter hyperintensity spatial patterns: risk factors and clinical correlates

finding: The SNP rs17217831-A was identified as exhibiting significant natural selection in sub-Saharan Africans, with high integrated haplotype score (iHS = 2.49) and extended haplotype homozygosity (XP-EHH = 2.00), suggesting its potential role in reducing susceptibility to critically ill COVID-19.
title: Critically-ill COVID-19 susceptibility gene CCR3 shows natural selection in sub-Saharan Africans

finding: This SNP, located upstream of CCR3, showed a standardized iHS of 6.31, indicating significant natural selection in sub-Saharan Africans, although further context on its direct impact on COVID-19 severity was not specified.
title: Critically-ill COVID-19 susceptibility gene CCR3 shows natural selection in sub-Saharan Africans

finding: The SNP rs3091311 presented a standardized XP-EHH value of 2.57, which was greater than the genome-wide 99% quantile, suggesting it is under strong selection pressure, with implications for CCR3's role in COVID-19 severity.
title: Critically-ill COVID-19 susceptibility gene CCR3 shows natural selection in sub-Saharan Africans

finding: was identified as an intergenic variant related to immune responses, influencing CCR5 which is involved in HIV-1 progression.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was reported in perfect LD concerning sunburn associations.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: The variant rs7614709 was associated with the protein Death-associated protein 1 (DAP) in African ancestry, explaining up to 65% of the variation in protein levels.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: Identified with vascular endothelial growth factor D protein (VEGF-D), this variant demonstrated large effects in both ancestry groups and was linked to heart failure risk.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: Variant associated with VEGF-D, having significant implications in cardiovascular disease pathways, particularly in relation to chronic kidney disease.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: This missense variant in LRIG1 was associated with atrial fibrillation and showed significant roles in cardiovascular health.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: This SNP was associated with decreased expression of ST6GAL1 and corresponded with lower N-sialylation at numerous glycan-derived traits, linked to increased risk of IgA nephropathy.
title: The genetics and epidemiology of N- and O- IgA glycomics

finding: The SNP rs62280366 was also negatively associated with IBS-C, showing an aOR of 0.64 (95% CI = 0.46-0.88), suggesting lower likelihood of constipation and potentially higher odds of diarrhea.
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: This SNP was associated with COVID-19 hospitalization for SLE patients, mapping to the CCR3 gene, with a significant meta-analysis P-value of 2.24×10^-57.
title: Disentangling the common genetic architecture and causality of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus with COVID-19 outcomes: genome-wide cross trait analysis and bi-directional Mendelian randomization study

finding: This SNP was associated with SLE and SARS-CoV-2 infection, found in the NXPE3 gene, further illustrating the genetic relationship.
title: Disentangling the common genetic architecture and causality of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus with COVID-19 outcomes: genome-wide cross trait analysis and bi-directional Mendelian randomization study

finding: Found on the p-arm of chromosome 3, this SNP was among the most strongly associated new loci identified for ADHD-CUD, with an OR of 1.05 and a p-value of 1.79×10^-15. It was linked to 69 genes through functional genomics data.
title: Disentangling the shared genetics of ADHD, cannabis use disorder and cannabis use and prediction of cannabis use disorder in ADHD

finding: This SNP was located intragenic in CADM2 on the q-arm of chromosome 3 and was associated with ADHD-CUD. It presented an odds ratio (OR) of 1.05 and a p-value of 6.93×10^-14, establishing its significance in the genetic landscape of the disorders.
title: Disentangling the shared genetics of ADHD, cannabis use disorder and cannabis use and prediction of cannabis use disorder in ADHD

finding: This SNP was identified as the most strongly associated concordant locus in the cross-disorder GWAS of ADHD-CU, being intragenic in CADM2 with an OR of 1.06 and a p-value of 7.82×10^-16, underlining its association with both ADHD and CU.
title: Disentangling the shared genetics of ADHD, cannabis use disorder and cannabis use and prediction of cannabis use disorder in ADHD

finding: The SNP rs3197999 was reported with an average of 1.46 genes having supportive functional evidence across its locus, specifically highlighted due to the gene(s) affecting susceptibility to colitis based on prior studies linked to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
title: Integrated cell type-specific analysis of blood and gut identifies matching eQTL for 140 IBD risk loci and entrectinib as possible repurposing candidate

finding: The intronic SNP in KNG1 was noted to have a role in bradykinin formation and its regulation by plasmin, integral to immune responses.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: The stop lost variant rs387907272 in MYD88 was linked to leukemia and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). MYD88 plays a critical role in immune response signaling pathways and its mutation is likely to have clinical implications.
title: Exome-wide association studies discover germline mutation patterns and identify high-risk populations in human cancers

finding: The SNP rs6802753, located near ZBTB38, was recognized as a novel genetic association with CD risk, presenting an odds ratio of 1.28 (95% CI = 1.18 to 1.38). This locus was noted for its pleiotropic effects on various human traits, including immune-related functions and other conditions, making it a candidate for further study in the context of CD.
title: Regulatory Variants on the Leukocyte Immunoglobulin-Like Receptor Gene Cluster are Associated with Crohn’s Disease and Interact with Regulatory Variants for TAP2

finding: The rs10513789 variant at the MCCC1 locus was found among the top signals in the African/African Admixed, European, and East Asian ancestry populations, highlighting its potential role in Parkinson's disease.
title: Multi-ancestry population attributable risk assessment of common genetic variation in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases

finding: The SNP rs11130187 was associated with a regulatory region (UTR3) and considered a novel finding in the analysis of mood instability, alcohol consumption, and alcohol use disorder.
title: Genetic overlap between mood instability and alcohol-related phenotypes suggests shared biological underpinnings

finding: The rs9815930 SNP, which resided intronically in the MST1R gene, showed robust causal effects on pain intensity across multiple brain tissues.
title: The genetic architecture of pain intensity in a sample of 598,339 U.S. veterans

finding: SNP rs2247036 was part of a credible set associated with pain intensity, situated nearby the TRAIP gene and demonstrating significant genetic correlation.
title: The genetic architecture of pain intensity in a sample of 598,339 U.S. veterans

finding: Statistical significance was demonstrated for rs74663707 in relation to class Bacilli, indicating its potential effect on gut microbiota in mediating selenium's impact on congenital deformities.
title: The Mendelian randomization analysis of trace elements Zinc, Selenium, Copper, Iron, and Phosphate with congenital foot deformities

finding: The low-frequency missense variant rs75495843 (MAF=3.0%) showed a stronger association for the risk of sebaceous cysts in women (OR: 3.17) compared to men (OR: 2.22). This SNP had already been linked to hereditary trichilemmal cyst formation.
title: Genetic architecture and shared mechanisms of common ‘neglected’ diseases

finding: The SNP rs9820465 tagged a locus between SLC4A7 and EOMES at 3p24.1 and was significantly associated with MacTel (P=5.6×10-09), indicating its importance in the genetic analysis of this disorder.
title: Identification of genetic factors influencing metabolic dysregulation and retinal support for MacTel, a retinal disorder

finding: SNP rs17279437 located at 3p21.31 within the SLC6A20 gene was reported as significantly associated with MacTel (P=6.2×10-10), providing further insights into the genetic underpinnings of this retinal disease.
title: Identification of genetic factors influencing metabolic dysregulation and retinal support for MacTel, a retinal disorder

finding: Discovered as a novel locus (p=4.47×10−9) proximal to TFRC, the transferrin receptor 1, SNP rs73210039 was implicated in central iron uptake, demonstrating differential effects on systemic vs central iron levels, which is significant in the context of iron accumulation.
title: Hemochromatosis Neural Archetype Reveals Iron Disruption in Motor Circuits

finding: SNP rs3817672, also near TFRC, was studied for its impact on serum transferrin and total iron binding capacity, indicating it shares association significance with central iron regulation despite being distinct from peripheral markers.
title: Hemochromatosis Neural Archetype Reveals Iron Disruption in Motor Circuits

finding: Identified intronic to CPHL1P, SNP rs112593750 (p=9.82×10−13) was noted for its association with iron transport functions related to hephaestin, a crucial element for effective intestinal iron transport, further linking it to iron absorption pathways.
title: Hemochromatosis Neural Archetype Reveals Iron Disruption in Motor Circuits

finding: The SNP rs2071044 was associated with schizophrenia risk via the imputed expression of the isoform ENST00000492146, which is an isoform of SFMBT1. This association showed a strong statistical significance with an adjusted P-value of 1.14 x 10^-6. The presence of this SNP in the gene body indicates a potential role in the reduced expression of SFMBT1, which has previously been linked to increased risk of SCZ and bipolar disorder.
title: Isoform-level transcriptome-wide association uncovers extensive novel genetic risk mechanisms for neuropsychiatric disorders in the human brain

finding: Rs2270197, a cis-miR-eQTL for miR-135a-5p, was significantly associated with conditions such as hypertension and osteoarthritis, indicating its potential role in these clinical diagnoses.
title: An atlas of genetic regulation and disease associations of microRNAs

finding: The SNP rs3915166 was specifically linked to the meQTL of CD80 in naive CD4+ T cells of lupus patients, highlighting its unique contribution to signal response and activation in this cell type.
title: Hypomethylation of miR-17-92 cluster in lupus T cells and no significant role for genetic factors in the lupus-associated DNA methylation signature

finding: The SNP rs13069868 in SLC9A9 showed associations with both GSD and GSND, contributing to the findings that multiple SNPs were linked to grip strength across both measures.
title: A GWAS for grip strength in cohorts of children – advantages of analysing young participants for this trait

finding: The SNP rs73064425:T in LZTFL1 was associated with the strongest risk for COVID-19 hospitalization compared to COVID-19 negative controls, with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 7%, an odds ratio (OR) of 1.37, and a significant p-value of 1×10^-11.
title: Common genetic variants identify targets for COVID-19 and individuals at high risk of severe disease

finding: The SNP rs2531743:G near SLC6A20 showed a directionally consistent association with COVID-19 positive cases versus COVID-19 negative, having a MAF of 42%, OR of 0.94, and a p-value of 2×10^-6.
title: Common genetic variants identify targets for COVID-19 and individuals at high risk of severe disease

finding: The distribution of rs1179252680 displayed statistical differences between cases and controls, indicating that it may act as a risk factor for various vascular endothelial dysfunction conditions.
title: The Mechanism of Vascular Endothelial Dysfunction Induced by Ferroptosis Mediated by NARFL Knockout

finding: The SNP rs75174029 was found to be an intronic variant in the FOXP1 gene, which plays a critical role in neural development. It was identified as the most likely causal variant associated with mood and anxiety disorders. Additional evidence, including Hi-C chromatin interaction data, suggested that rs75174029 interacts with several regions of FOXP1, indicating its potential role as a cis-regulatory element.
title: Combining Transdiagnostic and Disorder-Level GWAS Enhances Precision of Psychiatric Genetic Risk Profiles in a Multi-Ancestry Sample

finding: The SNP rs7652704 was identified as an intronic variant in a non-coding RNA locus and exhibited associations with mood/anxiety disorders. It was suggested to be an eQTL for NECTIN3 and demonstrated chromatin interactions with both NECTIN3 and BTLA, a gene related to immune response. Collectively, these findings indicated a regulatory role of rs7652704 in the context of mood/anxiety disorders.
title: Combining Transdiagnostic and Disorder-Level GWAS Enhances Precision of Psychiatric Genetic Risk Profiles in a Multi-Ancestry Sample

finding: At the chr3:45848457:C:T locus, associated with severe COVID-19, the variant rs35731912 showed a strong association with respiratory failure, particularly significant in the age groups 41-60 (P=2.15×10−23, OR=2.20) and 61-80 years (P=6.41×10−6, OR=1.49).
title: Detailed stratified GWAS analysis for severe COVID-19 in four European populations

finding: An intergenic variant located near NICN1, this novel SNP was associated with AUD. The NICN1 gene had links to depression and intelligence, indicating potential biological relevance to alcohol use.
title: Genetic underpinnings of the transition from alcohol consumption to alcohol use disorder: shared and unique genetic architectures in a cross-ancestry sample

finding: The study identified that homozygous carriers of rs36006402 had significantly lower axial length (AL) growth compared to wild-type individuals (p=0.005). This SNP is located in the intron of the SLC7A14 gene, which is crucial for retinal development and visual function. The odds ratio (OR) was calculated to be 4.8, with an associated p-value of 0.0003, indicating a strong link between this variant and reduced AL growth.
title: Associations between RetNet gene polymorphisms and efficacy of orthokeratology for myopia control : sample from a clinical retrospective study

finding: The SNP rs71325088 was positively associated with severe COVID-19 with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.15 in the current analysis, which was lower compared to the effect size reported by Pairo-Castineira et al. (OR=1.9). This SNP was located in the 3p21.31 locus, previously identified in studies that used population controls.
title: Genetic associations with severe COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs73064425 showed a positive association with severe COVID-19, with an OR of 1.17 in the present study, while Pairo-Castineira et al. reported a higher OR of 2.1. This SNP is also situated in the 3p21.31 locus, and a similar association was found using SARS-CoV-2 positive controls.
title: Genetic associations with severe COVID-19

finding: SNP rs116055168 was associated with traits interlinked with cardiovascular health, like height and body mass index, marking it as a positive and original finding.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: SNP rs5848907, previously linked with body mass index, maintained its significance in association with cardiovascular traits across populations, solidifying its positive and original finding.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: The rs13069079 variant in the FYCO1 gene was identified as associated with the hospitalization phenotype for COVID-19, providing insights into genetic factors affecting disease severity.
title: Exome-wide association study to identify rare variants influencing COVID-19 outcomes: Results from the Host Genetics Initiative

finding: The study investigated the association of the T allele of the rs1501299 SNP in the ADIPOQ gene and found that lower levels of serum adiponectin were protective against the development of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) in a Jordanian population. This finding suggested a potential genetic factor influencing adiponectin levels, which were notably decreased in non-obese PCOS patients.
title: Circulating adipokines in non-obese PCOS patients: a systematic review and meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs35677470 in DNASE1L3, which corresponded to a missense variant p.Arg206Cys, significantly affected various properties of cell-free DNA (cfDNA). It led to increased fragment size, reduced concentrations of cfDNA, altered cleave-site motif distributions, and enhanced the fraction of circulating fetal DNA during pregnancy. This SNP was associated with clinical implications for non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT), leading to potential inconclusive results and impaired sensitivity by causing overestimation of fetal fraction.
title: Cell-Free DNA GWAS Reveals Importance of p.Arg206Cys in DNASE1L3 for Non-Invasive Testing

finding: The variant rs4855883 in the APEH gene was identified as a relevant predictive factor for radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients. APEH is involved in metabolic processes.
title: Systematic Review of Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Acute Pain and Relevant Acute Toxicities Induced by Radiotherapy for Head and Neck Cancer

finding: The variant rs61744388 was characterized as a missense variant of the ULK4 gene. It ranked among the top variants in explaining the relationship between aortic annulus area and aortic valve regurgitation.
title: Genetic architecture of cardiac dynamic flow volumes

finding: The SNP rs2352974 was identified as a novel locus associated with PTSD, specifically connected to the circuitry-relevant brain regions CG and UNC. It was mapped to the gene TRAIP, which is involved in DNA damage and repair processes. The findings suggested a link between the neurobiological underpinnings of PTSD and the maintenance of neural integrity.
title: The genetic relationships between post-traumatic stress disorder and its corresponding neural circuit structures

finding: This SNP also intersected with the 12 associations identified in the landmark common genetic variants of autism study, marking it as a significant finding.
title: Exploring autism and autism co-occurring condition associations to elucidate multivariate genetic mechanisms and insights

finding: This SNP near the MFSD1 gene was the final top hit, revealing increased risk for depression with more stressful life events, reaching genome-wide significance (P = 4.5 × 10^-8).
title: Genome-wide by environment interaction study of stressful life events and hospital-treated depression in the iPSYCH2012 sample

finding: The SNP rs35855737 was identified as a genome-wide significant (GWS) variant associated with neuroticism in a GWAS conducted on approximately 73,000 subjects, indicating its relevance to this personality trait.
title: A genome-wide investigation into the underlying genetic architecture of personality traits and overlap with psychopathology

finding: The SNP rs61758195, corresponding to the deep intronic variant MME c.1188+428A>G, was identified through whole genome sequencing in two Australian families with recessive axonal Charcot-Marie-Tooth Neuropathy (CMT). This variant was found in a homozygous state in Family 1 and in a compound heterozygous state with another pathogenic MME variant in Family 2. The variant was demonstrated to create a novel splice donor site, causing the inclusion of an 83 bp pseudoexon and leading to a coding frameshift and a premature termination codon (PTC) in the MME transcript. This finding highlighted the pathogenic nature of deep intronic variants in CMT, a first such report, emphasizing the necessity for further assessments of these variants due to their potential impact on splicing.
title: A deep intronic variant in MME causes autosomal recessive Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy through aberrant splicing

finding: The SNP rs11708828 in the MOBP region was significantly associated with PSP, with a p-value of 7.04 × 10^-12 and a beta coefficient of -0.35, highlighting its relevance in the disorder.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: Identified as significant within the SLC41A3 locus, this SNP showed evidence of association with dental caries in the GLIDE pediatric cohort (EAF[T]: 0.20, P=0.02), indicating a potential genetic risk factor for ECC.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome-Wide Association Study of Early Childhood Caries

finding: The SNP rs1005678 was identified as a lead variant associated with both dyslexia and ADHD, indicating its involvement in neurodevelopmental processes related to these conditions. Specifically, it was previously reported in both the dyslexia and ADHD genome-wide association studies, suggesting a strong genetic overlap between these two traits.
title: Genetic neurodevelopmental clustering and dyslexia

finding: The variant rs13080752 in the LPP gene was recognized for its association with celiac disease as well as mLOX susceptibility, pointing towards shared genetic underpinnings.
title: Population analyses of mosaic X chromosome loss identify genetic drivers and widespread signatures of cellular selection

finding: The rs2371109 SNPin EOMES was connected to mLOX and linked to rheumatoid arthritis, indicating potential autoimmune susceptibilities.
title: Population analyses of mosaic X chromosome loss identify genetic drivers and widespread signatures of cellular selection

finding: The missense variant rs575892658 in the GORASP1 gene was linked to improved audiometric thresholds for carriers in the cohort. Furthermore, this gene was also specifically linked to Metabolic hearing loss through an outlier analysis.
