title: Accurate phenotypic classification and exome sequencing allow identification of novel genes and variants associated with adult-onset hearing loss

finding: The SNP rs13092193 was associated with the prognosis of acute ischemic stroke patients who had a history of cancer. In the context of the study referenced, the findings indicated that patients with active cancer had higher mortality rates post-stroke when treated with endovascular thrombectomy (EVT), suggesting a significant impact on outcomes that could be influenced by this specific genetic marker.
title: Does malignancy status effect outcomes in patients with large vessel occlusion stroke and cancer that underwent endovascular thrombectomy?

finding: This SNP was found to be an xQTL for multiple genes on chromosome 3 and was associated with schizophrenia GWAS. It highlighted the challenge of distinguishing the molecular effects due to pleiotropy.
title: Cross-ancestry, cell-type-informed atlas of gene, isoform, and splicing regulation in the developing human brain

finding: The SNP rs58322641 was analyzed alongside other variants and showed that increased genetic risk of CHIP correlated with a lower likelihood of Alzheimer's disease (AD), with a calculated odds ratio of 0.92 per log-odds increase, indicating a significant protective effect against AD.
title: Clonal hematopoiesis is associated with protection from Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The CCR2 variant (rs1799864) was identified in 8 patients, suggesting a possible protective role against Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection.
title: Clinical and molecular characterization of COVID-19 hospitalized patients

finding: The CCR5 variant (rs1800940) was identified in 1 patient, indicating its potential association with protection against Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection.
title: Clinical and molecular characterization of COVID-19 hospitalized patients

finding: The intronic variant rs1520483 in LTF gene was linked to increased risk of HPV(+) OPC, displaying an odds ratio of 1.23 (95% CI: 1.14, 1.32, p_meta=2.19×10^-8).
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: NCKIPSD rs12497850 was significantly involved in predicting alpha-synuclein levels in patients' CSF and was found to be associated with important clinical variables.
title: The multi-modality neuroimaging analysis identified an essential genetic variant associated with Parkinson’s disease

finding: This locus was previously identified as a GWAS hit for intraocular pressure and vertical cup-disc ratio. It regulates the timing of early retinal cell production and was confirmed in the present analysis.
title: Multi-omic spatial effects on high-resolution AI-derived retinal thickness

finding: This SNP was detected in a region interacting significantly with SOX2, a gene associated with microphthalmia and optic nerve hypoplasia.
title: Multi-omic spatial effects on high-resolution AI-derived retinal thickness

finding: The rs1801725 SNP in the CASR gene was identified as being associated with a higher risk of developing secondary malignancies in the lungs and bones among patients with breast, prostate, and skin cancers. Specifically, patients with the homozygous TT genotype exhibited increased circulating calcium levels and a 1.21 odds ratio for secondary malignancies of respiratory organs and a 1.20 odds ratio for secondary malignancies of bone. This indicates that dysregulation in calcium homeostasis due to the presence of the TT genotype may contribute to the progression and metastasis of hypercalcemia prone cancers.
title: Calcium-Sensing Receptor Polymorphisms at rs1801725 are Associated with Increased Risk of Secondary Malignancies

finding: SNP rs62250713 was found to be an intronic variant in CADM2 associated with all four substance use traits.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: Found on chromosome 3q28, the SNP rs710521 was significantly associated with bladder cancer, particularly noted in studies involving various populations.
title: A systematic review of genome-wide association studies on bladder cancer

finding: The SNP rs7613360 was identified in a GWAS meta-analysis of ADHD, where it was associated with increased risk for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. The study encompassed a total of 38,691 individuals with ADHD compared to 186,843 controls, and the SNP was part of one of the 27 genome-wide significant loci identified. This locus was linked to a polygenic context, indicating a broad genetic basis for ADHD.
title: Genome-wide analyses of ADHD identify 27 risk loci, refine the genetic architecture and implicate several cognitive domains

finding: The SNP rs2311059, closely located to rs7613360 on chromosome 3, was also found to be significant in the same GWAS meta-analysis of ADHD. Like rs7613360, it contributed to establishing significant genetic associations with ADHD, highlighting the involvement of this locus in the disorder's genetic architecture that was observed across a large sample of cases and controls.
title: Genome-wide analyses of ADHD identify 27 risk loci, refine the genetic architecture and implicate several cognitive domains

finding: The variant rs61176331 on chromosome 3 was identified as a novel maternal genome-wide significant association with HDP. This SNP, located near the RARB gene, had an odds ratio (OR) of 3.09 and a p-value of 7.97 × 10^−9 in the primary analysis. It was subsequently validated in the UK Biobank with an OR of 1.29 and p-value of 3.73 × 10^−2, confirming its association with HDP.
title: A multi-ancestry genome-wide association study identifies novel candidate loci in the RARB gene associated with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy

finding: The SNP rs4135300 at the SYN2 locus exhibited an association with pulse pressure (PP), especially in the 'non-current smoking' exposure group showing a significant P value of 8.72x10^-7. Its interaction effect was negative in the 'current smoking' group (Interaction P=3x10^-7). Furthermore, this variant served as an eQTL for SYN2, indicating gene expression changes related to smoking behavior.
title: Multi-omics insights into the biological mechanisms underlying gene-by-lifestyle interactions with smoking and alcohol consumption detected by genome-wide trans-ancestry meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs2581789 was identified as associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) at a genome-wide significant level (p = 2.1×10^-8, OR = 0.92) in a GWAS meta-analysis with 14,140 OCD cases and 562,117 controls. It was located in the intergenic region between SFMBT1 and RFT1 on chromosome 3p21.1. This SNP was associated with psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia (SCZ) and bipolar disorder (BP), along with traits related to body mass index (BMI), waist-hip ratio, and psychological parameters such as worry and well-being, indicating its pleiotropic effects involving shared neurobiological pathways across disorders.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies new locus associated with OCD

finding: SNP rs6445538 colocalized with eQTL and meQTL data, confirming its involvement in gene regulation related to smoking behaviors, specifically within the locus containing MUSTN1, STIMATE, and ITIH4.
title: Smoking-informed methylation and expression QTLs in human brain and colocalization with smoking-associated genetic loci

finding: The SNP rs4687472 was part of a colocalizing region that had a high probability of association (>80%) with gene expression and methylation changes, linking it to the regulation of smoking-associated traits in the locus involving MUSTN1, STIMATE, and ITIH4.
title: Smoking-informed methylation and expression QTLs in human brain and colocalization with smoking-associated genetic loci

finding: The IL5RA31+197A/G variant (rs340833) demonstrated a statistically significant interaction that was relevant to the development of IgAN (P < 0.001).
title: Candidate genes for IgA nephropathy in pediatric patients: exome-wide association study

finding: The SNP rs201109606, located in the 3' untranslated region of an alternatively spliced transcript of SUMF1, was associated with a reduced risk for Alzheimer's disease plus psychosis (AD+P), indicated by an odds ratio of 0.65. This result marked it as a significant and original finding within the context of the study.
title: Genome-Wide Association Identifies the First Risk Loci for Psychosis in Alzheimer Disease

finding: This rare variant was associated with fasting insulin (FI) upstream of the ROBO1 locus. It was notable for its presence only in the African population, linking it to potential T2D complications.
title: Whole Genome Sequence Association Analysis of Fasting Glucose and Fasting Insulin Levels in Diverse Cohorts from the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: This intronic variant was identified in the Samoan population and was linked to FI; however, it did not replicate in a separate cohort, indicating a need for more data.
title: Whole Genome Sequence Association Analysis of Fasting Glucose and Fasting Insulin Levels in Diverse Cohorts from the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: The SNP rs7652179 was identified as a lead SNP in the context of SGIT, having been replicated in related studies highlighting its significance for chronic pain phenotypes.
title: Decomposing the genetic background of chronic back pain

finding: The SNP rs13071488 was reported in the context of mitochondrial pyruvate carrier's role in cancer cell metabolism and tumorigenesis. This study implicated the SNP in cellular mechanisms that may impact cancer progression, highlighting its relevance as a genetic factor in understanding tumor biology.
title: Utilizing nullomers in cell-free RNA for early cancer detection

finding: The CROM:c.679G>C (rs60822372) variation was responsible for the Cr(a-) phenotype which was characterized by the absence of the Cr(a) antigen on the RBC membrane, observed at a frequency of about 10% in Middle Eastern populations.
title: A comprehensive characterization of blood group antigen variants in the Middle Eastern population genomes - Insights into genetic epidemiology

finding: The rs11409032 variant in the MYLK gene was also associated with OA in Ashkenazi Veterans, displaying a strong null effect similar to rs147959272, which suggested that these loci could play significant roles in OA development.
title: Novel Genetic Loci Associated with Osteoarthritis in Multi-Ancestry Analyses in 484,374 Participants from MVP and the UK Biobank

finding: This SNP, associated with the IGF2BP2 locus, was noted among the shared SNPs between type 2 diabetes and PHQ-9, highlighting its relevance in the researched relationship.
title: Bi-directional Mendelian randomization and multi-phenotype GWAS show causality and shared pathophysiology between depression and type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs7642426, located near ORC5, interacted with cumulative prenatal stress to show a significant trans-association with DNAm at cg06592260, which is within EPPK1. The association was significant (B=-0.013, SE=0.002, p=1.12×10^-13), indicating how maternal stress could affect the epigenetic landscape and possibly alter developmental processes.
title: Interactive effects of genotype with prenatal stress on DNA methylation at birth

finding: The eQTL variant rs189174 related to serum alkaline phosphatase levels was found to have an allele frequency of 0.91 in UKB-AFR compared to 0.34 in UKB-EUR, indicating a marked difference that may influence trait expression.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: The SNP rs4679885, located at the KPNA4/TRIM59 locus, was associated with an inverse causal relationship between clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) and leukocyte telomere length (LTL). The analysis revealed a significant beta coefficient of -0.017 with a p-value of 0.04, indicating that an increase in CHIP was associated with a decrease in LTL, thus supporting the hypothesis that CHIP could hasten telomere shortening.
title: Bidirectional Mendelian randomization supports bidirectional causality between telomere length and clonal hematopoiesis of intermediate potential

finding: For SNP rs167771 in DRD3, an allele frequency difference of 0.23 was noted, indicating its potential influence in metabolic reactions across various populations.
title: Diversity and level of evidence evaluation of commercial pharmacogenomic testing for mental health

finding: The SNP rs56065557 was identified as a novel locus significant for atrioventricular block (AVB) through genome-wide association analysis. This finding indicated its potential role in the heritable basis of CCDs.
title: Genetic Insights into Cardiac Conduction Disorders from Genome-Wide Association Studies

finding: The SNP rs7433306 was also recognized as a novel significant locus for AVB, implying its involvement in genetic predisposition to cardiac conduction disorders.
title: Genetic Insights into Cardiac Conduction Disorders from Genome-Wide Association Studies

finding: The fine-mapped SNP rs9834970 was implicated in cortical expression of TRANK1 and identified a burden of damaging rare variants in bipolar disorder.
title: Fine-mapping genomic loci refines bipolar disorder risk genes

finding: The SNP rs1015164 was associated with HIV set-point viral load and CD4+ T cell counts. This association suggested a plausible role in mediating inflammatory cell traffic and immune responses, linking it to the severity of COVID-19.
title: SUMMIT: An integrative approach for better transcriptomic data imputation improves causal gene identification

finding: The variant rs6809522 was associated with testosterone levels (β=0.016, P=3.00E-08), indicating its relevance in hormonal regulation in men.
title: Genome-wide analyses identify 21 infertility loci and over 400 reproductive hormone loci across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: Also at the chr3p21.31 locus, rs13092887-A showed a significant association with the severity of Covid-19, with an OR of 1.73 and P=2.38×10−8 in Europeans.
title: A year of COVID-19 GWAS results from the GRASP portal reveals potential SARS-CoV-2 modifiers

finding: The SNP rs10511087 was found to be significant in the EXT GWAS, indicating its relevance in externalizing behaviors. It was located in the CADM2 region and was associated with problematic alcohol use outcomes from the ALCP-O GWAS.
title: Parsing Genetically Influenced Risk Pathways: Genetic Loci Impact Problematic Alcohol Use Via Externalizing and Specific Risk

finding: The intronic variant rs1865250 in the CADM2 gene was robustly associated with several impulsivity phenotypes and other related behaviors, presenting a significant association with a P value of 1.06e-12.
title: The pleiotropic architecture of human impulsivity across biological scales

finding: This common missense variant in SCN10A was replicated in AF risk analyses, emphasizing its relevance to cardiac conduction.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: The protective SCN5A variant was associated with decreased risk for AF, hinting at its potential impact on pulse rate regulation.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: The association of this variant with AF risk further supported the role of SCN5A-SCN10A locus in cardiac arrhythmias.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: Identified in IBI analysis as a significant variant, it is known to relate to hypertension, although its prominence was less recognized in GWAS.
title: An individualized Bayesian method for estimating genomic variants of hypertension

finding: The SNP rs9871453 in the SCN10A locus was significantly associated with the occurrence of LCT-PVs in patients with AF. The association was further emphasized as it was one of the SNPs validating an elevated polygenic risk score (PRS) significantly different from that of normal PVs (p=1.64e-05). The findings highlighted the genetic background of patients with LCT-PVs.
title: Left common trunkus pulmonary veins have genetic background and poorer rhythm outcome after paroxysmal atrial fibrillation catheter ablation

finding: The SNP rs73188394 was found near the TKT gene, and every additional copy of the G allele was associated with a 21% higher circulating FGF23. This finding was significant with a p-value of 8.6 x 10^-118, highlighting its strong relationship with mineral metabolism traits.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS for circulating FGF23 Identifies Novel Network Interactions Between HRG-HMGB1 and Cardiac Disease in CKD

finding: The SNP rs56682988 was implicated in the association with iRBD via rare non-coding variants in the LAMP3 gene, identified in controls and contributing to the observed reduced risk of iRBD.
title: Novel associations of BST1 and LAMP3 with rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder

finding: The study found that in APOE4 carriers, BRHE-K carriers diagnosed with Alzheimer disease (AD) exhibited symptoms 6.4 years earlier than noncarriers. This SNP, rs1803274, related to the K-variant of butyrylcholinesterase (BCHE), was shown to significantly interact with the APOE4 allele to decrease age-at-onset for AD and increase the rate of progression from mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to AD, indicating a direct relationship between BCHE-K status and disease severity.
title: Onset of Alzheimer disease in apolipoprotein ɛ4 carriers is earlier in butyrylcholinesterase K variant carriers

finding: The SNP rs1245411910, known as c.520G>A, was identified as a pathogenic variant in the COL7A1 gene during the investigation of two unrelated patients with Recessive Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa (RDEB). The presence of this SNP was specifically related to the phenotype manifested by severe blistering and localized scarring, emphasizing its role in the disease's pathology.
title: New RDEB intermediate variant with in-frame partial exon skipping in FN III-like domain of type VII collagen

finding: Identified as a rare variant with significant effect size (OR > 2.1) located near EPHA3, further supporting the identification of rare variants in VTE.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs8192675, which is intronic in the SLC2A2 gene, was associated with altered expression of GLUT2 and also reproducibly linked to the glycaemic response to metformin in type 2 diabetes patients, indicating its role in metformin's effects.
title: The Effect of Metformin Treatment on the Circulating Proteome

finding: The SNP rs67183339 in the KCNMB2 gene was found to associate with cigarette smoking and varicose veins. This interaction proposed a mechanism where a variant could contribute to the cardiovascular-related risks associated with varicose veins due to the gene's role in potassium channel regulation.
title: Improving Genetic Association Studies with a Novel Methodology that Unveils the Hidden Complexity of All-Cause Heart Failure

finding: In the context of nephronophthisis, a nonsense variant in exon 18 of NPHP3 was identified in a proband with proteinuric renal disease and supported by multiple ClinVar submissions, confirming its pathogenicity.
title: Non-coding variants are a rare cause of recessive developmental disorders in trans with coding variants

finding: An intronic variant found near the splice donor site of exon 24 in NPHP3 was studied. Despite a low SpliceAI score, its high CADD and PhloP scores, along with its location, suggested a likely deleterious impact related to splicing in the context of the proband's renal disease.
title: Non-coding variants are a rare cause of recessive developmental disorders in trans with coding variants

finding: The SNP rs11928693 near HACD2 was noted in a GWAS of European ancestry, and it showed significance in the context of sleep duration within the large multi-ancestry meta-analysis that identified it as a novel association.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: This SNP at 3q26.31 demonstrated a z-score of 6.34, associating with TNIK, linked to neurogenesis and intellectual disability, highlighting its relevance to brain development.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: Identified within an intron of EPHA3 at 3p11.1, it linked to axon formation with a significant association in language-related functional connectivity metrics.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The SNP rs115160714, which refers to a c.*229C>T polymorphism in the TOPBP1 gene, was investigated in relation to endometrial cancer risk. It was found that this genetic variant could be associated with an increased susceptibility to developing endometrial cancer, supporting the notion that TOPBP1 is involved in the DNA damage response, which is critical for maintaining genome stability.
title: The mitotic CIP2A-TOPBP1 axis facilitates mitotic pathway choice between MiDAS and MMEJ

finding: The SNP rs529711487, a rare variant on chromosome 3, was identified as having a strong effect on endocranial globularity with a Beta estimate of 6.68 (SE = 1.15). Heterozygous carriers of this SNP exhibited larger globularity scores compared to homozygous major allele individuals, indicating its significant role in this trait despite its low minor allele frequency (0.002).
title: Imaging genomics reveals genetic architecture of the globular human braincase

finding: The SNP rs839254 was identified as a stable factor associated with dry matter (DM) content in yam tubers, consistently found in a significant association across two locations. Genotypes with the AA allele exhibited higher DM compared to GA and GG genotypes, indicating its influence on the culinary trait. The SNP is located downstream of the gene Dioal.09G047900, which encodes a Winged helix-turn-helix DNA-binding domain protein.
title: Detecting the genetic variants associated with key culinary traits in Dioscorea alata

finding: The SNP rs2272522 was reported as having a significant association with schizophrenia in Qatar. This finding was part of a broader investigation into the genetic factors contributing to schizophrenia, suggesting that variations in the close homologue of the L1 gene may influence susceptibility to this condition.
title: The L1CAM SAX-7 is an antagonistic modulator of Erk Signaling

finding: The ITIH3-rs2535629 SNP was linked to combined phenotypes of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), bipolar disorder (BD), unipolar depression (UD), and schizophrenia (SCZ). It also correlated with the expression of the closest ITIH3 gene and was involved in regulatory interactions with multiple eGenes, indicating its potential significance across various psychiatric conditions.
title: Decoding the multimorbidities among psychiatric disorders and cognitive functioning

finding: The SNP rs60464856 was characterized as a significant prostate cancer risk factor. Pooled analysis from the PRACTICAL cohort indicated that the G allele was associated with a heightened prostate cancer risk (pvalue=1.2E-16). Additionally, the G allele correlated with increased expression of the target gene RUVBL1 across multiple datasets, evidencing its role in prostate cancer pathogenesis. The study employed CRISPR interference screening, which confirmed that multiple guide RNAs targeting this SNP led to substantial inhibition of RUVBL1 expression and significant growth advantage in prostate cancer cell lines. Furthermore, ChIP-qPCR analysis exhibited preferential binding of cohesion subunits to the A allele, suggesting allele-specific regulatory dynamics at this locus and its involvement in chromatin structure. RUVBL1 expression was notably linked to cell cycle pathways and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer patients.
title: Combined CRISPR and proteomics screening reveal a cohesin-CTCF-bound allele contributing to increased expression of RUVBL1 and prostate cancer progression

finding: In a GWAS analysis of the composite latent variable associated with the schizophrenia cluster, rs9874537 was identified with a P value of 4.5 x 10-8, which highlighted its significance in linking genetic architecture to MRI phenotypes related to schizophrenia.
title: Linking the genetic structure of neuroanatomical phenotypes with psychiatric disorders

finding: rs2535629 also correlated with increased transcript levels of ITIH4, suggesting a consistent regulatory role across developmental stages concerning ASD.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: The eQTL rs832190 showed consistent increases in THOC7 transcript levels across both tissue types, supporting its significance in the context of ASD.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: This SNP was shown to have opposing effects on PCCB gene transcript levels, highlighting the complexity of gene regulation in ASD.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: Similar to rs7432375, this SNP exhibited non-collinear impacts on PCCB gene expression, further illustrating intricate regulatory interactions relevant to ASD development.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: rs4481150 was identified as an eQTL that increased ITIH4 transcript levels exclusively in the adult cortex, demonstrating its stage-specific regulatory role in ASD.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: The SNP rs55961674 was identified as an intronic variant of KPNA1. Despite KPNA1 being depleted and showing low expression in dopaminergic neurons, the upstream gene CASR was found to have significant expression specificity to dopaminergic neurons. The study highlighted that variations in CASR could contribute to the risk of Parkinson's disease (PD) due to its role in calcium handling in neurons.
title: Single cell spatial transcriptomic and translatomic profiling of dopaminergic neurons in health, aging and disease

finding: The SNP rs11709472, associated with celiac disease, was linked with chromatin accessibility at a locus control region between BCL6 and LPP, crucial for B cell function.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: It was significantly associated with autoimmune diseases and identified within GC-specific chromatin regions, highlighting its potential regulatory role for BCL6.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: Linked to celiac disease, the SNP rs9834159 was found in B cell-specific chromatin, which emphasizes its associations with B cell functionality in autoimmune responses.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: The SNP city was associated with various autoimmune diseases and shown to be involved in B cell-specific regulatory mechanisms affecting GC dynamics.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: The SNP was associated with allergy and found to participate in chromatin accessibility linked to autoimmune regulatory networks.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: Also associated with allergy, this SNP was part of the chromatin landscape that indicated significant correlations with B cell activation and immune responses.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: This SNP was linked to multiple sclerosis and was present in regulatory regions critical for GC functionality amidst autoimmune pathology.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: Associated with asthma, this SNP was recognized in immune cell-specific chromatin, showcasing potential involvement in regulatory pathways influencing allergic responses.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: The SNP was accessible across immune lineages and implicated in autoimmune regulatory mechanisms within B and Tfh cells.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: This SNP exhibited accessibility in diverse immune lineages, suggesting its broad regulatory influence potentially linked to autoimmunity.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: Associated with autoimmune disorders, this SNP was identified in chromatin regions influencing gene expression that is pertinent to immune regulation.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: The SNP rs6441972 was implicated in the regulation of the CCR2 gene in Treg cells, suggesting its significance in T1D through allele-specific regulatory pathways.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: The SNP rs13079080 was associated with differential regulation of the succinate receptor 1 (SUCNR1) gene by miRNA-4470, indicating a potential genetic influence on AMD susceptibility through modulation of this receptor.
title: The metabolite receptor SUCNR1 in oxidative stress-induced age-related macular degeneration

finding: SNP rs4686991 was associated with SHR in a single credible set and exhibited opposite effects in different ancestries: a marginal beta of 0.0401 in the China Kadoorie Biobank (CKB) and -0.024792 in the UKB, both showing strong significant associations.
title: Genetics of skeletal proportions in two different populations

finding: The SNP rs1800668 was associated with the HGFL (hepatocyte growth factor-like) protein levels. It was located 326 Kb upstream of the MST1 gene and was a significant eQTL for 25 genes across multiple tissues. It displayed high overlap in epigenomic annotation marks and was implicated in the regulation of proteins related to obesity.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: This SNP was identified alongside rs1800668 in association with HGFL levels and was part of a larger linkage disequilibrium (LD) block that contained additional significant SNPs. Its presence in the analysis underlined the genetic regulation of proteins involved in metabolic disorders.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: The SNP rs724608 was associated with the IL1AP protein, bolstering previous findings linking obesity and the IL-1 pathway. It was underlined as having relations with other SNPs in linkage disequilibrium, supporting its relevance in inflammatory and metabolic pathways.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: DRD3 rs6280 Ser/Ser subjects had lower prolactin levels compared to Gly allele carriers, suggesting its role in modulating metabolic responses during olanzapine treatment.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: rs6809836 was significantly associated with GP+M and previously linked to Barrett’s esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma, emphasizing its relevance in esophageal disorders.
title: Genome-wide association study of gastrointestinal disorders reinforces the link between the digestive tract and the nervous system

finding: The analysis of rs62262685 revealed variability in variant allele frequency (VAF) among heterozygous normal samples. This SNP was assessed using a specific exome target capture kit, indicating a notable effect from the methodology used in sequencing, and it was part of a larger study of genetic variations present in cancer and their implications.
title: Detecting oncogenic selection through biased allele retention in The Cancer Genome Atlas

finding: The SNP rs13071606 was linked to research examining its potential as a biomarker in breast cancer, specifically in the context of employing multidimensional diffusion MRI to characterize tissue microstructure. The study illustrated how specific genetic loci could correlate with biological features detectable through advanced imaging techniques, suggesting a relationship between the SNP and the sensitivity of MRI in identifying cancerous tissues.
title: The variability of multidimensional diffusion-relaxation MRI estimates in the human brain

finding: The findings confirmed a significant four-way interaction effect for rs53576 where G carriers showed accelerated trait judgments with oxytocin, indicating increased sensitivity to its effects compared to AA genotype carriers.
title: Oxytocin modulation of self-other distinction is replicable and influenced by oxytocin receptor (OXTR) genotype

finding: For the TT homozygotes of rs2268498, significant effects on memory performance were observed, where they showed pronounced effects on subsequent memory accuracy particularly for conditions involving negatively valenced words.
title: Oxytocin modulation of self-other distinction is replicable and influenced by oxytocin receptor (OXTR) genotype

finding: The SNP rs1800734 was linked to enhanced expression of the DCLK3 gene through mechanisms involving long-range interactions, which were shown to promote progression of colorectal cancer. This finding highlighted the significance of non-coding genetic variants in regulating gene expression and influencing cancer biology.
title: WAPL maintains dynamic cohesin to preserve lineage specific distal gene regulation

finding: The SNP rs73178598 was identified in a GWAS study as being associated with psoriasis. It was located around 240kb upstream of the SATB1 locus, where the antisense non-coding RNA SATB1-AS1 is transcribed. This suggests that the SNP may play a role in the transcriptional regulation of SATB1, potentially impacting T cell differentiation and immune responses.
title: Identification of a novel enhancer essential for Satb1 expression in TH2 cells and activated ILC2s

finding: The SNP rs13071488 was associated with the expression of mitochondrial pyruvate carrier (MPC) genes, specifically MPC1 and MPC2, which were involved in the malignant development of lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD). This association highlighted its potential role in cancer cell metabolism and tumorigenesis, providing context for understanding the genetic influences on tumor proliferation, migration, and invasion.
title: Development and validation of glycolysis-cholesterol synthesis genes in lung adenocarcinoma

finding: Located within the large PTPRG gene, this variant associated with the QT interval (P = 8 x 10^-7) loops over more than 200kb to its own promoter.
title: Detailed Regulatory Interaction Map of the Human Heart Facilitates Gene Discovery for Cardiovascular Disease

finding: Associated with the PR interval (P = 4.14 x 10^-11), this SNP was found within the ITGA9 gene and looped to its promoter.
title: Detailed Regulatory Interaction Map of the Human Heart Facilitates Gene Discovery for Cardiovascular Disease

finding: The polymorphism rs53576 within the OXTR gene was shown to be associated with different social behaviors. The G allele was linked to optimal social development, including higher levels of dispositional empathy and favorable prosocial features. A/A homozygotes exhibited poorer social traits, reduced empathy accuracy, and a less flexible social development. The interaction between rs53576 and maternal overprotection revealed significant effects in the Italian sample, with A/A homozygotes being negatively affected by maternal overprotection regarding adult avoidance, whereas G-carriers were positively associated with avoidance.
title: Recalled parental bonding interacts with oxytocin receptor gene polymorphism in modulating anxiety and avoidance in adult relationships

finding: The SNP rs2886870 was associated with the expression of the gene MB21D2. It was predicted to affect NFKB binding affinity, which was found to influence mRNA levels of the connected gene, suggesting a role in transcriptional regulation.
title: Functional effects of variation in transcription factor binding highlight long-range gene regulation by epromoters

finding: SNP rs2352974, located on Chromosome 3, showed previous associations with general cognitive ability, intelligence, and educational attainment. In the current study, it demonstrated significant heterogeneity and the largest associations with VNR, Tower, Matrices, and Trails-B measures, linking it to higher order cognition while showing negligible associations with more basic cognitive processes.
title: Genetic “General Intelligence,” Objectively Determined and Measured

finding: The SNP rs1482852 was associated with different parameters of fetal growth, adiposity in newborns, maternal adiponectin levels, and cord blood leptin levels. This finding suggested that variants in this region on chromosome 3 may be involved in metabolic programming and growth regulation, particularly in response to maternal smoking during pregnancy.
title: Placental DNA methylation signatures of maternal smoking during pregnancy and potential impacts on fetal growth

finding: The SNP rs900400, located near the LEKR1 gene, was linked to elevated insulin release following an oral glucose challenge. Its C-allele was specifically associated with lower birth weight, indicating its role in fetal growth and metabolism, related to maternal smoking's effects.
title: Placental DNA methylation signatures of maternal smoking during pregnancy and potential impacts on fetal growth

finding: Similar to rs1482852 and rs900400, the SNP rs13322435 was implicated in the regulation of fetal growth, although specific details of its associations were less emphasized. It was associated with metabolic programming, supporting the idea that genetic variants in this locus were responsive to MSDP-related changes.
title: Placental DNA methylation signatures of maternal smoking during pregnancy and potential impacts on fetal growth

finding: The rs1464791 variant was also significantly associated with beat synchronization and situated within a human-accelerated region. This variant too acted as an eQTL for the GBE1 gene, which is associated with neuromuscular disease, reaction time, and cognitive impairments.
title: Genome-wide association study of musical beat synchronization demonstrates high polygenicity

finding: The SNP c.-13G > C (rs17429833) was linked with an increased risk for familial colorectal cancer in research that focused on variants in the CLDN1 gene.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: Similar to rs17429833, the SNP c.108C > T (rs72466472) was also associated with an increased risk for familial colorectal cancer in the same variant study involving the CLDN1 gene.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: This SNP was examined in relation to inflammation and might have implications in conditions such as colorectal cancer given its biological significance.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs9859077 was linked to a regulatory network indicating connectivity with other loci based on established biological priors, which resulted in the identification of novel edges in the inferred networks.
title: Network reconstruction for trans acting genetic loci using multi-omics data and prior information

finding: The original research by Ding et al. (2013) was confirmed for the HYAL locus using rs116075629, maintaining the argument regarding Neanderthal introgression. Therefore, the phylogenetic relationships drawn from the current study were consistent with prior findings.
title: Focusing on human haplotype diversity in numerous individual genomes demonstrates an evolutional feature of each locus

finding: rs28372852 was located in the promoter of the GFM1 gene and served as the alternative ASB of CREB1 and reference ASB of MXI1. The allelic imbalance correlated with respective binding motifs, and it was identified as an eQTL target for GFM1. This finding indicated that ASB could directly switch gene expression activity between activators and repressors.
title: Landscape of allele-specific transcription factor binding in the human genome

finding: The SNP rs11708187-A was linked to monocyte count, which is important in the context of meningococcal infections, a finding supported by genome-wide association study results.
title: Explainable models using transcription factor binding and epigenome patterns at promoters reveal disease-associated genes and their regulators in the context of cell-types

finding: The SNP rs9809116-G was associated with both monocyte count and platelet counts, indicating its significance in the development of the meningococcus prothrombotic trait, as highlighted by GWAS findings.
title: Explainable models using transcription factor binding and epigenome patterns at promoters reveal disease-associated genes and their regulators in the context of cell-types

finding: The SNP rs55890339-T was also associated with monocyte count, contributing to the understanding of immune response in meningococcal infections as per genome-wide association study data.
title: Explainable models using transcription factor binding and epigenome patterns at promoters reveal disease-associated genes and their regulators in the context of cell-types

finding: The SNP rs12497693 was linked to platelet counts, reflecting the severity of infections, thus demonstrating its relevance with GWAS findings regarding meningococcal infections.
title: Explainable models using transcription factor binding and epigenome patterns at promoters reveal disease-associated genes and their regulators in the context of cell-types

finding: The SNP rs13081776 was identified in the context of its association with pancreatic cancer immunity, specifically regarding the roles of activated regulatory T-cells and the dysfunction and senescence of T-cells. This correlation suggests that the genetic variation at this locus may influence the immune response in pancreatic cancer, potentially relating to the mechanisms of immune cell interactions and chronic inflammation, which were also highlighted in studies linking T cell-monocyte complexes to diseases like diabetes and HIV.
title: CD3+ T-cell: CD14+monocyte complexes are dynamic and increased with HIV and glucose intolerance

finding: The finding related to SNP rs2305037 in the CBLB gene indicated that cell lines homozygous for this SNP were more resistant to lapatinib, as assessed through cellular variability of p-STAT3. This was part of a broader analysis linking SNP status to signaling characteristics predictive of drug sensitivity.
title: Deciphering the Signaling Network Landscape of Breast Cancer Improves Drug Sensitivity Prediction

finding: The SNP rs7632287 was previously identified in a meta-analysis as being associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). This finding highlights the potential link between alterations in the expression levels of the OXTR gene, which encodes the oxytocin receptor important for social behavior, and the risk of ASD.
title: Investigating the impact of paternal aging on murine sperm miRNA profiles and their potential link to autism spectrum disorder

finding: The SNP rs237887 was also linked to autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in earlier studies. It was part of the meta-analysis that identified polymorphisms in the OXTR gene, suggesting its involvement in the etiology of ASD.
title: Investigating the impact of paternal aging on murine sperm miRNA profiles and their potential link to autism spectrum disorder

finding: Associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), the SNP rs2268491 was identified in a previous meta-analysis focused on the OXTR gene, implicating its role in the susceptibility to ASD.
title: Investigating the impact of paternal aging on murine sperm miRNA profiles and their potential link to autism spectrum disorder

finding: SNP rs2254298, recognized from a meta-analysis, was linked to autism spectrum disorder (ASD) as a polymorphism within the OXTR gene, indicating its potential importance in the risk of developing ASD.
title: Investigating the impact of paternal aging on murine sperm miRNA profiles and their potential link to autism spectrum disorder

finding: The rs6444081 T2D risk allele (C) was linked to decreased chromatin accessibility at a CRE that regulated the gene ETV5, which modulates insulin secretion. It was suggested that this allele disrupts NRF2 binding, leading to diminished ETV5 responses in the context of ER stress.
title: Comparative Multi-omic Mapping of Human Pancreatic Islet Endoplasmic Reticulum and Cytokine Stress Responses Provides Insights into Type 2 Diabetes Genetics

finding: The rs4685264 T2D risk allele (G) was associated with increased chromatin accessibility at a cytokine-induced CRE, facilitating the binding of the transcription factor MAX, which may lead to upregulation of the putative effector gene GALNT15.
title: Comparative Multi-omic Mapping of Human Pancreatic Islet Endoplasmic Reticulum and Cytokine Stress Responses Provides Insights into Type 2 Diabetes Genetics

finding: The finding related to rs1805124 was that it was present in 10 out of 12 analyzed personal samples, and in the masked set, it was found in 16 out of 19 samples. The population allele frequency for rs1805124 was noted to be 23.96%, which indicated a low probability of masking and a high probability of introduction. Additionally, there was a zygosity change observed in one masked sample. This finding demonstrated the effectiveness of the masking technique particularly for alleles with low population frequencies, thus showcasing its significance in managing clinically relevant variants.
title: Privacy preserving storage of sequenced genomic data

finding: The study identified that the DRD3 rs6280 polymorphism (Ser9Gly) had a significant influence on functional connectivity and gray matter volume of the hippocampus in patients with first-episode, drug-naïve schizophrenia. This finding highlighted the potential role of this SNP in the neuroanatomical features associated with schizophrenia.
title: Genotypic and phenotypic consequences of domestication in dogs

finding: The SNP VEPH1/rs3911403-T was found to increase in frequency from sub-Saharan Africa to Latin America, indicating a potential role in immune response variations related to Zika congenital complications.
title: Hypothetical Human Immune Genome Complex Gradient May Help to Explain the Congenital Zika Symdrome Catastrophe in Brazil: A New Theory

finding: The SNP CD80/rs2629396-G was found to increase in frequency from sub-Saharan Africa to Latin America, potentially affecting host immune responses to viral infections.
title: Hypothetical Human Immune Genome Complex Gradient May Help to Explain the Congenital Zika Symdrome Catastrophe in Brazil: A New Theory

finding: The SNP rs6781009 was linked to cardiac electrophysiological traits, specifically found in strong linkage disequilibrium with lead SNPs of QRS complex, QRS duration, QT interval, and electrocardiographic traits. Notably, it was located within a stage-specific D80 enhancer that interacted with the promoter of the cardiac sodium channel gene SCN5A, a finding corroborated by similar results from circular chromosome conformation capture studies in human cardiac tissue.
title: 3D Chromatin Architecture Remodeling during Human Cardiomyocyte Differentiation Reveals A Role Of HERV-H In Demarcating Chromatin Domains

finding: The rs1554675 SNP associated with the EPHB1 gene was found to be a genome-wide significant locus correlated with ↑WS depression, demonstrated by a beta coefficient of 0.92 (95% CI: 0.63-1.21) and a p-value of 8.29 x 10^-10 in BMI-adjusted analyses.
title: Characterisation and Genetic Architecture of Major Depressive Disorder Subgroups Defined by Weight and Sleep Changes

finding: The rs1426041 SNP, linked to the CLSTN2 gene, was another genome-wide significant locus tied to ↑WS depression with a beta coefficient of 0.68 (95% CI: 0.48-0.88) and a p-value of 5.12 x 10^-11, also in analyses adjusted for BMI.
title: Characterisation and Genetic Architecture of Major Depressive Disorder Subgroups Defined by Weight and Sleep Changes

finding: The XPC gene polymorphism represented by A>C transition (rs2228001) resulting in a Lys939Gln change was associated with bladder cancer. This SNP was noted for its role in DNA damage recognition and was predictive of critical events in human bladder cancer carcinogenesis.
title: Association of Metabolic and DNA-repair gene polymorphisms with Longevity: a role for GSTT1, GSTP and XPC genes

finding: The common variant rs4586858 in TGFBR2 was associated with declined TGFBR2 expression, suggesting that repressed TGF-β signaling might be beneficial for longevity.
title: Longevity-associated SMAD3 non-coding centenarian variant impairs a cell-type specific enhancer to reduce inflammation

finding: The SNP rs13071246 was related to the study by Larson and Tuor (2021), which explored the deep learning classification of Cheatgrass invasion in the Western United States. This finding indicated that specific genetic markers could be associated with plant invasiveness and resilience, providing insights that could be valuable for restoration ecology and the management of seed procurement.
title: Not all seed transfer zones are created equal: Using fire history to identify seed needs in the Cold Deserts of the Western US

finding: The SNP rs1801282, located within the PPARG gene, was recognized as an established T2D risk variant associated with higher levels of Plasminogen Activator Inhibitor 1 (PAI-1) and insulin resistance.
title: Genetics of fasting indices of glucose homeostasis using GWIS unravels tight relationships with inflammatory markers

finding: The SNP rs13092255 was linked to the study by Ronca et al. in 2021, which found that Pentraxin 3 inhibits the angiogenic potential of multiple myeloma cells, indicating a possible role in therapeutic pathways related to Multiple Myeloma.
title: Comparison of Transcriptomic Changes in Younger and Older Multiple Myeloma Patients from the MMRF-CoMMpass Study RNA-Seq Data

finding: This SNP showed an inverse association with breast cancer, especially after exclusion from other genetic instruments, thereby indicating a protective effect of calcium.
title: Circulating concentrations of micro-nutrients and risk of breast cancer: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs12152448 was linked to foliar spectra and traits in the research by Girard et al. in 2020, which examined nitrogen deposition gradients in bog plants, highlighting its relevance to nutrient interactions in plant ecosystems.
title: Predicting leaf traits across functional groups using reflectance spectroscopy

finding: The SNP rs2228001, linked to cisplatin response/toxicity, showed varying frequencies in Ukrainians, emphasizing its importance in assessing cancer treatment efficacy in this population.
title: Genome Diversity in Ukraine

finding: The SNP rs1318814 was related to coronary artery disease (CAD) and blood pressure traits. This variant was intronic to the ZNF827 gene on chromosome 4 and overlapped with a regulatory element predominantly activated in coronary arteries and R-SMCs, lacking in TP-SMCs.
title: Genomic, transcriptomic and proteomic depiction of iPSC-derived smooth muscle cells as emerging cellular models for arterial diseases

finding: The presence of SNP rs13092263 was associated with the induction of long-term antitumor CD8+ T cell immunity as demonstrated in the study by Ferrantelli et al. (2021). This SNP was linked to enhanced immune response resulting from engineered extracellular vesicles, particularly highlighting the potential of these vesicles to enhance the effectiveness of CD8+ T cell immunity in combating various pathogens, including SARS-CoV-2.
title: Induction of SARS-CoV-2 N-specific CD8+ T cell immunity in lungs by engineered extracellular vesicles associates with strongly impaired viral replication

finding: The SNP rs3804640, located in an intron of the CD47 gene, showed a large, positive effect in the single SNP analysis relating bipolar disorder to smoking initiation and lifetime smoking. This SNP was noted for its significant association with the odds of developing bipolar disorder, indicating that it might play a role in the pathophysiology of the disorder by influencing smoking behaviors.
title: Smoking and the risk for bipolar disorder: causal evidence from a bidirectional Mendelian randomization study

finding: The variant rs2279829 at 3q24 was associated with both CSA and CV in the pars triangularis, postcentral, and supramarginal cortices. This SNP is located in the 3' UTR of the gene ZIC4, highlighting its potential role in these cortical measures.
title: Genetic Determinants of Cortical Structure (Thickness, Surface Area and Volumes) among Disease Free Adults in the CHARGE Consortium

finding: The SNP rs148648107 showed confirming results for modifier effects at the MLH1 region, reiterating the complex genetic landscape of Huntington's disease modifications.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The variant rs144287831 within the MLH1 locus was nominally associated with a later AO in MJD (P = 0.02, effect size = -0.98). This suggested that this variant may influence the progression of MJD.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies genetic factors that modify age at onset in Machado-Joseph disease

finding: Similarly, the variant rs1799977 in the MLH1 locus also showed nominal association with a later age at onset in MJD (P = 0.02, effect size = -0.98), indicating a possible role in modifying the onset of disease.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies genetic factors that modify age at onset in Machado-Joseph disease

finding: The SNP rs2336725 showed a 99.0% co-localization probability with RFT1, an enzyme implicated in protein N-glycosylation pathways, suggesting a significant association with height traits.
title: Multi-tissue analysis reveals short tandem repeats as ubiquitous regulators of gene expression and complex traits

finding: The SNP rs2581830 was established as the top associated SNP with height in both the eMERGE cohort and larger studies, demonstrating a significant correlation with imputed AC repeat number related to height.
title: Multi-tissue analysis reveals short tandem repeats as ubiquitous regulators of gene expression and complex traits

finding: SNP rs10936748, located in LOC105374224, was reported in the top 30 SNPs and linked to genes involved in AML pathways.
title: Iterative feature selection method to discover predictive variables and interactions for high-dimensional transplant genomic data

finding: The SNP rs11129640 was found to reside upstream of the Arpp21 gene and was identified in recent studies as being associated with entorhinal cortical thinning in Alzheimer's disease patients. This suggested a potential link between the SNP and morphological changes in neuronal populations, specifically in relation to dendritic structures and their alterations in various conditions.
title: Morphometric reconstructions atlas shows insult-driven plasticity in cortical VIP/ChAT interneurons

finding: The SNP rs7615206 was identified as having the strongest causal effect on reducing the risk of cleft lip/palate (CLP) in offspring, with a P-value of 0.00546. It is located in the MST1R gene, which encodes a receptor important in mechanical regulation of bone remodeling. The analysis suggested that European parents who carry this HPA-related SNP could reduce the risk of cleft palate in their offspring by at least 21%.
title: Filamin A mediates embryonical palatal fusion by linking mechanotransduction with β-Catenin/Smad2

finding: The SNP rs35081325 displayed the strongest association with severe COVID-19, with a p-value of 9.5e-50, indicating it was a significant positive original finding related to this phenotype.
title: A genetic variant protective for COVID-19 is inherited from Neanderthals

finding: The variant rs71327015, located inside the CCR9 gene, was reported to be under positive selection in South Asian populations, showcasing patterns associated with archaic ancestry.
title: Exploring adaptive introgression in modern human circadian rhythm genes

finding: The SNP rs1800734 was found to enhance DCLK3 expression through long-range interaction and promoted colorectal cancer progression. This finding highlighted the role of non-coding variants in gene expression regulation and their potential implications in cancer biology.
title: Rapid depletion of CTCF and cohesin proteins reveals dynamic features of chromosome architecture

finding: The variant rs1801282 (Pro12Ala) demonstrated an association with increased PPARG expression, reduced risk for diabetes, and lower circulating triglycerides. Importantly, this SNP also displayed a directional concordance with reduced albumin levels, consistent with phenotypic changes observed in HGFAC knockout mice, suggesting a conserved HGF-PPARγ signaling axis.
title: HGFAC is a ChREBP Regulated Hepatokine that Enhances Glucose and Lipid Homeostasis

finding: The rs11571842 variant at the CCK promoter created an activating TFDP1 or a repressive ZNF343 sequence, which corresponded to increased or decreased CCK expression, highlighting its regulatory role.
title: Functional dissection of complex and molecular trait variants at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The SNP rs2370964 on chromosome 3 was shown to interact with the promoter region of the distant gene CX3CR1. This interaction was associated with higher expression levels of CX3CR1 in the GM12878 cell line, and it was previously reported to contribute to the risk of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The findings from this study highlighted the potential of FusNet's predictive results to offer insights into disease mechanisms, particularly in the context of complex diseases.
title: Fusion Neural Network (FusNet) for predicting protein-mediated loops

finding: The SNP rs74737358, located in the XPC gene, was identified as a known pathogenic variant causing recessively inherited xeroderma pigmentosum (OMIM #278720) when inherited with a second pathogenic variant. It was found in UL sample S07, and its high allele frequency in the general population (approximately 0.31% in gnomAD v2.1.1) along with a variant allele frequency (VAF) of 0.560 indicated that this was likely a germline variant.
title: Targeted sequencing of FH-deficient uterine leiomyomas reveals biallelic inactivating somatic fumarase variants and allows characterization of missense variants

finding: The SNP rs13071585 was mentioned in the context of chromosomal aberrations in breast cancer by Privitera et al. (2021). It was linked to the framework for the cooperation of transcriptionally dysregulated genes, emphasizing its relevance in the study of breast cancer biology.
title: Marker-free characterization of single live circulating tumor cell full-length transcriptomes

finding: In the study, the oxytocin (OT) induced suppression of amygdala responses to fear faces was only significant in G-non-carriers (AA genotype). This effect was significant on the first day (p < 0.001, Cohen's d = 1.00) and also on the fifth day in participants who received OT every other day (p < 0.001, d = 1.41). The findings were particularly tied to the treatment effects of OT, indicating a strong genotype-dependent response in those with the AA genotype.
title: Oxytocin effects on brain and behavior are influenced by dose-frequency and receptor genotype: therapeutic implications

finding: The findings indicated that on the first day, OT-induced suppression of amygdala responses to fear faces was significant only in A-carriers (AA and AG genotypes, p = 0.001, d = 0.91), and it remained significant on the fifth day in the group that received OT every other day (p = 0.004, d = 0.81). Additionally, the treatment x genotype interaction for emotional intensity ratings was significant for rs2254298 (F(2, 105) = 6.25, p = 0.003), with post-hoc analyses showing a significant reduction in emotional intensity ratings in A-carriers on the fifth day (p < 0.001, d = 1.19). The alteration in behavioral responses was thus dependent on the genotype, highlighting the role of rs2254298 in mediating the effects of OT.
title: Oxytocin effects on brain and behavior are influenced by dose-frequency and receptor genotype: therapeutic implications

finding: The SNP rs9876026 was shown to be an sQTL for the gene TAMM41, affecting the binding site for the RNA-binding protein PRPF8. This provided insight into how this variant impacts splicing mechanisms by altering RBP interactions.
title: Identification and analysis of splicing quantitative trait loci across multiple tissues in the human genome

finding: This SNP was implicated in multiple phenotypes at a p-value less than 5×10⁻⁸, underscoring its relevance in genetic studies concerning metabolic traits and microbiome associations.
title: Large-scale association analyses identify host factors influencing human gut microbiome composition

finding: SNP rs9875578 demonstrated a clear result that indicated increased binding affinity of RBMX to the mutant lncRNA over the wild-type, suggesting a profound structural alteration.
title: Effect of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms on the structure of long noncoding RNAs and their interaction with RNA Binding Proteins

finding: SNP rs11130222 was linked to significant docking score changes when RBMX was docked, indicating structural disruptions and potential functional consequences.
title: Effect of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms on the structure of long noncoding RNAs and their interaction with RNA Binding Proteins

finding: The variant rs5186 was located in the 3' UTR of the AGTR1 gene and exhibited a higher frequency in Ashkenazi Jewish, Latino/Admixed American, and European (non-Finnish) populations (about 0.3) compared to South and East Asians and Africans/African Americans (less than 0.1). This variant was associated with an increased response to losartan in a study performed on a cohort of European ancestry.
title: A versatile and interoperable computational framework for the analysis and modeling of COVID-19 disease mechanisms

finding: The variant rs12721226 was identified as a missense variant with a very low frequency across populations (less than 0.01). The alternative allele (A) was associated with a decreased affinity to losartan and its metabolite EXP3174, which could impair the clinical efficacy of the drug. This finding was significant in the context of genomic variants impacting drug response in COVID-19 treatments.
title: A versatile and interoperable computational framework for the analysis and modeling of COVID-19 disease mechanisms

finding: The SNP rs12330631, a conserved SNP, displayed a PIP of 0.96 for BMI under the PolyFun + SuSiE framework compared to a PIP of 0.25 with SuSiE, highlighting enhanced resolution in identifying causal variants for this trait.
title: Functionally-informed fine-mapping and polygenic localization of complex trait heritability

finding: The SNP rs2270894, also a promoter SNP, was fine-mapped with a PIP of 0.96 for platelet count using PolyFun + SuSiE, contrasting with a PIP of 0.19 with SuSiE alone, which underscores the improvement in identifying likely causal variants.
title: Functionally-informed fine-mapping and polygenic localization of complex trait heritability

finding: This SNP showed significant differential allelic expression (DAE) with 57% of heterozygotes demonstrating a preferential expression pattern, indicating its potential role in modulating PIK3CA expression in breast cancer.
title: Preferential allelic expression of PIK3CA mutations is frequent in breast cancer and is prognostically significant

finding: Demonstrated DAE in a smaller fraction (14%) of heterozygotes, linking it to allelic expression imbalance, which highlights its potential role in breast tumorigenesis.
title: Preferential allelic expression of PIK3CA mutations is frequent in breast cancer and is prognostically significant

finding: This SNP also displayed DAE with 14% of heterozygotes preferentially expressing one allele, suggesting its involvement in the regulation of PIK3CA expression in breast cancer.
title: Preferential allelic expression of PIK3CA mutations is frequent in breast cancer and is prognostically significant

finding: Showed DAE in 14% of heterozygotes, contributing to the allelic expression imbalance of PIK3CA which is significant in the context of breast cancer.
title: Preferential allelic expression of PIK3CA mutations is frequent in breast cancer and is prognostically significant

finding: Identified as a strong candidate for being a cis-regulatory SNP, significantly associated with DAE at rs12488074, and linked to total PIK3CA expression in cancer, highlighting its regulatory importance.
title: Preferential allelic expression of PIK3CA mutations is frequent in breast cancer and is prognostically significant

finding: Part of the group that showed unilateral DAE, contributing to a preferential expression pattern of the same allele, which underscores its functional significance in PIK3CA regulation.
title: Preferential allelic expression of PIK3CA mutations is frequent in breast cancer and is prognostically significant

finding: This SNP was part of a study that applied UAS multispectral imagery at different physiological stages to optimize yield prediction and enhance resource use in corn.
title: Deep Learning-Based High-Throughput Phenotyping Of Maize (Zea mays L.) Tasseling From Uas Imagery Across Environments

finding: The index variant rs1920644 was associated with ADHD across the lifespan, marking it as a significant finding.
title: Shared genetic background between children and adults with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The polymorphism rs3732378 (p.Thr280Met) in CX3CR1 was linked to hypothyroidism (p=1.3×10⁻⁷, OR=1.07, 95% CI: 1.05-1.10) as well as monocyte counts and percentages.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: rs1466684 (p.Thr179Met) in P2RY13 was associated with neutrophil count (p=1.68×10⁻⁶, β=0.016, 95% CI: 0.0094-0.023), marking a first report of this association.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs13076750 was associated with an alternate splice form of a rare exon within the gene, extending the exon length, and this finding was supported by q-RT-PCR and RNAseq analysis.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: The SNP rs2999046 was located within a predicted enhancer region related to the EEFSEC gene on chromosome 3q21.3. Its association with endometriosis was supported by mQTL analysis indicating that it influenced expression through sweeping chromatin interactions in endometrial samples.
title: Global Endometrial DNA Multi-omics Analysis Reveals Insights into mQTL Regulation and Associated Endometriosis Disease Risk

finding: The SNP rs6787229 was linked to MYL3 gene expression and UACR. It demonstrated high colocalization probability (SCP = 0.79) with podocyte-specific open chromatin peak, indicating its role in kidney function.
title: Mapping genomic regulation of kidney disease and traits through high-resolution and interpretable eQTLs

finding: The SNP rs3774729 within the ATXN7 gene was linked to Spinocerebellar ataxia type 7 (SCA7) in South African patients. This polymorphism showed a high prevalence due to a founder effect among patients of Black African ethnic origin, with approximately 43% of individuals being heterozygous. This provided an ideal target for developing allele-specific silencing therapies and suggested broader applicability in other Southern African populations.
title: Molecular and electrophysiological features of spinocerebellar ataxia type seven in induced pluripotent stem cells

finding: SNP rs10433615 was found to have a concordant direction of effect in both regional CT and SA related to bipolar disorder (BD). A higher genetic vulnerability for BD correlated with greater CT in the medial supplementary motor cortex and increased SA in the insula and medial prefrontal cortex.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs60135207 was associated with both CT and SA for schizophrenia (SCZ), with HMPs of 0.004 for CT and 9.04×10^-4 for SA. It reflects a genetic relationship between SCZ and structural brain changes.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs6789751 exhibited a positive association with increased CT for ADHD, supporting its role in influencing cortical structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs4367080 indicated significant associations with lower SA of the parietal operculum in ADHD, showcasing its role in structural brain variations.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs56842404 was associated with greater CT in the inferior temporal cortex for ASD, underscoring its genetic relevance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs2083180 linked to greater surface area in the temporal pole for psychotic disorders demonstrated genetic relevance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The rs60939770 SNP was identified as a significant genetic variant associated with the proportion of CCR5+CD4+ mTreg cells in people living with HIV (PLHIV) and healthy controls (HC). It showed a strong genome-wide significance with a P-value of 4.29 × 10^-16 in PLHIV and 3.18 × 10^-10 in HC. The genetic analysis revealed that individuals carrying at least one rs60939770-G allele had a higher proportion of CCR5+CD4+ mTreg cells compared to those homozygous for the A allele, indicating a potential role in modulating CCR5 expression.
title: Host genetic variants regulates CCR5 expression on immune cells: a study in people living with HIV and healthy controls

finding: The rs11574435 SNP was associated with the mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) of CCR5 in CD4+ and CD8+ T cell subsets in both PLHIV and HC with a significant P-value < 5 × 10^-8. The CC genotype was linked to higher CCR5 MFI levels compared to the TC genotype in these T cell populations. Importantly, rs11574435 was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with the CCR5d32 mutation, affecting CCR5 expression and potentially influencing HIV susceptibility.
title: Host genetic variants regulates CCR5 expression on immune cells: a study in people living with HIV and healthy controls

finding: The rs1015164 SNP was associated with both the proportions of CCR5-expressing cells and their MFI in CD4+ mTreg subsets from both PLHIV and HC. The evidence suggested that individuals with the rs1015164-A allele displayed a higher proportion of CCR5+CD4+ mTreg cells compared to those with the G allele, highlighting its role in regulating CCR5 surface expression.
title: Host genetic variants regulates CCR5 expression on immune cells: a study in people living with HIV and healthy controls

finding: The rs71327064 SNP was significantly associated with CCR5 MFI in CD4+ TEMRA cells, with a P-value < 6.22 × 10^-9. This SNP, although affecting CCR5 expression levels in a differentiated subset, appeared to have different regulatory characteristics compared to other variants analyzed.
title: Host genetic variants regulates CCR5 expression on immune cells: a study in people living with HIV and healthy controls

finding: The rs35677470 polymorphism in the DNASE1L3 gene was associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic sclerosis. This association provided structural biological insights into how genetic variants may influence susceptibility to these autoimmune diseases.
title: Activation of the cGAS-STING innate immune response in cells with deficient mitochondrial topoisomerase TOP1MT

finding: The V78M mutation (rs2271496) in SIDT1 had a clinically reported impact on exogenous small RNA uptake. This SNP was located on the beta-strand within the extracellular domain (ECD) of SIDT1, which suggested that it could disrupt the intricate interaction networks among neighboring amino acids. Consequently, this alteration was believed to reduce the stability of the ECD, impairing SIDT1's ability to bind and absorb nucleic acids.
title: Cryo-EM structures of human SID-1 transmembrane family proteins and implications for their low-pH-dependent RNA transport activity

finding: The SNP rs6808074, located over 200kb upstream of the CCR2 promoter, was associated with expression levels of CCR2 in classical monocytes. It likely perturbed the function of a distal enhancer that regulates CCR2 expression, suggesting a significant role of the CCR2 pathway in COVID-19 pathogenesis.
title: COVID-19 genetic risk variants are associated with expression of multiple genes in diverse immune cell types

finding: The SNP rs9289231 was associated with serum Kalirin levels in the context of early-onset coronary artery disease, as established in the referenced literature. This connection was characterized by a polymorphism in the KALRN gene that suggested a potential role in cardiovascular pathology, which is relevant in the landscape of vascular-related cognitive impairment.
title: Proteome profiling of brain vessels in a mouse model of cerebrovascular pathology

finding: The SNP rs17279437 was identified as associated with CSF betaine levels and was closely located to the SLC6A20 gene, which is involved in betaine transport. This finding highlighted a significant connection between this SNP and the metabolite betaine in cerebrospinal fluid.
title: Cerebrospinal fluid metabolomics identifies 19 brain-related phenotype associations

finding: The SNP rs35170539 showed a strong association with oxalate levels in CSF, with a p-value of 5.64×10⁻¹¹. This association was notably stronger in CSF compared to previously reported findings in blood, thus pointing to unique genetic loci that control oxalate levels in CSF.
title: Cerebrospinal fluid metabolomics identifies 19 brain-related phenotype associations

finding: This SNP was associated with CD8 T-cells and T-central memory cell immune signatures, highlighting its relevance in T-cell function and immune response.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP, located near the AC022336.2 gene, was involved in associations driven by binary traits indicative of coronary heart disease, exhibiting high genetic correlations.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: At the GLYCTK gene, the meta-analysis identified signal 1 (rs610060) associated with serine degradation and fructose metabolism. This SNP was significant in studies conducted with Finnish populations.
title: Adipose tissue eQTL meta-analysis reveals the contribution of allelic heterogeneity to gene expression regulation and cardiometabolic traits

finding: The second signal identified at the GLYCTK gene was rs11711914, which was significant in studies involving non-Finnish Europeans. This SNP indicated an alternative regulatory signal related to the same gene with implications for metabolism.
title: Adipose tissue eQTL meta-analysis reveals the contribution of allelic heterogeneity to gene expression regulation and cardiometabolic traits

finding: At the ADIPOQ gene, the meta-analysis found signal 1 (rs35469083) associated with adipose tissue gene expression, identified in the context of GWAS for cardiometabolic traits.
title: Adipose tissue eQTL meta-analysis reveals the contribution of allelic heterogeneity to gene expression regulation and cardiometabolic traits

finding: Signal 2 at the ADIPOQ gene was represented by rs143257534, detected in conditional analyses unique to certain population studies, demonstrating a link to adipose biology.
title: Adipose tissue eQTL meta-analysis reveals the contribution of allelic heterogeneity to gene expression regulation and cardiometabolic traits

finding: The SNP rs35081325 was identified as part of the 3p21.31 locus associated with susceptibility to severe COVID-19. This locus was replicated in multiple GWAS studies, underscoring its relevance in understanding the genetic risk for severe respiratory failure related to COVID-19.
title: Association of CXCR6 with COVID-19 severity: Delineating the host genetic factors in transcriptomic regulation

finding: The SNP rs34068335 showed strong colocalization with the association of severe COVID-19 in the GWAS dataset. A significant p-value of 5.02 × 10^-22 was reported, and this SNP was also linked to an increased percentage of monocytes in a blood-trait GWAS.
title: Association of CXCR6 with COVID-19 severity: Delineating the host genetic factors in transcriptomic regulation

finding: SNP rs10490770 was predicted to alter the binding affinity of the transcription factor RELA. This SNP was identified in a high LD region associated with significant eQTLs for the CXCR6 gene, which plays a role in TRM cell regulation.
title: Association of CXCR6 with COVID-19 severity: Delineating the host genetic factors in transcriptomic regulation

finding: SNP rs67959919 was associated with the transcription factor SP1 binding affinity changes and was found in high LD with several significant eQTLs of CXCR6, thereby suggesting its potential role in the regulation of CXCR6 expression.
