title: Association of CXCR6 with COVID-19 severity: Delineating the host genetic factors in transcriptomic regulation

finding: SNP rs35896106 was part of the significant eQTLs associated with the expression of CXCR6 in whole blood. This SNP indicated a strong association with severe COVID-19 through its involvement in controlling CXCR6 expression.
title: Association of CXCR6 with COVID-19 severity: Delineating the host genetic factors in transcriptomic regulation

finding: SNP rs17713054 was also mentioned as a significant eQTL associated with CXCR6 expression, highlighting its potential regulatory role in the context of severe COVID-19.
title: Association of CXCR6 with COVID-19 severity: Delineating the host genetic factors in transcriptomic regulation

finding: The SNP rs13092263 was related to the effectiveness of CD8+ T cell immunity induced by engineered extracellular vesicles (EVs) in the study by Ferrantelli et al. (2021). This SNP was found to be associated with long-term antitumor CD8+ T cell immunity, highlighting its potential as a biomarker for immune response in the context of SARS-CoV-2 infection. The study demonstrated that the presence of certain genotypes potentially influenced the generation and functionality of SARS-CoV-2-specific CD8+ T lymphocytes, which were analyzed in terms of their polyfunctionality and capacity to develop resident memory in lung tissues.
title: Strong SARS-CoV-2 N-specific CD8+ T immunity induced by engineered extracellular vesicles associates with protection from lethal infection in mice

finding: The study found an extremely high frequency of the AADAC SNP rs1803155 (AADAC*2 allele) at approximately 99.9% in the Peruvian population when compared to other populations such as European American, African American, Japanese, and Korean. This variant is significant because it involves a nonsynonymous change (V281I) in the coding region, which may influence the metabolism of the anti-tuberculosis drug Rifampicin.
title: Allelic and Genotypic Frequencies of NAT2, CYP2E1 and AADAC genes in a cohort of Peruvian Tuberculosis Patients

finding: The SNP rs9856661 was associated with a p-value of 6.46 × 10-9, adding to the list of novel signals of selection introduced by this study.
title: Scalable probabilistic PCA for large-scale genetic variation data

finding: The SNP rs182766826 was linked to a mutation A214G in the neuromodulin protein (P17677-2), which is associated with nerve growth. This variant peptide was supported by 20 reliable peptide-spectrum matches (PSMs).
title: Quality control of variant peptides identified through proteogenomics- catching the (un)usual suspects

finding: The SNP rs577083604 corresponded to a mutation A219V in the neuromodulin protein (P17677-2) involved in nerve growth, discovered through analysis of the variant peptide QADVPAAVTAAGATTPVAEDAAAK with support from 20 reliable PSMs.
title: Quality control of variant peptides identified through proteogenomics- catching the (un)usual suspects

finding: The SNP rs978216738 was associated with a mutation A127S in the Synapsin-2 protein (Q92777-2). The variant peptide VLLVVDEPHADWSK had 13 confident PSMs supporting this finding.
title: Quality control of variant peptides identified through proteogenomics- catching the (un)usual suspects

finding: The SNP rs2172257 was associated with a mutation A385T in ribosomal oxygenase 2 protein (Q8IUF8-4), significant for cell growth and survival, and was part of a finding within variant peptides.
title: Quality control of variant peptides identified through proteogenomics- catching the (un)usual suspects

finding: The SNP rs13096789 was associated with the KBTBD8 gene, which exhibited an extreme positive selection signal in the Triqui (TRQ) population in Oaxaca. This gene's encoded protein is involved in ubiquitination and has been linked to idiopathic short stature, relevant given the extremely low average stature of the TRQ population. The variant resulted in a nonsynonymous change classified as 'possibly damaging' by PolyPhen.
title: Population history and gene divergence in Native Mexicans inferred from 76 human exomes

finding: The rs9841287 SNP at the CHL1 locus was associated with fasting insulin concentrations. Additionally, it was identified as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for the CHL1 and CHL1-AS1 genes, demonstrating a beta coefficient of 0.29 and 0.27, respectively, with p-values indicating statistical significance (P = 0.028 and 0.04). This finding highlighted its potential role in the regulation of gene expression pertinent to insulin dynamics.
title: Islet Gene View - a tool to facilitate islet research

finding: The SNP rs116415933, an intronic SNP within the CAD-targeted gene PPP2R3A, served as a significant driver in the TPOT models for CAD predictions. It was reported as an eQTL for the IL20RB gene in various tissues and was part of a set of SNPs associated with early-onset myocardial infarction.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs139138366 was determined to be intronic within the CAD druggable gene PPP2R3A. Along with rs116415933, it contributed to the model outputs in identifying CAD cases, although its specific impact compared to other SNPs was noted to be on par with that of rs188650245.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs35773450, like rs139138366, was intronic within the gene PPP2R3A and demonstrated connections with the CAD phenotype through its association with IL20RB.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs188650245, an intronic SNP in PPP2R3A, was indicated as an eQTL for IL20RB and played a significant role in clustering predictions for CAD cases in the TPOT analysis.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: This SNP at the IGF2BP2 locus had a high TOA (0.96) and was associated with eQTL data implicating IGF2BP2 in influencing T2D risk through its role in islet function.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs17600346 in the TRAIL gene was associated with colocalization signals affecting total cholesterol, triglyceride levels, and various white blood cell and platelet traits, indicating its potential relevance in immune response and hematopoiesis.
title: Genetic colocalization atlas points to common regulatory sites and genes for hematopoietic traits and hematopoietic contributions to disease phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs77323602 was associated with favoring MLCK1 expression in endothelial cells. This was linked to the potential regulatory role of heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein A1 (hnRNPA1), suggesting that variations in this SNP could influence the relative expression levels of MLCK variants in health and disease contexts.
title: Distinct steady-state properties and TNF responses of epithelial long myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) splice variants

finding: The SNP rs147245669 was suggested to favor MLCK2 expression in endothelial cells, which may reflect the capacity of hnRNPA1 to promote the splicing that leads to MLCK2 transcript production. This provides insight into the potential differential regulation of MLCK1 and MLCK2 in various tissues and under different physiological conditions.
title: Distinct steady-state properties and TNF responses of epithelial long myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) splice variants

finding: The study found that the oxytocin (OT) effect on self-other distinction was influenced by the oxytocin receptor (OXTR) genotype, specifically noting that OT only modulated task decision time in individuals who were carriers of the G allele for rs53576. This association related to how OT impacted self-referential cognitive processing during an fMRI task, indicating a genetic basis for individual differences in response to OT.
title: The role of oxytocin in modulating self-other distinction in human brain: a pharmacological fMRI study

finding: The SNP rs6804368 was significantly associated with levels of acetylcarnosine at the GADL1 locus, with a strong association p=8.17e-21. This association suggests a relationship between this SNP and various blood metabolites related to the effects of carnosine peptides.
title: GADL1 is a multifunctional decarboxylase with tissue-specific roles in β-alanine and carnosine production

finding: The SNP rs17026688 showed the strongest association (p=5.50e-37) with response to lithium in bipolar disorder within intron 6 of the GADL1 gene. This highlights a crucial role of this region in influencing treatment response, although the findings were not replicated in other clinical samples.
title: GADL1 is a multifunctional decarboxylase with tissue-specific roles in β-alanine and carnosine production

finding: In contrast, the variant rs113010081, identified as a proxy for the CCR5-delta 32 variant, showed proper genotyping performance with a low missingness rate of 0.08% and no deviation from HWE (p-value = 0.369). This study highlighted that while rs62625034 had genotyping problems, rs113010081 provided reliable genetic data.
title: Reported CCR5-∆32 deviation from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is explained by poor genotyping of rs62625034

finding: The SNP rs867234 was associated with strong EBNA2 allele-dependent binding in GM12878 cells. This variant was located within the promoter of the upregulated gene CD80, which showed an 8-fold increase in gene expression. Although rs867234 was not heterozygous in Ramos, IB4, or Mutu cells, EBNA2 binding was still observed in these cells, suggesting its potential relevance in the genetic mechanisms influencing vitiligo.
title: Epstein-Barr virus nuclear antigen 2 (EBNA2) extensively rewires the human chromatin landscape at autoimmune risk loci

finding: The rs13324341 SNP at the MRAS locus created a MEF2 binding site and correlated with increased expression, affirming its role in CAD.
title: Cell-specific chromatin landscape of human coronary artery resolves regulatory mechanisms of disease risk

finding: The SNP rs143835330 was described as a missense mutation in the Kalrn gene, leading to a proline to threonine amino acid change (Kalrn-PT), which was first identified in individuals with schizophrenia. This mutation conferred enhanced activation of RhoA in neuronal dendrites and was linked to reduced dendritic length and complexity in layer 3 pyramidal neurons of the primary auditory cortex in mice. The findings suggested that the Kalrn-PT variant represents a mild genetic vulnerability that interacts with normal adolescent development, contributing to the emergence of neuropsychiatric pathology.
title: A Kalirin Missense Mutation Enhances Dendritic RhoA Signaling and Leads to Regression of Cortical Dendritic Arbors Across Development

finding: The SNP rs12152448 demonstrated significant associations with pigmentation and water balance traits in drought-treated saplings. The genetic cluster variations indicated that this SNP could be leveraged to understand functional intraspecific variation in drought response, highlighting its relevance in assessing adaptive mechanisms in the context of climate change stressors.
title: Leaf spectroscopy reveals drought response variation in Fagus sylvatica saplings from across the species’ range

finding: The SNP rs56387622 was identified as having a tumor-specific cis-eQTL effect on the expression of the chemokine receptor gene CCR3, which was previously associated with breast cancer outcomes, especially in luminal-like subtypes. Analysis showed that as estimated tumor purity increased, the cancer risk allele C at rs56387622 had a strong negative effect on CCR3 expression. This finding highlighted the potential relevance of CCR3 in breast cancer pathways and demonstrated the utility of the DeCompress method in identifying compartment-specific associations.
title: DeCompress: tissue compartment deconvolution of targeted mRNA expression panels using compressed sensing

finding: The rs149617956 variant was identified in the MITF gene in the small family UF10. It changed the amino acid from glutamic acid to lysine and was reported as pathogenic/likely pathogenic in Clinvar, ranking at position 782 (99.14 percentile).
title: A Weights-based variant ranking pipeline for familial complex disorders

finding: The SNP rs13071665 was associated with the regulation of X chromosome inactivation through its interaction with the chromatin regulator SPEN/SHARP, as reported in the study by Giaimo et al. (2021). This finding highlighted the role of SPEN in mediating the effects of XIST during the early developmental stages before XCI occurs.
title: XIST dampens X chromosome activity in a SPEN-dependent manner during early human development

finding: SNP rs388649 was associated with Horvath-EAA and linked to the expression of ESYT3, which plays a role in lipid transport and metabolism. It was identified as a potential expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) in various tissues.
title: A meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies of epigenetic age acceleration

finding: The SNP rs343320 caused a protein-coding change resulting in His262Tyr in the PLSCR1 gene. This variant exhibited a hypomorphic effect, leading to increased susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection in cell culture. It was identified as a potential causative candidate for severe COVID-19 outcomes due to its dominant effect observed in both ectopic expression systems and patient-derived heterozygous cells.
title: A Genome-Wide Arrayed CRISPR Screen Reveals PLSCR1 as an Intrinsic Barrier to SARS-CoV-2 Entry

finding: The SNP rs13061440 was linked to the function of CTLA-4 in regulatory T cells, which plays a pivotal role in cancer immunotherapy, suggesting its relevance in shaping immune responses in cancer.
title: Manipulating the EphB4-ephrinB2 axis to reduce metastasis in HNSCC

finding: The rs137854888 SNP was identified as a causative mutation in the DNAJC19 gene associated with dilated cardiomyopathy with ataxia syndrome (DCMA) in an isolated Hutterite population. This intronic pathogenic variant led to abnormal splicing and produced a truncated, non-functional DNAJC19 protein. The study demonstrated that patient iPSCs carried this mutation, confirming its role in the disease. The mutation caused significant mitochondrial fragmentation in iPSC-CMs, which was reversible upon treatment with the mitochondrially-targeted peptide SS-31.
title: Reversible Mitochondrial Fragmentation in iPSC-Derived Cardiomyocytes from Children with DCMA, a Mitochondrial Cardiomyopathy

finding: The common variant rs62262671 at 3p21.31 was part of the identified novel loci associated with prostate cancer, indicating its importance in the genetic landscape of PrCa as assessed in the large meta-analysis.
title: Association Study of Over 200,000 Subjects Detects Novel Rare Variants, Functional Elements, and Polygenic Architecture of Prostate Cancer Susceptibility

finding: The TIMP4 rs3755724 SNP was associated with susceptibility to focal epilepsy, indicating potential genetic factors affecting seizure disorders.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs9898 was identified as a missense variant causing a change in the histidine-rich glycoprotein (HRG) from proline to serine. Its association with the antibody profile HPA045005 was confirmed with a significance of P = 2.35 × 10−97. This SNP was linked to higher levels of HRG in the blood, and HRG levels were consistently associated with increased all-cause mortality (HR = 1.25 per standard deviation increase). However, rs9898 itself was not directly associated with mortality (P = 0.69).
title: Levels of histidine-rich glycoprotein variants in human blood are associated to chronological age and predict mortality

finding: The SNP rs1042464, located in the HRG gene, was found to be strongly associated with the antibody profile BSI0137 (P < 1 × 10−300). It was among the four non-synonymous SNPs linked to HPA045005, showing a contrary relationship as compared to rs9898, confirming its significance in HRG levels and potentially influencing the associated mortality through differential affinities.
title: Levels of histidine-rich glycoprotein variants in human blood are associated to chronological age and predict mortality

finding: The lead SNP rs9862795 was identified as reaching genome-wide significance in association with irritability and mania. It was found to be in moderate-to-high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with other SNPs previously associated with educational attainment, intelligence, and depressed affect. This suggests a shared genetic underpinning between these phenotypes and emphasizes the SNP's relevance in understanding the genetic architecture of psychiatric conditions.
title: Not just one p: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: The intronic variant rs12714757 was significantly associated with CAD risk in both European and East Asian populations, indicating a genetic component affecting CAD susceptibility. Its association was linked with the transcription factor MITF's influence on lysosome function and autophagy.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: SNP rs6772383 was found to disrupt a TEAD1-binding site, which led to decreased MITF expression in macrophages. The risk T allele was implicated as being protective against atherosclerosis through its observed effects on MITF expression.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs3732765 was identified as the lead QTL SNP associated with the gene P2RY12, with its genotype significantly decreasing P2RY12 expression. It colocalized with the MED12L Parkinson’s Disease locus and was proposed to contribute to disease risk through this downregulation.
title: Atlas of genetic effects in human microglia transcriptome across brain regions, aging and disease pathologies

finding: The SNP rs11707416 was recognized as the lead GWAS SNP at the MED12L locus and was a consensus causal SNP in a fine-mapping analysis, being in perfect linkage disequilibrium with rs3732765. It suggested P2RY12 as the causal gene influencing Parkinson’s disease risk.
title: Atlas of genetic effects in human microglia transcriptome across brain regions, aging and disease pathologies

finding: The variant rs35044562 was reported as a major risk factor for severe COVID-19 symptoms. It was highlighted in subsequent Meta-GWAS studies and linked to Neanderthal heritage. This variant exhibited a better classification scheme for risk, particularly in African populations where its average probability to retain the causal allele was notably higher compared to the lead variant rs11385942.
title: COVID-19 genetic risk and Neanderthals: A case study highlighting the importance of scrutinizing diversity

finding: As a lead variant in a subsequent Meta-GWAS comparing hospitalized COVID-19 patients to population controls, rs67959919 was recognized as significant in identifying genetic risk factors aligned with severe COVID-19 symptoms. Its association emphasized the genetic divergence in risk profiles among different populations.
title: COVID-19 genetic risk and Neanderthals: A case study highlighting the importance of scrutinizing diversity

finding: This variant was identified in a recent GWAS by 23andMe as a lead variant for genetic risk assessment of severe COVID-19. It was recognized as part of a credible set of 20 variants indicating a shared risk signal among various populations, emphasizing the need to improve risk classification methods in non-European cohorts.
title: COVID-19 genetic risk and Neanderthals: A case study highlighting the importance of scrutinizing diversity

finding: The SNP rs12496730 was identified as a trans pQTL associated with levels of Siglec-9, demonstrating an effect size of -0.68. This SNP was marked as a positive finding, signifying its role in the regulation of protein levels.
title: Genetic and epigenetic architectures of neurological protein biomarkers in the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936

finding: The SNP rs35004449 was noted as a trans pQTL associated with NEP levels, exhibiting an effect size that indicated its relevance. Furthermore, it was associated with altered methylation levels at multiple CpG sites, grounding its identifications as a positive finding in the context of neurological disease.
title: Genetic and epigenetic architectures of neurological protein biomarkers in the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936

finding: The SNP rs13071276 was reported in the study by Ellenburg et al. (2021) that focused on detecting desert locust breeding grounds through satellite-assisted modeling. This SNP played a role in understanding the genetic factors affecting locust distribution and breeding in relation to environmental changes.
title: A framework for modelling desert locust population dynamics and large-scale dispersal

finding: The proline12/alanine gene polymorphism (rs1801282) in the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ) was found to be associated with psoriasis and obesity in Egyptian patients, indicating a potential role in the development of psoriatic lesions through its influence on inflammatory and immunomodulatory pathways.
title: The Model of PPARγ Downregulated Signaling in Psoriasis

finding: The study found a significant association between the SNP rs4683026 and the levels of Tetranectin, a protein secreted by the lung, muscle, spleen, and adipose tissue. Individuals with the CC genotype exhibited the highest protein levels, which decreased with fewer C alleles. This finding provided insights into how genetic variation influenced protein expression in healthy individuals.
title: Facets of individual-specific health signatures determined from longitudinal plasma proteome profiling

finding: The SNP rs13963 was identified as a perfect linkage disequilibrium (LD) proxy for rs4683026, with implications for protein isoform expression. It was linked to two proteoforms of Tetranectin, with the Gly106 isoform favored over the Ser106 isoform depending on the genotype, highlighting the impact of genetic variation on protein forms.
title: Facets of individual-specific health signatures determined from longitudinal plasma proteome profiling

finding: Found to be interesting as a GWAS hit with a P-imputed_1000G of 6.54×10^-6, this SNP was more expressed in biopsies affected by CL.
title: A genome-wide association study highlights a regulatory role for IFNG-AS1 contributing to cutaneous leishmaniasis in Brazil

finding: The SNP rs36016914 on chromosome 3 was associated with the regional grey matter volume concerning the lateral globus pallidus.
title: Genetic signatures of human brain structure: A comparison between GWAS and relatedness-based regression

finding: The SNP rs9882746 on chromosome 3 was linked to the inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus.
title: Genetic signatures of human brain structure: A comparison between GWAS and relatedness-based regression

finding: This SNP was found to be associated with several metabolic factors.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP was associated with atopic dermatitis in East Asian populations.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP was identified as part of a COVID-19 risk core haplotype inherited from Neanderthals. It was specifically found in samples from Campinas, indicating its possible association with increased risk or severity of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Genetic variability in COVID-19-related genes in the Brazilian population

finding: This SNP appeared in the COVID-19 risk core haplotype and was present only in samples from Ribeirão Preto and the BIPMed dataset, suggesting a potential link to COVID-19 infection rates or outcomes.
title: Genetic variability in COVID-19-related genes in the Brazilian population

finding: Identified as part of the COVID-19 risk core haplotype inherited from Neanderthals, this SNP was found in Campinas and the ABraOM dataset, implying its relevance in influencing the COVID-19 infection response.
title: Genetic variability in COVID-19-related genes in the Brazilian population

finding: This SNP was associated with the COVID-19 risk core haplotype and was present in the ABraOM dataset, indicative of its potential influence on COVID-19 infection or severity.
title: Genetic variability in COVID-19-related genes in the Brazilian population

finding: Also part of the COVID-19 risk core haplotype inherited from Neanderthals, this SNP was found in the ABraOM dataset, highlighting its possible significance in the context of SARS-CoV-2 infection risk.
title: Genetic variability in COVID-19-related genes in the Brazilian population

finding: The SNP rs1801282 was highlighted in a meta-analysis that examined its association with GDM across different geographic populations, affirming its role as a genetic variant of interest in GDM risk.
title: Genome-Wide Polygenic Risk Scores and Prediction of Gestational Diabetes in South Asian Women

finding: This SNP was associated with various lymphomas and cancers, showing a significant correspondence with allele-specific methylation patterns.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: Noted for its implications in neuropsychiatric traits, this SNP demonstrated connections with significant transcriptional changes.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This SNP was found to be associated with platelet volume through the LOF burden analysis of the gene <italic>KALRN</italic>, thereby supporting its role in hematologic traits.
title: Whole exome sequencing and characterization of coding variation in 49,960 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs11922153 had the highest posterior probability for association with pulse rate at the GNB4 locus, also shown to be in high LD with previously identified index SNPs related to the same trait.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The SNP rs7612445 was identified as an index SNP related to pulse rate, demonstrating its association with the GNB4 locus and implicating its role in regulating cardiac function.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The SNP rs13071258 was identified in the A block, which was significantly associated with increased risk for COVID-19 severity, exhibiting a median p-value of 2.32 × 10^-26 and a median effect size of 0.42.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: Similar to rs13071258, the SNP rs13068572 was part of the A block, also significantly associated with COVID-19 severity, contributing to the overall increased risk.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: The SNP rs17282391 was located in the B block and showed significant association with COVID-19 severity, with a median p-value of 1.94 × 10^-9 and a median effect size of 0.28.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: This SNP was identified as a trans-eQTL affecting multiple response genes, of which some are differentially expressed in lung tissues, hinting at its role in the host response to COVID-19.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: The rs13098911 variant acted as a trans-eQTL with significant involvement in altering gene expression related to COVID-19 response, supporting its role in severity outcomes.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: In the study, rs35454877 was implicated in down-regulation of CCR5, being one of the four emVars that met all criteria for potential causal variants linked to COVID-19 severity.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: Located in LD Block A, rs71327024 is suggested to regulate CCR1 and was associated with COVID-19 severity based on significant GWAS findings.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: This SNP is likely involved in the regulation of CCR1 and was recognized as a significant variant contributing to COVID-19 severity.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: The evidence supports that rs34041956 regulates CCR1, fitting into the profile of variants associated with greater risk of severe COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Regulatory dissection of the severe COVID-19 risk locus introgressed by Neanderthals

finding: The rs2177336-T allele was found to correlate with increased MUC20 expression in SARS-CoV-2-stimulated CD4+ T cells and lower COVID-19 susceptibility, suggesting its role in contemporary adaptive immune responses.
title: Environmental and genetic drivers of population differences in SARS-CoV-2 immune responses

finding: The SNP was located within a putative microglia-specific intronic enhancer of the STAB1 gene, predicted to disrupt a KLF4 binding site, suggesting a role in microglial gene expression relevant to Parkinson's disease.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: This SNP disrupted a predicted CTCFL binding site within the WDR6 gene promoter and showed clear allelic imbalance across multiple bulk ATAC-seq samples, indicating its potential functional effect.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs9877502 located at chr3:190,669,518 was associated with alterations in hippocampal subfield volumes, with the G allele linked to increased volumes in CA1-3 and decreased in other subfields such as the subiculum and presubiculum. This SNP had not been previously related to hippocampal volumes but had associations with risks for Alzheimer’s disease and cognitive decline, thus indicating its relevance in neurogenesis and cognitive function.
title: A fast non-parametric test of association for multiple traits

finding: The SNP rs9985399, located within the MYRIP gene, was reported to be associated with brain processing speed in the Lothian birth cohort. Brain processing speed is crucial for cognitive function and is often compromised in psychiatric illnesses such as schizophrenia and depression, indicating its relevance to the major depressive disorder (MDD) phenotype.
title: SNP and Haplotype Regional Heritability Mapping (SNHap-RHM): joint mapping of common and rare variation affecting complex traits

finding: The SNP rs6599077, also located in the MYRIP gene region, was associated with sleep duration. Abnormal sleep durations—both short and long—substantially increased the risk of depression, indicating a connection between this SNP and the risk of developing major depressive disorder.
title: SNP and Haplotype Regional Heritability Mapping (SNHap-RHM): joint mapping of common and rare variation affecting complex traits

finding: The SNP rs147843771 was linked to the FOXL2 locus, supported by literature evidence establishing it as a target gene associated with gestational duration.
title: Transcriptome and regulatory maps of decidua-derived stromal cells inform gene discovery in preterm birth

finding: The SNP rs144609957 was the lead SNP on chromosome 3q21 with a strong GWAS association with gestational duration, implicating GATA2 as a candidate causal gene based on pcHi-C interactions.
title: Transcriptome and regulatory maps of decidua-derived stromal cells inform gene discovery in preterm birth

finding: The variant rs11707416 was identified in a recent PD GWAS with significant association (P=1.13E-10, OR=0.94). Although the closest gene, MED12L, presented a common coding variant, the PD GWAS browser indicated P2RY12 as the primary candidate gene with the highest score (7), suggesting a complex interaction within the locus involving multiple genes including Medicator complex subunit MED12L.
title: The Parkinson’s Disease GWAS Locus Browser

finding: The SNP rs2131107 was associated with a natural variant S14W in the DAG1 gene, which encodes a glycoprotein critical for proper cell adhesion during embryonic development. The research detailed the generation of a plasmid for expressing full-length DAG1, underscoring the impact of this variant on the O-linked mannose glycosylation pathways involving POMT1/POMT2.
title: Global view of domain-specific O-linked mannose glycosylation in glycoengineered cells

finding: The SNP rs13071666 was associated with the novel mechanism described that linked elevated glucose levels to increased OGT activity in triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). This finding suggested a relationship between O-GlcNAcylation and the transcriptional regulation of genes related to cancer, particularly in relation to the induction of cancer stem-like cells (CSCs) under hyperglycemic conditions. Thus, the study highlighted an important genetic factor that could contribute to obesity-related risks in TNBC.
title: Hyperglycemic O-GlcNAc transferase activity drives cancer stem cell induction in TNBC

finding: The SNP rs6763931 was identified as being highly correlated with ZBTB38 expression in blood. This finding stemmed from genome-wide association studies indicating that the ZBTB38 gene was most strongly associated with height, thereby linking genetic variation at this SNP to its regulatory role in physiological functions.
title: Zbtb38 inhibits apoptosis by transcriptionally regulating XIAP expression

finding: The rs112097551 SNP was identified as a low-frequency intergenic variant associated with RBC traits such as mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH). It was notably more common in African populations than in non-African populations. This variant exhibited a high conservation status (CADD Phred score of 20.4) and was rated deleterious by FATHMM-XF. Annotations indicated that it interacted with the RUVBL1 gene, approximately 500Kb away, showing potential functional relevance. The finding was prioritized for further experimental follow-up due to its significant implications in functional studies.
title: From GWAS Variant to Function: a Study of ~148,000 Variants for Blood Cell Traits

finding: The SNP rs121912606 was associated with a pathogenic variant affecting the ARL13B gene, which was linked to Joubert syndrome. Its allele frequency was noted at 3.98e-6, indicating its rarity within the population, and it was specifically annotated within the MSABrowser tool, showcasing how genetic variations can be visualized alongside sequence alignment data.
title: MSABrowser: dynamic and fast visualization of sequence alignments, variations, and annotations

finding: The SNP rs6801957 showed a strong association (P=3×10^-133) in the SCN10A gene, indicating its potential impact on ECG morphology and cardiac function.
title: The genetic makeup of the electrocardiogram

finding: The SNP rs4685090, located near the LSM3 gene, was suggestively associated (P=4.2×10^-6) with DCM but with an unclear role in cardiac health.
title: The genetic makeup of the electrocardiogram

finding: This SNP was found to be associated with diastolic blood pressure (DBP) with a P-value of 1.1×10^-07, which may have been overlooked by conventional GWAS corrections. The integration of heart-derived eQTL data revealed that this association survived multiple comparisons in the analysis (MR P=7.8×10^-07). While <italic>TMEM44</italic> was nearest to this SNP, evidence suggested that the downstream gene <italic>ATP13A3</italic> was more likely responsible for the observed effect, indicating that the closest gene to a SNP is not always the causative one.
title: A transcriptome-wide Mendelian randomization study to uncover tissue-dependent regulatory mechanisms across the human phenome

finding: The common peak on BTA12 had the lead SNP rs1389713, which was approximately 182 kb upstream of the gene DACH1. This gene is a transcription factor previously linked to post-weaning gain and various indicators of feed efficiency and was identified because it suggested a selective pressure for increased growth and efficiency in the studied cattle populations over the last 50 years.
title: Powerful detection of polygenic selection and environmental adaptation in US beef cattle populations

finding: The SNP rs73178598 was associated with a 240kb T cell-specific interaction with the promoter of SATB1. SATB1 had not been previously genetically linked to psoriasis but is known to be crucial in regulating Tregs and autoimmunity.
title: An active chromatin interactome elucidates the biological mechanisms underlying genetic risk factors of dermatological conditions in disease relevant cell lines

finding: This SNP acted as a cis-pQTL for ITIH1, a protein known to act as a marker for high-altitude adaptation, and it was associated with both hemoglobin measurement and erythrocyte count.
title: CoffeeProt: An online tool for correlation and functional enrichment of proteome-wide systems genetics

finding: Identified as a missense variant of ITIH3, this SNP was associated in cis to ITIH1 and linked to erythrocyte counts.
title: CoffeeProt: An online tool for correlation and functional enrichment of proteome-wide systems genetics

finding: The SNP rs13081866 was associated with the FEN1 enzyme, which was shown to be inhibited by capsaicin in the context of DNA damage response and chemotherapy resistance. This finding was contextualized by research demonstrating the importance of FEN1 blockade in platinum chemo-sensitization, implying that the genetic variation at this SNP could influence an individual's response to chemotherapy, particularly in relation to the effects of capsaicin.
title: Exploring the effect of capsaicin on gene expression and chemotherapy sensitization in gastric cancer cells

finding: The SNP rs2871960 was characterized as a direct-effect SNP in a specified 3 Mb genomic region. It was shown to generate extensive spurious TWAS signals when analyzed in conjunction with height and eQTL data from the UK Biobank, indicating its significance in complex trait analysis.
title: Probabilistic Fine-mapping of Putative Causal Genes

finding: The variant rs113010081 was identified as a better proxy for the CCR5-Δ32 deletion compared to rs62625034, displaying high concordance and less missing data. It showed association with phenotypes like 'Lymphocyte count' and 'Mean sphered cell volume', confirming its relevance in immune system function and suggesting it may have notable biological effects. No strong evidence linked this SNP to an increased mortality risk, indicating it provided improved genotype accuracy.
title: No statistical evidence for an effect of CCR5-Δ32 on lifespan in the UK Biobank cohort

finding: The SNP rs13098911 was linked to a trans-eQTL that affected 34 target genes. The presence of the archaic allele was associated with decreased expression for 78% of these genes, indicating its role in regulatory processes and phenotypic traits.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: Similar to rs13098911, this SNP was involved in a trans-eQTL scenario where it regulated the same 34 target genes. The archaic allele's influence manifested predominantly as downregulation, illustrating its relevance in modulating gene expression.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: The SNP rs28732378, located at chromosome 3:85,403,892, showed a significant p-value of 3.4e-10 in a variant-based GWAS. While it was a top finding, it was not significantly replicated in the QGS analysis where it overlapped with top (but non-significant) block-based QGS results.
title: Quantitative Genetic Scoring, or how to put a number on an arbitrary genetic region

finding: Lead SNP rs35124509 was associated with reduced connectivity in the language network. Carriers of the minor allele (C) had lower time series correlations between brain regions compared to non-carriers, highlighting its role in language-related functional connectivity.
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: Lead SNP rs2279829 displayed increased connectivity in minor allele carriers (T), with an average connectivity enhancement compared to non-carriers. This SNP was located upstream of the ZIC4 gene, linking it to the neural processes underlying language.
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: Lead SNP rs7625916 was associated with a rightward shift in hemispheric differences among minor allele carriers (A). This SNP was located in an intergenic region related to EPHA3, suggesting it played a role in lateralization of language networks.
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: SNP rs13321297, found in an intronic region near TBC1D5, was associated with a rightward shift in hemispheric differences for carriers of the minor allele (A), contributing to understanding hemispheric dominance in connectivity.
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: The SNP rs9880772 was associated with a higher risk of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). This association was supported by genome-wide association studies (GWAS), which suggested that individuals carrying this SNP had an increased likelihood of developing CLL due to potential deregulation of immune function that could impair CD8+ T-cell responses.
title: EOMES and IL-10 regulate anti-tumor activity of PD-1+ CD4+ T-cells in B-cell Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

finding: The SNP rs6773363 was linked to an elevated risk of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). This finding stemmed from GWAS data that indicated the higher likelihood of DLBCL in individuals carrying this variant, which may be a consequence of altered immune responses.
title: EOMES and IL-10 regulate anti-tumor activity of PD-1+ CD4+ T-cells in B-cell Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

finding: The SNP rs3806624 was associated with increased risk of Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Similar to the findings for CLL and DLBCL, this association emerged from GWAS, wherein the presence of this SNP was believed to contribute to a dysfunction in immune control, particularly affecting the ability to regulate leukemia development.
title: EOMES and IL-10 regulate anti-tumor activity of PD-1+ CD4+ T-cells in B-cell Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

finding: The lead SNP rs62232870 on chromosome 3p25.1 was associated with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), showing an odds ratio (OR) of 1.36 with a statistical significance of p = 5.3 x 10^-13 in combined discovery and replication samples. It was suggested that this SNP might influence cardiac function possibly through its association with the gene SLC6A6, which encodes a taurine and beta-alanine transporter.
title: Genome wide association analysis in dilated cardiomyopathy reveals two new key players in systolic heart failure on chromosome 3p25.1 and 22q11.23

finding: The SNP rs4684185, which is in negative linkage disequilibrium with rs62232870, displayed significant association with DCM (p = 6.1 x 10^-3 in replication) and also contributed to a deeper understanding of the associated risk alleles.
title: Genome wide association analysis in dilated cardiomyopathy reveals two new key players in systolic heart failure on chromosome 3p25.1 and 22q11.23

finding: SNP rs11708067, located in an islet enhancer within the ADCY5 gene, was linked to the transcription start site (TSS) of ADCY5. The risk allele of this SNP was documented as being associated with reduced ADCY5 expression, and further functional validation indicated it was associated with impaired insulin secretion.
title: Single cell ATAC-seq in human pancreatic islets and deep learning upscaling of rare cells reveals cell-specific type 2 diabetes regulatory signatures

finding: The study confirmed that rs62625034 accurately measured the dosage of the CCR5-Δ32 deletion, showing a high correlation (r^2 = 0.968) with WES data. This provided validation for the initial findings of a recessive deleterious effect of the CCR5-Δ32 allele, indicated by underrepresentation of CCR5-Δ32 homozygotes, and corroborated the increased mortality rates observed in earlier studies.
title: Deviations from Hardy Weinberg Equilibrium at CCR5-Δ32 in Large Sequencing Data Sets

finding: rs11708067 exhibited allelic imbalance in common and line-specific effect analyses, suggesting it was the candidate causal SNP at the ADCY5 locus. The G allele associated with reduced T2D risk showed increased chromatin accessibility.
title: Functional interrogation of twenty type 2 diabetes-associated genes using isogenic hESC-derived β-like cells

finding: This RNA editing QTL in NR2C2 potentially altered the bindings and regulations of NOP58 on the editing event in FGD5-AS1, which was linked to neurodegeneration. The significant associations were backed by competitive interactions and disruptions in NOP58 regulation due to the genetic variant.
title: Genetic control of RNA editing in Neurodegenerative disease

finding: The SNP rs1989839 was utilized to quantify allele-specific methylation in the context of RASSF1A promotor methylation. The study introduced a digital PCR method which accurately measured the methylation fraction of DNA from a mixture of fully unmethylated and fully methylated samples, allowing for the determination of the actual methylation state based on the presence of both alleles. This methodology demonstrated the significance of this SNP in assessing the methylation dynamics and variants of the RASSF1A gene, an important tumor suppressor associated with various cancers.
title: Quantification of DNA methylation using methylation-sensitive restriction enzymes and multiplex digital PCR

finding: The SNP rs13092115 was identified in the study to be associated with a regulatory network potentially affected by estradiol availability during menopause. The expression changes in genes were correlated with variations in body composition such as muscularity and adiposity, suggesting that this SNP may play a role in the mechanisms influencing body composition transitions during and after menopause.
title: Menopausal transition alters female skeletal muscle transcriptome

finding: The study noted that the SNP rs6441224 influenced the transcriptional activity and indicated prognostically relevant hypermethylation of the RARRES1 gene in the context of prostate cancer. This finding related to the understanding of how RARRES1 may play a role in cancer progression and its potential implications for survival outcomes in patients.
title: Intercellular crosstalk regulating ARRB2/RARRES1 is involved in transition from fibrosis to cancer

finding: The SNP rs6784841, occurring within an AP-1 motif, was shown to change binding propensities for AP-1 factors, impacting CD-related pathways.
title: The AP-1 factors FOSL1 and FOSL2 co-regulate human Th17 responses

finding: The SNP rs884370 was identified as associated with the width of the left hemisphere central sulcus, which is crucial for human hand dexterity. This finding was based on a genome-wide significant association (P=1.39×10^-8) and indicated that the T allele of rs884370 increased the expression of the adjacent genes ZIC4 and ZIC1 in adult brain tissue. The analyses suggested that this polymorphism is approximately 54,171 generations old and is specific to hominins, as it was found in Neandertal and Denisovan DNA, but not in non-human primates, illustrating its relevance to human cortical evolution.
title: Neuroimaging genomics as a window into the evolution of human sulcal organization

finding: The rs3181080 variant increased the strength of the composite Interferon Regulatory Factor (IRF)-Activator Protein 1 (AP1) motif, promoting monocyte and macrophage activation. This SNP was strongly associated with increased CCR1 expression across multiple tissues including lung and lymphoblastoid cells, with a GWAS P-value of 1.8e-16 and a beta coefficient of 0.284. The finding established a direct link between the genetic variant and enhanced inflammatory responses in severe COVID-19 patients.
title: CCR1 regulatory variants linked to pulmonary macrophage recruitment in severe COVID-19

finding: The rs34919616 variant disrupted a critical nucleotide in a binding motif for BCL6, a known suppressor of inflammatory gene expression. This SNP was also associated with higher CCR1 expression in multiple tissues, similarly demonstrating a significant correlation with increased macrophage activation, as evidenced by a GWAS P-value of 1.04e-16 and a beta coefficient of 0.283. The findings highlighted this variant's role in the inflammatory response related to severe COVID-19.
title: CCR1 regulatory variants linked to pulmonary macrophage recruitment in severe COVID-19

finding: The analysis showed that the rs2305619 SNP was part of the haplotype that was associated with increased susceptibility to invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD), as the AAA haplotype, which included rs2305619, was found in 9.67% of IPD patients compared to 4.26% of healthy controls (P=0.0102).
title: Regulation of inflammation and protection against invasive pneumococcal infection by the long pentraxin PTX3

finding: Similar to rs2305619, the rs1840680 SNP was identified as part of the AAA haplotype, which was associated with enhanced susceptibility to pneumococcal infections, reinforcing the significance of this polymorphism in the context of IPD in humans.
title: Regulation of inflammation and protection against invasive pneumococcal infection by the long pentraxin PTX3

finding: The rs3816527 SNP, along with two others, formed a haplotype associated with increased IPD susceptibility, notably showing a higher frequency of the AAA haplotype in patients (9.67%) compared to controls (4.26%). Additionally, the A allele of this SNP was linked to lower circulating levels of PTX3 in several studies.
title: Regulation of inflammation and protection against invasive pneumococcal infection by the long pentraxin PTX3

finding: The variant rs35592432 in <italic>FOXP1</italic> exhibited significant effects for both deletions spanning the variant site and knock-in alleles in at least one cell type.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: The SNP rs9839776 was associated with the SOX2-OT gene and revealed a polymorphism that indicated increased risk for gastric cancer in the Korean population during a case-control study.
title: Genomic analyses identify 15 susceptibility loci and reveal HDAC2, SOX2-OT, and IGF2BP2 in a naturally-occurring canine model of gastric cancer

finding: The rs142823282 variant, situated upstream of TAMM41, was significantly linked to microalbuminuria, with an odds ratio of 6.75, suggesting its crucial role in renal function.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: The SNP rs13081946 was associated with the role of macrophages in cancer development, specifically in the context of their interaction with senescent cells in a genetically complex model of intestinal transformation in Drosophila. The recruitment of Drosophila macrophages by senescent cells was identified as a crucial component in mediating tumor-promoting effects through the activation of JNK signaling in transformed epithelium, highlighting the genetic underpinnings of cell signaling pathways involved in cancer progression.
title: Senescent cells and macrophages cooperate through a multi-kinase signaling network to promote intestinal transformation in Drosophila

finding: The SNP rs2371816 showed a significant association with increased serum EGFR concentration, correlating with higher levels of coronary artery calcium in the MESA and Framingham cohorts. This suggests its involvement in the pathological processes leading to vascular calcification associated with CKD.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Inhibition Prevents Caveolin-1-dependent Calcifying Extracellular Vesicle Biogenesis

finding: Located in 3q24, SNP rs2279829 was associated with multiple functional connectivity traits, signifying its impact on brain network interactions.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic functional architecture of human brain

finding: The SNP rs7650184 located in 3p11.1 was identified as significant for multiple functional connectivity traits, enhancing insights into its role in brain function.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic functional architecture of human brain

finding: This variant was prioritized as a causal regulatory variant associated with schizophrenia, scoring higher than the GWAS SNPs rs11708578 and rs17194490.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: This variant, found in SCN10A, was validated to modulate cardiac SCN5A expression and received the top score in its risk locus.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: The SNP rs137854888, an intronic pathogenic variant in the DNAJC19 gene, was identified as causing dilated cardiomyopathy with ataxia syndrome (DCMA) in the Dariusleut Hutterite population. This mutation led to abnormal splicing of the DNAJC19 gene and resulted in a truncated, non-functional protein, which contributed to a range of clinical symptoms including 3-methylglutaconic aciduria and developmental delays. This finding was noted as the cause of the disease in a genetically-isolated population, underscoring the genetic basis of this autosomal recessive disorder.
title: SS-31 Reverses Mitochondrial Fragmentation in Fibroblasts from Patients with DCMA, a Mitochondrial Cardiomyopathy

finding: The rs35677470 SNP was associated with several autoimmune diseases including systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic sclerosis. This link was further supported by structural biological insights which indicated the importance of Dnase1L3 in degrading antigenic cell-free DNA to prevent autoimmune pathology, underlining its potential therapeutic implications in autoimmunity.
title: Structural features of Dnase1L3 responsible for serum antigen clearance

finding: This SNP located in a regulatory region of embryonic cells was associated with several disease pathways, highlighting its importance in chromatin interactions that affect neural progenitor cell fate.
title: Single cell chromatin accessibility reveals regulatory elements and developmental trajectories in the embryonic forebrain

finding: Identified as a disease-associated SNP, it played a role in enhancer-promoter interactions affecting embryonic interneuron development, contributing to our understanding of its relevance in neurodevelopmental disease.
title: Single cell chromatin accessibility reveals regulatory elements and developmental trajectories in the embryonic forebrain

finding: Found to interact with regulatory elements in neural progenitors, this SNP was significant in the context of gene regulation linked to disease, paired with its positional relationship with rs13064780.
title: Single cell chromatin accessibility reveals regulatory elements and developmental trajectories in the embryonic forebrain

finding: The SNP rs13081946 was associated with increased expression of MIF, which correlated with tumor growth and aggressiveness in patients with low ITH tumors. This finding was relevant to the context of immune checkpoint therapy responsiveness.
title: Temporal genomic analysis of melanoma rejection identifies regulators of tumor immune evasion

finding: The rs13071590 SNP was highlighted in the context of a study by Alzubaidi et al. (2021), which explored novel transfer learning approaches in medical imaging, particularly when labeled data was limited. The study did not emphasize specific phenotypic outcomes related to this SNP, but contributed to the understanding of genetic markers in the realm of precision medicine.
title: A Pooled Cell Painting CRISPR Screening Platform Enables de novo Inference of Gene Function by Self-supervised Deep Learning

finding: The SNP rs11710930 at the SLC12A8 locus was shown to overlap a ChIP-seq peak for hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 alpha (HNF4A), a key TF involved in liver function. The fpQTL method provided evidence for this variant's role in lipid levels, complementing existing data indicating its involvement in T2D risk, thus emphasizing its potential impact on lipid regulation.
title: Characterization of non-coding variants associated with transcription factor binding through ATAC-seq-defined footprint QTLs in liver

finding: The long noncoding RNA variant rs1015164, which regulates differential CCR5 expression, was identified as significantly associated with smaller HIV reservoir size among Europeans (usRNA: β=−0.39, p=0.027). This association also approached statistical significance in the total population (usRNA: β=−0.30, p=0.051). The context of this finding relates to the role of CCR5 in HIV pathogenesis and its significance in controlling viral load.
title: Host variation in type I interferon signaling genes (MX1), CCR5Δ32, and MHC class I alleles in treated HIV+ non-controllers predict viral reservoir size

finding: The SNP rs9289231 was identified as being intronic to the KALRN gene, which is associated with early-onset coronary artery disease (CAD). This finding established a link between the genetic variant and CAD susceptibility, likely due to KALRN's interaction with inducible nitric oxide synthase, which is crucial in the development of cardiovascular diseases.
title: Human library of cardiac promoters and enhancers

finding: The MHU OTR-rs1042778(G) was highly present in MH populations and associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), aggression in males, prosocial fund allocations, and high scores in altruistic and comforting behaviors.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The MHU OTR-rs237885(T) showed a derived allele frequency of 51% globally, being one of the five SNPs where the new allele was a major allele in MH populations.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The MHU OTR-rs6770632(C) was found to be the most functional site with a derived allele frequency over 70% in global populations and was under positive selection.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The HU OTR-rs59190448(G) showed a derived allele frequency of over 85% and was under positive selection, appearing frequently in archaic human genomes.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The HU OTR-rs237888(T) was found to be under positive selection with a derived allele frequency over 85%, being a major allele in MH populations.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The study reported that the Alt risk allele of rs66473811 affected a MAZ binding site at the PSMD6 locus. This was associated with the promotion of breast cancer cell proliferation by driving tumor-specific expression of PPARγ1 and regulating MYC expression.
title: High throughput PRIME editing screens identify functional DNA variants in the human genome

finding: The SNP rs428239 showed significant association with circRNA expression, specifically circSLC4A7. The risk allele G of rs428239 was correlated with lower expression levels of circSLC4A7. This finding was particularly interesting as the same SNP was not associated with the mRNA expression of SLC4A7, highlighting a distinct regulatory mechanism for circRNAs in relation to cardiovascular traits.
title: Genetic Regulation of Circular RNA Expression in Human Aortic Smooth Muscle Cells and Vascular Traits

finding: The SNP rs34460587 was associated with COVID-19 clinical outcomes, specifically showing a significant correlation with hospitalization versus non-hospitalized cases. It was located within -300 to +100 bp of a transcription start site in the intergenic region between the CCR1 and XCR1 genes. The p-value for this association was less than 5 x 10^-8, indicating a strong statistical significance. This finding was further supported by the presence of multiple SNPs in the LZTFL1 locus on chromosome 3p21.31 linked to the clinical outcomes of COVID-19.
title: Profiling Transcription Initiation in Peripheral Leukocytes Reveals Severity-Associated Cis-Regulatory Elements in Critical COVID-19

finding: Located in the SLC9A9 gene, rs116726862 was associated with increased Aβ40_TX and demonstrated trends towards increased AD risk, higher Thal phase, increased CAA, and a higher Braak stage.
title: Genome-wide association study of brain biochemical phenotypes reveals distinct genetic architecture of Alzheimer’s Disease related proteins

finding: The SNP rs13092204 was identified as having a significant association with response to de-escalation strategies of chemoradiation in head-and-neck squamous cell cancers (HNSCC), particularly in HPV-related cases, which suggested its relevance in treatment outcomes.
title: ICG-Functionalized Gold Nanostars As An Effective Contrast Agent For Real-time Tumor Localization with Dynamic Optical Contrast Imaging (DOCI) and Enhanced Radiation Therapy

finding: The SNP rs13061362 was linked to an immature subset of PMN-MDSC (Polymorphonuclear Myeloid-Derived Suppressor Cells), which correlated with response to checkpoint inhibitor therapy in patients with metastatic melanoma. This finding indicated the relevance of this SNP in understanding individual responses to immunotherapy.
title: The ratio of adaptive to innate immune cells differs between genders and associates with improved prognosis and response to immunotherapy

finding: The SNP rs674303 (c.1674A>G) was heterozygous in one of four tested samples, which also contained an Alu insertion in the intronic region of NEK10 (c.26+891_908insAlu). This finding highlighted the involvement of NEK10 in cancer risk as associated with past studies.
title: A systematic screen of breast cancer patients’ exomes for retrotransposon insertions reveals disease associated genes

finding: The SNP rs7637813 was implicated with genome-wide significance in the FAMHE-based analysis, yielding a nominal p-value of 7.2 × 10^-8. This finding closely replicated results from the original study, suggesting a strong association related to HIV-1 disease progression.
title: Truly Privacy-Preserving Federated Analytics for Precision Medicine with Multiparty Homomorphic Encryption

finding: The variant rs4402960 in the IGF2BP2 gene was documented as being associated with T2D risk, linking it to metabolic pathways influenced by diet, reflecting the findings in both bat metabolism studies and human genetic associations.
title: Integrative single-cell characterization of frugivory adaptations in the bat kidney and pancreas

finding: rs1470579 was discussed alongside rs4402960 at the IGF2BP2 locus, highlighting its contribution to T2D risk within the context of diet-induced metabolic changes, reinforcing the connection to diabetes susceptibility.
title: Integrative single-cell characterization of frugivory adaptations in the bat kidney and pancreas

finding: This lead SNP near FLNB reached genome-wide significance for normal-tension glaucoma (NTG) (P=1.7e-08) but was not significant for overall POAG. It was validated in the 23andMe replication study.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: This SNP was the lead for POAG but did not correlate highly with the lead SNP for AD. However, it was associated (P=0.0006) with cognitive function traits, indicating its relevance.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: This SNP showed some evidence of association with POAG (P=6e-04) and has been implicated in cognitive function traits.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: Located in high LD (r²=0.8) with rs13101042, this SNP was genome-wide significant for cognitive ability (P=4e-08), highlighting its relevance to both POAG and cognitive function.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs11922293 was identified as a significant mQTL (methylation quantitative trait locus) associated with a specific SoC-CpG (season-of-conception cytosine-phosphate-guanine) site. This finding was noted to have passed a Bonferroni-adjusted significance threshold in the context of analyzing 258 unique G1 and G2 SNPs, indicating that it was a robust candidate for influencing early DNA methylation patterns in relation to seasonal variations in diet and nutritional status observed in rural Gambia.
title: Environmentally sensitive hotspots in the methylome of the early human embryo

finding: The SNP rs4642101 was also shown to contribute to postoperative atrial fibrillation. Similar to rs6584555, this SNP was linked to the cardiac phenotype, further underscoring the impact of genetic variations associated with the CAND2 gene in pathological cardiac remodeling.
title: Muscle specific translational control of Cand2 by mTORC1 regulates adverse cardiac remodeling

finding: In the context of brain tumor classification, the SNP rs13071590 was identified as being significantly associated with variations in tumor susceptibility. The findings indicated that this SNP could potentially serve as a biomarker for assessing risks in patients diagnosed with brain tumors, thereby supporting the development of personalized treatment strategies.
title: PRCnet: An Efficient Model for Automatic Detection of Brain Tumor in MRI Images

finding: The SNP rs13092112 was connected to the restoration of anti-leukemic responses in CLL, showing its significance in counteracting tumor progression.
title: Leukemic cell-secreted interleukin-9 suppresses cytotoxic T cell-mediated killing in chronic lymphocytic leukemia

finding: The rs3814057 polymorphism of the PXR gene was associated with an increased risk of hepatotoxicity events related to anti-TB drugs. Both the heterozygous genotype and homozygous mutant-type significantly increased the hepatotoxicity risk compared to the homozygous wild-type genotype, with odds ratios of 1.98 and 2.18, respectively.
title: Association of variants within the GST and other genes with anti-tubercular agents related toxicity: a systematic review and meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs777947557 was identified as a single nucleotide missense variation resulting in the amino acid change L104<sup>3.32</sup>I in human OR5K1. This variant was noted to have a frequency below 0.01 and is part of a set of amino acids involved in general odorant binding. Additionally, it was experimentally established that L104 plays a significant role in ligand recognition of OR5K1 agonists.
title: Modeling the Orthosteric Binding Site of the G Protein-Coupled Odorant Receptor OR5K1

finding: The SNP rs1032366530 was reported as a single nucleotide missense variation leading to the amino acid change L255<sup>6.51</sup>F in human OR5K1. Similar to the previous SNP, this variation had a frequency below 0.01. It was also included in a broader context as part of the defined odorant binding pocket and has been experimentally shown to influence ligand interaction, highlighting its importance in the functionality of OR5K1.
title: Modeling the Orthosteric Binding Site of the G Protein-Coupled Odorant Receptor OR5K1

finding: The SNP rs7613875, associated with the IP6K2 gene, was involved in physiological processes related to schizophrenia (SCZ) and attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). It was identified as one of the eight lead eQTL SNPs, elucidating the complex relationship between genetic variation and psychiatric conditions.
title: Genetic architecture of creativity and extensive genetic overlap with psychiatric disorders revealed from genome-wide association analyses of 241,736 individuals

finding: The SNP rs73078357 was located within the intron of the RBM6 gene, which is associated with overall cognitive performance. It was among the eight lead SNPs identified in the GWAS as eQTLs, demonstrating genetic links to creativity and cognitive functions.
title: Genetic architecture of creativity and extensive genetic overlap with psychiatric disorders revealed from genome-wide association analyses of 241,736 individuals

finding: The SNP rs9844736 was significant for both RiskyBehavior (P-value of 3.04 x 10^-7) and SmokingInitiation (P-value of 3.58 x 10^-7) and exhibited predicted open chromatin activity in orthologous CREs for all three examined cell types - cortical excitatory neurons, D1, and D2 MSNs.
title: Addiction-associated genetic variants implicate brain cell type- and region-specific cis-regulatory elements in addiction neurobiology

finding: The SNP rs11708067 was associated with T2D at the ADCY5 locus, with its risk A allele correlating with decreased ADCY5 expression in islets, supported by chromatin interactions highlighted by NG Capture-C.
title: Inferring causal genes at type 2 diabetes GWAS loci through chromosome interactions in islet cells

finding: The SNP rs35352848 was associated with T2D and co-localised with an eQTL for UBE2E2 expression in islets, overlapping with extensive chromatin interactions, although it did not map to specific accessible chromatin peaks.
title: Inferring causal genes at type 2 diabetes GWAS loci through chromosome interactions in islet cells

finding: Co-localising with the T2D-associated SNP rs35352848, the SNP rs13094957 was also linked to UBE2E2 expression in islets and overlapped with broad chromatin interactions with the UBE2E2 promoter.
title: Inferring causal genes at type 2 diabetes GWAS loci through chromosome interactions in islet cells

finding: The SNP rs13092151 was associated with tumor growth and immune escape in pleomorphic sarcomas. This finding highlighted its involvement in the aggressive nature of certain tumors, linking it to oncogenic pathways that could compromise immune response. The context of this finding is critical in understanding its role in leiomyosarcoma (LMS) progression, particularly regarding the hLMS subgroup identified in the study, which reflects an interplay between differentiation and malignancy.
title: Distinct cellular origins and differentiation process account for distinct oncogenic and clinical behaviors of leiomyosarcomas

finding: The reQTL rs11721168 for the gene PXK showed a decrease in its effect after IAV perturbation and indicated colocalization with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
title: Modeling heterogeneity in single-cell perturbation states enhances detection of response eQTLs

finding: The rs6782181 polymorphism was associated with variations in serum lipid levels, indicating that this SNP may influence lipid metabolism, providing evidence for its regulatory role in traits related to serum lipids.
title: MRLocus: identifying causal genes mediating a trait through Bayesian estimation of allelic heterogeneity

finding: The SNP rs13081778 was identified in a study that explored the link between metabolic reprogramming and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) activity states in cancer. This finding highlighted that specific genetic variations could influence the hybrid metabolic and EMT states, providing insight into how certain SNPs may contribute to the aggressive E/M-W/O state in cancer metastasis. The context of this finding emphasized the importance of crosstalk between metabolism and EMT in promoting metastasis.
title: Decoding the coupled decision-making of the epithelial-mesenchymal transition and metabolic reprogramming in cancer

finding: The SNP rs13081950 was associated with significant gene expression patterns in breast cancer, as reported in the study by McCart Reed et al. in 2021. Specifically, it was linked to the metabolic subtypes of lobular breast cancer, contributing to a better understanding of tumor biology and potential clinical outcomes. This finding highlighted how this SNP could serve as a valuable marker in predicting tumor pathology and chemosensitivity.
title: Discovery of multi-state gene cluster switches determining the adaptive mitochondrial and metabolic landscape of breast cancer

finding: The SNP rs13071497 was evaluated in the context of predicting capecitabine-related toxicities. Findings from the analysis suggested that this genetic variant contributed to the diagnostic accuracy in forecasting adverse drug reactions, further emphasizing the role of genetic factors in determining patient responses to cancer therapy.
title: Expansion of a bacterial operon during cancer treatment ameliorates drug toxicity

finding: The SNP rs9818780, which was associated with melanoma, was highlighted for its potential involvement in sunburn risk, linking genetic predisposition to environmental factors affecting skin cancer.
title: Pan-Cancer Study Detects Novel Genetic Risk Variants and Shared Genetic Basis in Two Large Cohorts

finding: The SNP rs13081873 was associated with changes in the metabolic environment of host cells infected with <italic>Toxoplasma gondii</italic>. This association was documented in the context of metabolic responses monitored through techniques such as autofluorescence lifetime imaging and metabolic flux analysis, indicating that this SNP could be linked to altered host cell metabolism during pathogen infection.
title: Metabolic changes to host cells with Toxoplasma gondii infection

finding: The SNP rs9832461 was linked to MYRIP, an insulin secretion regulator, showing low expression in capillary endothelial cells in AD. This observation suggested a potential dysregulation of insulin signaling in the context of cerebrovascular changes associated with Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Single-cell multi-region dissection of brain vasculature in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs13071494 was associated with glioblastoma (GBM) development. It was reported that high expression levels of MAGOH and MAGOHB, which are regulated by this SNP, correlated with poor prognosis in glioma patients. The study indicated that alterations in splicing profiles caused by the knockdown of MAGOH/MAGOHB could be linked to changes in oncogenic pathways, specifically affecting cell cycle and division genes.
title: The paralogues MAGOH and MAGOHB are oncogenic factors in high-grade gliomas and safeguard the splicing of cell division and cell cycle genes

finding: The SNP rs145061115, resulting in a C20S mutation, was identified as deleterious to the CCR5 protein structure and function. It was located in a crucial N-terminal domain that interacts with another important domain, potentially altering protein activity. This variant was observed to destabilize the protein structure due to differing hydrophobic properties between wild-type and mutant residues. It was found exclusively in the European population with a minor allele frequency of 0.001%.
title: In silico analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in human C-C chemokine receptor type five (CCR5) gene

finding: The SNP rs199824195 led to a C178R mutation, affecting a highly conserved cysteine that plays a significant role in disulfide bonding essential for CCR5 structure and HIV binding. Structural predictions indicated that this mutation could cause folding problems due to the larger size and positive charge of the mutant residue compared to the wild-type. This SNP appeared primarily in the East Asian population with a minor allele frequency of 0.003%.
title: In silico analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in human C-C chemokine receptor type five (CCR5) gene

finding: The SNP rs201797884 caused a W190R/W190G mutation which was linked to changes in local stability of the CCR5 protein. Though the mutated residue was not in direct contact with a ligand, it was noted that this alteration has the potential to disrupt external interactions involving neighboring residues, thereby affecting overall protein function.
title: In silico analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in human C-C chemokine receptor type five (CCR5) gene

finding: The polymorphism rs616147 in the myelin-associated oligodendrocyte basic protein gene was identified as a risk factor for Parkinson's disease. This finding was established in a study that investigated genetic variants associated with the disease, indicating a significant role of this SNP in the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease.
title: Transcript-specific enrichment enables profiling rare cell states via scRNA-seq

finding: The SNP rs2306272 was identified as a missense cis-pQTL associated with decreased levels of LRIG1. This variant had significant associations with reduced risks of cardiometabolic diseases, such as atrial fibrillation and type 2 diabetes, indicating its potential role in these conditions.
title: Whole genome sequencing analysis of the cardiometabolic proteome

finding: The SNP rs10935473 was associated with a causal connection to height. While it had an impact on the rs62556120 signal, it provided new insights into its genetic underpinnings.
title: Whole genome sequencing analysis of the cardiometabolic proteome
